story:
Help a Bastard Get to Edinburgh.

Hey, fans!  Red Bastard need your help! Please like and repost this campaign!

Something is happening with Red Bastard that I never expected.  Something that I think is unique in theatre and VERY unique for a comedy show.

It has become an award-winning show that is literally changing people's lives.

  • Winner:  Best in Theatre
  • Winner:  Best in Fest
  • Winner:  Most Outrageous Show
  • Winner:  Community Commitment Award
  • Winner:  Best Solo Performance

I've spoken to people who have quit their miserable jobs after seeing the show who went on to start their own careers!  Someone made a marriage proposal, just last week.  A man reunited with his estranged sister whom he hadn't spoken to for 8 years.  All of these things took place at the show, in front of the audience.  We can only imagine what might have happened in private after the show.

This is a show where real things happen.

Really amazing things,  really scary things, and really funny things.  It's a very special show and Edinburgh is a great opportunity to put this show in fron of European and American Producers.

Please help me do that. 

 

What We Need

Producing in Edinburgh ain't cheap. Most people lose money at the festival.  It takes a lot to be noticed in a festival of over 2300 shows.  But I've put together a team that I think will help me do that.

I'll be with Assembly, one of the best producing houses at the festival, I'm working with Impressive PR, which is already securing me interviews and features for newspapers and magazines.  

My goal for the festival, will simple be to work my ass off, break even and put the show in front of European and American Producers who will help me to build an international Red Bastard Tour.  

Here are examples of costs:

  • $4000 Housing- 2 BR Flat in Edinburgh (myself and David Berga, who will meeting wtih producers and attempting to make bookings for the show)
  • $3500  Publicist  (Impressive PR.  They've secured a feature with the Scotsman, which is a huge coup!)
  • $2300 Flights
  • $3050 Ad in the Fringe Guide, And Foamex large posters
  • $1080  15,000 flyers and 300 posters.
  • $450 Edinburgh Fringe Entry Fee
  • $2290  flyering Team to flyer potential audiences at the festival.

There are other expenses, too.  (Venue Rental, Equipment Rental, Food etc...)  But htis is my goal to get the above expenses covrerd. If I can do that, I will be in great shape

What You Get

$25 gets you a 2x3" Red Bastard Button.  Keep it where you most need it and Red Bastard's eyes will constantly be asking you-  "Do you Dare?..."

$100 gets you an Autographed Poster of Red Bastard complete with a lipstick kiss! 

$1000 And you'll get a private and exclusive Video made from Red Bastard just for you. Who knows what it will be?  Not even me!!!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't contribute money at the monent.  You can still help!  

1.  Please tell people about the campaign.

Use the Indiegogo Share tools.  Tell people on Facebook, twitter or email.A few clicks might make a huge difference in bringing this show to Edinburgh, and bringing the show to Edinburgh could make a huge difference in taking it around the world.

2.  Maybe you know a producing house/ producer/ or U.S. booker who might be interested in the show.  Make an introduction.  I"ve got a packet ready to give to them with photos, 5 star reviews, awards and a description of the show.

story:
Short Summary

For a small company, receiving national recognition is a dream come true! Getting there is the harder part. This is the 35th anniversary of Ballet Theatre of Maryland and 10th anniversary season for the artistic director, Dianna Cuatto. As a local company, our mission is to enrich our community through art and ballet in particular. We are a non-profit organization and most of our dancers devote their time for little to no monetary compensation. It is a struggle to stay afloat when many Marylanders do not even know we exist. In order to afford living expenses, most of our dancers work second jobs. Whether that be waiting tables, retail, teaching dance, or tutoring, money and time is tight. On top of living expenses, dancers have other non-negotiable expenses, the largest one perhaps being pointe shoes. A dancer can spend up to $3000.00 on pointe shoes per year. At a larger company those expenses are covered but at a smaller company like BTM, dancers receive only a small stipend per show toward their shoes. Hence developed our project!

Our goal is to raise money for a pointe shoe fund that would allow all our dancers to consistently dance on good, safe shoes for the 2013-2014 season. This would greatly improve the quality of our rehearsal time and it would be energizing and motivating to see BTM be capable of providing such an advantage to its dancers. Good shoes are a huge asset to ensuring the longevity of our bodies and thus the longevity of BTM as a reputable ballet company! Not to mention, we cannot put on our many creative mainstage performances without them!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal of $15,000 would be an amazing beginning to an ever growing fund to keep all of our dancers - full company members, apprentices, and trainee 3's - in pointe shoes all season long. In return for any contribution, small or large, Ballet Theatre of Maryland will show appreciation by thanking donors with a unique reward! Donors are not purchasing these items rather being acknowledged with a gift for their generosity. All donations are tax deductible and rewards will be distributed at the completion of the 60 day campaign!

The Impact

The best way to express the positive impact and great value of having a fully functioning professional company in Annapolis is through a quote by the Artistic Director herself:

"Our professional company aims to inspire our audience through the transforming power of American dance. Energy, athleticism, dynamism and passion are classic American dance ideals that move our dancers to achieve higher levels of artistry and skill, whether through the drama of contemporary pieces or by making classic ballet storytelling come to life.

Our school of Classical and Contemporary Dance is the only school in Maryland that offers a fully comprehensive ballet training program for the beginner student up to the professional dancer. Our focus on the healthy body aesthetic, healthy body types, and healthy mentoring is a hallmark of our school and company.

In my tenth season as Ballet Theatre of Maryland’s Artistic Director, I'm looking forward to continuing to produce high-caliber ballet performances that engage the mind and spirit and express Maryland’s unique voice through movement. My goal is to make ballet accessible to all while attaining ever higher levels of artistic excellence."

-Dianna Cuatto

It's not always easy to find consistent support in such a small town but we are growing every year. While the company's budget cannot yet provide the dancers with the shoes that needed to keep bringing our art to the community, we are hoping that taking this proactive approach will serve as the impetus to that next step!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone will be able to contribute and that is okay! Do you know anybody near or far that might be interested in our cause? Help us find people that might be interested in contributing - ask folks to get the word out!  "Indiegogo" has some great share tools to help make some noise about our campaign.

 

*Photography credit to David Hartcorn, Debby Helman, and Donna Cole

story:
I am a choreographer, living and working in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. I'm an artist, a dreamer, a fighter - a son, husband, and lover...

In April 2008, I was commissioned by famed mezzo soprano, Patricia Ruggles, to choreograph and perform a 25-minute solo entitled Chanson D'Ève, a meditation on the life of Eve, as written in the words and score by Gabriel Fauré, and accompanied by pianist, Paul Zeigler.

An opportunity has emerged to remount this work.

On Tuesday, April 23rd, I will present a remounted version of Chanson D'Ève, with five of Toronto's most luminous female dancers (Laurence Lemieux, Claudia Moore, Heidi Strauss, Linnea Swan, and Stéphanie Tremblay Abubo).  Patricia Ruggles and Paul Zeigler are traveling from the United States to reprise their original roles in the performance.

All proceeds from the ticket sales of this performance will benefit the YWCA Toronto, and the choreographic work will be gifted to the organization upon the completion of this evening's performance.

Your donation means so much to me.  

Your donation provides an opportunity for two world-class musicians to travel to Toronto and perform in Canada for the first time.  Your donation shows your support for dance and music, and the power that it has to transform and contribute to the society in which we live.

I'm raising $5000 to cover the costs of the production, including:

  • artist's fees and honoraria
  • artist's travel/accommodation/per diem, for Patricia and Paul
  • sets/costumes/props
  • food/wine at the event (for 70 people)
  • piano tuning
  • rehearsal studio rentals

All money raised through this campaign, not spent on the production costs will go directly to the YWCA Toronto. (I am waiving my choreographic fee, and providing my services at no cost to the production.)

There are some amazing perks for donating...

CDs, original prints by Seth Ruggles Hiler, a dinner package for two, and tickets to the event... so please contribute to the campaign!  Every dollar is appreciated.

If you are unable to donate, please consider spreading the word about this campaign - share it or send the link to your friends and family.

For further information on the event, find us on Facebook (Chanson D'Ève).

I thank you so much for your consideration...

Michael Caldwell, choreographer & event organizer

 

 

 

Further information about the performance:

Chanson D’Ève features the Canadian premiere of Michael Caldwell’s Chanson D’Ève, a choreography for five luminous female dancers (Laurence Lemieux, Claudia Moore, Heidi Strauss, Linnea Swan, and Stéphanie Tremblay Abubo) followed by Gabriel Fauré’s song cycle of the same name. The piece is accompanied by mezzo soprano, Patricia Ruggles, and pianist, Paul Zeigler – both acclaimed for their work in New York City. With a blend of mysticism and sensuality, Chanson D’Ève details the life of Eve, from “newborn whispers” to the “breath of the dead”.

Also, Paul Zeigler’s Hafiz Sufi Songs, as sung by Patricia Ruggles, receives its Canadian premiere as well – a collection of six songs drawn from the poetry of Hafiz (1320-1389), one of Islam’s greatest literary wonders. The Sufis cherish the poetry of Hafiz as a perfect expression of the human experience of divine love. 

Additionally, visual artist, Seth Ruggles Hiler will create a series of drawings/paintings for exhibition at the event.www.sethruggleshiler.com

Chanson D’Ève is a celebration of women through dance/music/art.

 

Tuesday, April 23rd

7:15pm – pre-show reception + art exhibit

8:00pm – performance

 

The Citadel Theatre at Regent Park

304 Parliament Street

Toronto, ON M5A 3A4

 

For further information:

Find us on Facebook! (Chanson D’Ève)

story:
What's up with the baby?"

So, one day I was sitting in my apartment, once again, thinking about this play I've always dreamt of doing called The Baby Dance by Jane Anderson. It's a piece that's such a slice of heaven for actors...beautiful writing and a good, old rollercoaster of emotions that are blended with wonderful humor to boot. And, for the audience, it's a beautiful night of theater so it's a big win-win all around.

Then, it hit me that I actually could do it if I got the rights. So, I applied and, low and behold, I got 'em - so a huge YAY to that! Now, I'm writing you to ask for your support to get "The Baby Dance" from my wishlist to the stage.

Does a baby really dance in the play? Because that would be awesome.

No, but good question, my friend. It does, however, have many other levels of awesomeness. The Baby Dance is a beautifully, written piece about an L.A. couple who want to have children but can’t. Out of their desperation, they arrange to buy an unborn child from a dirt-poor Southern couple. The play also has so much to say about families, poverty and disparity between the classes.

Plus, being a good Southerner, I was particularly drawn to the poor couple. Initially, the audience thinks ‘Oh, I know who they are. They’re poor dumb, Southerners,” but as the play progresses, they realize they are far from that characterization. It’s just a beautifully written piece that really touches audiences and deserves to be produced again.

What you'll get by donating to The Baby Dance or, a.k.a., good Karma goes a long way.

The Baby Dance will have a six-week run from March 1st to April 14th on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. The fundraising goal is $9,500 that would cover all production costs from theater rental to rehearsal space and from director and designer fees to publicity. Every dollar donated would be spent on the production and every dollar dollar is so appreciated! Please check out the perks that are listed for you!

Also, please feel free to share this with folks you know who love good theater, love giving away moolah or just love helpin a gal out. Seriously, please feel free :)

story:
Why are we asking?
 
We are asking for money because we just won a spot at the global finals of "Destination Imagination", (you can look it up at http://www.globalfinals.org) but we go to a public school in downtown Toronto, and the finals are in Tennessee. Most of the schools going to finals are private and have access to funds that we don't have. Luckily  an anonymous donor has payed for most of our costs, but we still need a bit more. 
Please, we really want to compete and this would be an amazing experience for us.
 
 
Who are we?
 
We are a team of grade 6 students who had the opportunity to compete in an amazing competition called Destonation Imagaintion. In this competion we chose to compete in a challenge where we have 5 minutes to make a skit where there is a change in reality that we get given (e.g. There is no moon.) Then we get given a comunication type out of,
1. debate
2. Text messaging/email
3. slide show
4. Song
5. News show
6. Poetry 
 
After our 5 minutes of prep time we get 3 random nouns and we have 1 minute to make a slogan that we use in the skit.
Because it is improv all we have for props, costumes, and scenery are 8 white tee shirts and up to 16 washable markers to draw on the shirts with.  We just won second place in Ontario!

story:
Who is Ivy Theatre Company?

Ivy Theatre Company was founded by Audrey Alford, Katie Braden, and Gwenevere Sisco.  We are dedicated to dynamic storytelling that explores the human condition in a visceral way in order to provoke thought and challenge both the artist and the audience.  Our work climbs inside, up and over the walls that have confined and silenced the voices of the few and the oppressed.

In an effort to avoid asking for your generosity again and again, we are campaigning to fund our entire season.  The seeds have been sown, and we have three plays ready to take root, but we need your help.

 

Tell me more about this Season....

Black Ice, a new play by Lezlie Revelle, is being produced in association with Midtown International Theatre Festival in The Jewel Box at WorkShop Theatre in late July. This piece is hugely important to us as an LGBT-themed play, told from the perspective of a straight woman conquering her homophobia.  

Like Poetry, a new play by Kristian O'Hare, is being produced at FringeNYC in August. We are very excited to climb inside this experimental piece about a young man confronting his homosexuality with the help of his homeopathic doctor and his spirit guide, Walt Whitman. 

Mill Fire, Sally Nemeth's acclaimed work from the Women's Project, follows a young woman fighting against an oppressive system trying to put a price tag on the loss of her husband.  We have secured the rights and will be producing Mill Fire in the fall.

OK. I'm interested. Where's my money going?

We are serious bargain-hunters, so were keeping the budget extremely tight. That said producing three plays in Manhattan is a bold undertaking.  Here's an example of how you can contribute.

$10 (Seedling) covers the cost of 1/2 an hour of rehearsal space.
$25 (Roots) provides a few important props.
$50 (Sprout) will cover the cost of printing for marketing materials.
$100 (Bud) contributes to the stipend for one actor
$250 (Vine) provides a stipend for a stage manager.
$500 (Leaf) covers the cost of advertising for the Fringe.
$1000 (Branches) provides all our set pieces.
$2500 (Garden) provides for one week of performance space.


How Else Can I Help?

Come see our shows!  Not only will you be supporting Independent Theatre, but you will be supporting your community!  We are proud to donate a portion of proceeds from our shows to The Trevor Project, the leading national organization providing crisis intervention and suicide prevention services to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning youth. 

Spread the Word!  Share this page with anyone who's passionate about the arts or the subject matter of our shows! Follow us on Twitter, Like us on Facebook!  Tweet about our Campaign!

Who is Ivy Theatre Company?
Ivy Theatre Company was founded by Audrey Alford, Katie Braden, and Gwenevere Sisco.  We are dedicated to dynamic storytelling that explores the human condition in a visceral way in order to provoke thought and challenge both the artist and the audience.  Our work climbs inside, up and over the walls that have confined and silenced the voices of the few and the oppressed.
In an effort to avoid asking for your generosity again and again, we are campaigning to fund our entire season.  The seeds have been sown, and we have three plays ready to take root, but we need your help.
 
Tell me more about this Season....


Black Ice, a new play by Lezlie Revelle, is being produced in association with Midtown International Theatre Festival in The Jewel Box at WorkShop Theatre in late July. This piece is hugely important to us as an LGBT-themed play, told from the perspective of a straight woman conquering her homophobia.  
Like Poetry, a new play by Kristian O'Hare, is being produced at FringeNYC in August. We are very excited to climb inside this experimental piece about a young man confronting his homosexuality with the help of his homeopathic doctor and his spirit guide, Walt Whitman. 
Mill Fire, Sally Nemeth's acclaimed work from the Women's Project, follows a young woman fighting against an oppressive system trying to put a price tag on the loss of her husband.  We have secured the rights and will be producing Mill Fire in the fall.
OK. I'm interested. Where's my money going?


We are serious bargain-hunters, so were keeping the budget extremely tight. That said producing three plays in Manhattan is a bold undertaking.  Here's an example of how you can contribute.

$10 (Seedling) covers the cost of 1/2 an hour of rehearsal space.$25 (Roots) provides a few important props.$50 (Sprout) will cover the cost of printing for marketing materials.$100 (Bud) contributes to the stipend for one actor$250 (Vine) provides a stipend for a stage manager.$500 (Leaf) covers the cost of advertising for the Fringe.$1000 (Branches) provides all our set pieces.$2500 (Garden) provides for one week of performance space.How Else Can I Help?



Come see our shows!  Not only will you be supporting Independent Theatre, but you will be supporting your community!  We are proud to donate a portion of proceeds from our shows to The Trevor Project, the leading national organization providing crisis intervention and suicide prevention services to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning youth. 

Spread the Word!  Share this page with anyone who's passionate about the arts or the subject matter of our shows! Follow us on Twitter, Like us on Facebook!  Tweet about our Campaign!

story:
Short Summary

Tempting Tree produces theatre that seduces and fiercely engages in the cultural, philosophical and social discussions that affect young Canadian adults by telling stories that challenge our convention and force our audiences to confront their own beliefs. We're raising money for our upcoming production of TAPE by Stephen Belber. TAPE is not only an entertaining story that mixes nail-bitting drama and laugh-out-loud comedy but is an important play that asks serious questions about sexual violence and the choices that shape our lives. When high school friends Jon and Vince are reunited after years apart, an ugly secret forces them to face the people they’ve become. As a decade old love feud returns, a high stakes game of cat and mouse leads these former friends, and their high school crush Amy, to confront what really happened the night of their senior prom. A high-octane thriller that will leave audiences guessing till the very end, TAPE takes an unsavoury look at our teenage years and the moments we try to forget. 


What We Need & What You Get

Our company engages professional emerging artists under the Canadian Actor's Equity Indie 2.0 union agreement. In order to make this show possible we need to raise $15,000.00. If you help us reach our goal you can receive exciting perks like your name in the show playbill, a signed production poster, invitations to an exclusive pre-show talk with the Artistic Director and show designers. Post-show private cocktail reception with the cast and crew and limited VIP tickets to opening or closing night of the show. The funds from the campaign will go to employ young professionals and contract local business partners who are developing young businesses run by like-minded entrepreneurs.  


The Impact

Tempting Tree Theatre Collective is actively engaged in the community and local arts scene. As the 2013-2014 Young Company in Residence at The Arts Project, we are uniquely positioned to engage with other artists in the community and provide theatre for young-adults by young-adults. We have recently closed our professional production of Reasons to be Pretty by Neil Labute. Which ran for two weeks at The Arts Projects and explored what it means to be Pretty. Neil Labute’s, Reasons to be Pretty, dove beneath the shinny facade of two young couples to explore the raw, nasty, and often times ridiculous emotional truths of relationships, affairs and break-ups that we all know too well. This project is valuable to our community because it not only supports the local arts and culture scene but asks tough questions about who we are, how we grow up, and the danger of secrets. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can make a donation. If you want to help us out in other ways, you can get the word out by posting this fundraiser on your Facebook and twitter pages. Let people know that this is going on so we can bring and share this fantastic show with our community.

story:
Hi guys! Thanks for visiting out page! Our names are Alex Madda and Madeline Sharton, and we have both written one-woman shows that have been accepted to the United Solo Theatre Festival at Theatre Row in New York City in Fall 2014. We are so excited to be showcasing our respective shows at United Solo on 42nd Street in the next few months! Alex's show Prom Queen by Default debuted in January 2014, and Madeline's Power Play in May 2013. We are both graduates from the University of Michigan Department of Theatre & Drama, and after our successful trial runs at UofM, we are so excited to be making our Off-Broadway debuts in our original one-woman shows!

A little about our shows:

Prom Queen by Default (Sept. 26th):

Come follow the life and times of Alex Madda and her kooky college and high school career, seen through the magic of song and beginners’ dance. Audiences will sit on the train of her prom dress as they venture into stories of dance club woes, brunette insecurities, and the search for the most convenient post-college entry-level job.

Power Play (Oct. 23rd):

What are the powerful people among us getting away with? What invisible systems must we fight against? Whether we choose to examine the men who scarred the backs of slaves, the suits who stroll the White House corridors, or “The Most Popular Girl in School,” the truth remains that nothing is more powerful than power. Oh, except maybe chocolate.

What We Need & What You Get

In order for our professional debuts to become a reality, we have set a budget of $4000. This covers expenses pertaining to advertisement, travel, props, scenery, equipment, and studio rental space. 

We are both new, out-of-town artists, and for our shows to be fully realized, we feel that this is the appropriate amount needed to make our shows possible. With any donation you are able to give, you would help by fund

Funding Breakdown:

Plane Travel- $800
United Solo Website and Program Advertisement- $1000
Postcard and Snail Mail: $200
Props and Scenery: $400
Studio Rental Space: $1000
Equipment Rental: $200
Absence from Work: $400

For helping to fund our project, check out the fun incentives we've got in store! 

    The Impact

    As recent college graduates, we are two young artists entering the professional world of theatre. Having our first professional experience in an Off-Broadway New York City Theatre Festival is a risky one, but we know it's what we need to ignite this theatrical transition from university to professional theatre. New and original theatre is always in demand, and your donation would help fuel this ever so exciting genre of performance. 

      Challenges & Risks

      Our biggest challenge is getting our names and our shows publicized around the city. We know that we are competing with large theatrical productions all around the city, and we are aware that our shows are but a small fraction in comparison to the theatrical world around us. Your donation would help raise media and print attention for our shows, and help gather audiences from across the city. 

      Interested in Coming to Our Shows?

      If you interested in attending either of our shows or know anyone who you think would be interested, here are the links for our individual performances: 

      Prom Queen by Default, by Alex Madda. Sept. 26th @ 6pm: 

      http://unitedsolo.org/us/2014-promqueen/

      Power Play by Madeline Sharton. Oct. 23rd @ 7:30pm:

      http://unitedsolo.org/us/2014-powerplay/

      THANK YOU FOR HELPING MADELINE AND ALEX PURSUE THEIR FIRST PROFESSIONAL THEATRICAL ENDEAVORS! ANY DONATION HELPS!

story:
Hi everyone! What's going on? I’m Chase Smith and for the past 5 years I've been the Student Pastor and Worship Leader at Trinity Church in Salisbury, NC. God has blessed the time my wife and I have served there and is now starting us out on a new adventure!

In March, I received an invitation to attend a nationwide talent showcase in Orlando, FL through the Christian talent agency AMTC – Actors Models and Talents for Christ. AMTC is a non-profit, 501©(3) Christian ministry that’s been around for over 30 years.

This week long event in December will put me in front of hundreds of Hollywood agents and record label executives. They’ve launched thousands of careers and this is an INCREDIBLE opportunity to impact the world and further the Kingdom of God. But I need your help. I am trying to raise money to help pay for my trip. I need to raise $6,645 to cover my expenses, registration, professional training intensive weekends (professional talent training sessions with voice and acting coaches, and a professional photo shoot) round trip plane tickets, showcase auditions, and hotel reservations. 

I would like to model this support process after what Paul had to say in Philippians 4:10-19. In these verses, Paul is thanking the saints in Philippi for their aid while he was traveling to Macedonia and Thessalonica. Verse 17 says, “Not that I am looking for a gift, but I am looking for what may be credited to your account.”

Do not look at this as simply a gift, but yet an opportunity to invest in a ministry of God’s work. Let's be a part of God’s plan together! This decision you are going to make in one that you will be rewarded for in heaven. I don't want you to miss out!



How did you come up with $6,645?

Here is my campaign broken down in detail:


$3,395 - registration, trainings, auditions (singer songwriter / scene read / on camera)

$500 - orientation deposit

$1,300 - 2 round trip plane tickets (COL to ORL / ORL to COL)

$1,000 - hotel reservation (Dec 31-Jan 5 at $150 a night)

$75 - Cold Read Showcase

$75 - Improv Showcase

$75 - Group Improv Showcase

$75 - TV Presenter Showcase 

$75 - Product Endorsement Showcase

$75 - Stand-Up Showcase

Singer, scene read, on camera Showcases included above

TOTAL:  $6,645



Other Ways To Help!

If you can’t financially support this campaign, I understand. Here are a couple more ways you can help!

  • I would also like to ask for your support through prayer. Please pray for Leslie and me as we continue to follow God’s will and live a life worthy of the calling we have received!
  • Share my campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Reddit, and IndieGoGo! They have links and tools on this website to help you do this! The more people contributing the better!




Thank you so much for checking this video out! We will keep in touch! Until then, Grace and Peace to you all!

story:
Short Summary

lemonTree creations is presenting a new dance piece entitled MSM [men seeking men] inspired by transcripts of online conversations between men who seek other men. Set inside a world of electronic beats where music is the omnipotent power, the piece is a movement deconstruction of online male personas and their personal exchanges with other men.

The cast features queer dancers and actors:

Cole Alvis, Aldrin Bundoc, Corrado Cerruto, Andrew Hartley, Ryan G Hinds, Louis Laberge-Côté, Cyril Limousin

Live spinning by DJ Scooter (Cub Camp)

Concept/Direction INDRIT KASAPI

Dramaturgy JONATHAN SEINEN

Lighting/Set Design JOE PAGNAN

This project was supported by a Theatre Creators' Reserve recommendation from Cahoot's Theatre Company and is being developed in their Playwright's Hot House unit.

What We Need

We need to raise money to cover our production costs so that 100% of our ticket sales will go towards paying our incredible team of artists.
 
Production Costs include:
  • Fringe Festival Fee
  • Set Construction
  • Hazer Rental
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Marketing Costs (poster/postcard printing etc)

Why support lemonTree creations

lemonTree creations is a very small and young theatre company courageously working towards growth. For this project we rely on Box Office sales and donations from people like  you to reach our goal.
 
Your visionary support is extremely important as it fosters our young company and, with it, the growth of art and heritage of culture within our city and our country.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate at this time please support us by:
 

Buying a ticket to MSM [men seeking men] at the FRINGE - tickets available: www.fringetoronto.com

Spreading the word via twitter, facebook, instragram, blogs etc

 

Thank you!

story:
Summary & Description

“In Colour” is a dance show exploring the possible personalities of red, yellow, and blue. In this stage production brought to life with an original score, the dancers tell the story of these contrasting shades. Works of visual art will be specially created by a local artist (Jude Dixon) for the event and sold in the lobby, creating a truly unified artistic experience. Performers include head choreographer/producer Rebecca Karpus, Amanda Gillies, and Megan Wainman, alongside the music of Lindsay Warnock. Performed at the Evergreen Cultural Centre in Coquitlam Friday August 29th at 8:00pm, “In Colour” will be a curious, compelling and colourful piece of art. Tickets are $15 and can be purchased at https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/in-colour-tickets-10863401727

 Did you read somewhere that "In Colour" would be performed at a different venue than what is stated above? Recently our venue has changed to the Evergreen Cultural Centre in Coquitlam. Same time, same date, but different venue. Our apologies. 

I'm Rebecca Karpus, the producer, creator, and head choreographer of summer 2014’s “In Colour”. I grew up on the West Coast and began dancing at a young age, much like two of my good friends, Amanda Gillies and Megan Wainman. Truth be told, the three of us grew up together in the same dance schools, summer programs, competitions, and companies. In fact, Amanda and I are first cousins. These three ladies are the cast of “In Colour”.


  All of us are all extremely passionate about dance, leading us to careers in the field including the School of Alberta Ballet (Megan), Coastal City Ballet (Amanda), and Ryerson University, BFA: Dance (myself). However, dancing professionally is a very hard thing to do between frequently relocating one’s life on the drop of a hat, countless auditions, and chronic injuries. In the midst of a chaotic career as a dancer, it can be easy to lose sight of what one has right in front of them- good friends with good ideas. Therefore, once the three of us finally ended up in the same city at the same time, I grabbed the chance to pool our talent, our strengths, and our love for dance, to create something that we can call our own. After innumerable shows as a dancer in a company or in a school, we now have our opportunity to dance in our own entity that we call “In Colour”. This production is 100% for the passion of choreography, dance, and artistic vision. Ever since I was 14, “Create my own dance show” was on my lifelong bucket list. So here I am today, choreographing “In Colour” with these two remarkable ladies, and wanting to share our final product with you.

What We Need & What You Get

  We are hoping to raise $550 for this production. This money would go directly to costumes, the rental dance floor, props and small set pieces, the venue fee, promotional materials (posters, programs, etc.), and paying those involved in the show (primarily the performers and the composer).

  Be excited because we are offering some unique perks! If you contribute $50 (Package A), you will receive two complimentary tickets and a poster signed by the cast and the composer. If you contribute $100 (Package B), you will receive two complimentary tickets plus a free hour and a half dance class for you and/or a loved one, taught by one or more of the cast members. We are distributing ten Package A’s, and two Package B’s.

The Impact

  Support from you would impact so many young and diverse artists. Between three dancers, a visual artist, a composer, a graphic designer, a videographer, a production manager/lighting designer, and many more, we are a versatile crew of youthful and passionate artists. Offering us the finances to create this multifaceted piece would allow this artistic community to develop not only for our benefit, but also for our growing audience base.

  Your contribution would be greatly valued because it would show us that we are capable of creating work without the direct support of a large company/institution. Knowing that you support independent dance projects gives us the confidence to continue working within this structure, which we so enjoy. Your support impacts every artist involved in the piece, showing us that small productions are more than possible, creating a growing appreciation for the arts. We would deeply appreciate your contribution to help make our dreams become a reality—for the joy of dance, old friendships, and art.

Other Ways You Can Help

  Not in the financial position to contribute but still would like to help out? Thank you! You can help us by spreading the word on “In Colour”. Tell your friends and family about it and use social media (Facebook, Twitter, and so forth) to publicize the event. Having a full house would be the most incredible experience for us, so the more who know about it, the better! Make sure to pass along the date, location, and time, as well as the ticket information. As well, we always require volunteers. If you are free on the performance night and would like to give us a hand, give us a shout! More importantly though, please attend “In Colour”, if you can. The biggest gift is an interested audience, eager to enjoy original dance and music.

About Me

Rebecca Karpus is a dancer, dance instructor, choreographer, and graduate student at Simon Fraser University. She received her training at several Canadian dance institutions including Arts Umbrella, Pacific Dance Arts, and L’Ecole superieure de ballet du Quebec. After graduating from high school (through half day programs that allowed her more time to train) she attended the BFA: Dance Performance program at Ryerson University in Toronto. After three years of the program, Rebecca decided to complete her degree as a Bachelor of Performing Arts at Capilano University. Rebecca has taught at numerous lower mainland studios including The danceLAB, the Pro Arte Centre, and Adagio Rhythmic Academy. In September she will be starting her MA in Comparative Media Arts, specializing in dance history. Rebecca aspires to become a dance scholar/historian while continuing to teach, choreograph, and produce.

However, dancing professionally is a very hard thing to do between frequently relocating one’s life on the drop of a hat, countless auditions, and chronic injuries. In the midst of a chaotic career as a dancer, it can be easy to lose sight of what one has right in front of them- good friends with good ideas. Therefore, once the three of us finally ended up in the same city at the same time, I grabbed the chance to pool our talent, our strengths, and our love for dance, to create something that we can call our own. After innumerable shows as a dancer in a company or in a school, we now have our opportunity to dance in our own entity that we call “In Colour”. This production is 100% for the passion of choreography, dance, and artistic vision. Ever since I was 14, “Create my own dance show” was on my lifelong bucket list. So here I am today, choreographing “In Colour” with these two remarkable ladies, and wanting to share our final product with you.  
What We Need & What You Get  We are hoping to raise $550 for this production. This money would go directly to costumes, the rental dance floor, props and small set pieces, the venue fee, promotional materials (posters, programs, etc.), and paying those involved in the show (primarily the performers and the composer).  Be excited because we are offering some unique perks! If you contribute $50 (Package A), you will receive two complimentary tickets and a poster signed by the cast and the composer. If you contribute $100 (Package B), you will receive two complimentary tickets plus a free hour and a half dance class for you and/or a loved one, taught by one or more of the cast members. We are distributing ten Package A’s, and two Package B’s.  
The Impact  Support from you would impact so many young and diverse artists. Between three dancers, a visual artist, a composer, a graphic designer, a videographer, a production manager/lighting designer, and many more, we are a versatile crew of youthful and passionate artists. Offering us the finances to create this multifaceted piece would allow this artistic community to develop not only for our benefit, but also for our growing audience base.  Your contribution would be greatly valued because it would show us that we are capable of creating work without the direct support of a large company/institution. Knowing that you support independent dance projects gives us the confidence to continue working within this structure, which we so enjoy. Your support impacts every artist involved in the piece, showing us that small productions are more than possible, creating a growing appreciation for the arts. We would deeply appreciate your contribution to help make our dreams become a reality—for the joy of dance, old friendships, and art.  
  
Other Ways You Can Help  Not in the financial position to contribute but still would like to help out? Thank you! You can help us by spreading the word on “In Colour”. Tell your friends and family about it and use social media (Facebook, Twitter, and so forth) to publicize the event. Having a full house would be the most incredible experience for us, so the more who know about it, the better! Make sure to pass along the date, location, and time, as well as the ticket information. As well, we always require volunteers. If you are free on the performance night and would like to give us a hand, give us a shout! More importantly though, please attend “In Colour”, if you can. The biggest gift is an interested audience, eager to enjoy original dance and music.About Me
Rebecca Karpus is a dancer, dance instructor, choreographer, and graduate student at Simon Fraser University. She received her training at several Canadian dance institutions including Arts Umbrella, Pacific Dance Arts, and L’Ecole superieure de ballet du Quebec. After graduating from high school (through half day programs that allowed her more time to train) she attended the BFA: Dance Performance program at Ryerson University in Toronto. After three years of the program, Rebecca decided to complete her degree as a Bachelor of Performing Arts at Capilano University. Rebecca has taught at numerous lower mainland studios including The danceLAB, the Pro Arte Centre, and Adagio Rhythmic Academy. In September she will be starting her MA in Comparative Media Arts, specializing in dance history. Rebecca aspires to become a dance scholar/historian while continuing to teach, choreograph, and produce.

story:
"I have measured out my life with coffee spoons." -T.S. Eliot, The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock

Who are we?

CoffeeSpoons Theatre Project is a collective of passionate individuals who seek to put on free theatre that is accessible and inviting to anyone and everyone. The brainchild and obsession of Shanti Gonzales, raised in Dedham MA and theatre student at McGill University in Montréal, the Project returns for its second summer. 

There are those who see theatre as stale words, a stiff-backed chair, and a stuffy windowless room--we here at CoffeeSpoons hope to change that. We strive to breathe youthful and inspired life into the theatre, bringing comedic one-acts into a casual café setting. With CoffeeSpoons, "a night at the theatre" involves food, friends, drinks, and laughter. 

Our first production, selections from David Ives's All in the Timing, premièred in August 2013 at Paradise Café in Dedham. We were just a bunch of kids who loved the theatre enough to try and make something out of nothing. We were amazed to find our exhaustion and exhilaration rewarded by packed houses both nights. 

This year, CoffeeSpoons is again stirring up something exciting. We will be back at Paradise Café August 20-23, 2014 with three of Shel Silverstein's comedic one-acts from the collection An Adult Evening with Shel Silverstein. (Yup, he wrote plays too!) We also have many other surprises brewing here at CoffeeSpoons, but we need your help.

CoffeeSpoons is hoping to be bigger and bolder than ever this summer. Last year, we scraped by on Shanti's barista paycheck, with our costs eventually offset by generous audience donations. However, CoffeeSpoons's growth requires more. Please donate to our cause and help us continue to stir up an informal theatre experience like never before. 

Where is the money going?

Your donations will help us pay for all the things that make our show possible: from performance rights to props to costumes to manpower to publicity and much more. Every penny counts! Even if we don't reach our goal we will still be able to use these funds to make our Project bigger and bolder than ever before. If we do reach/surpass our goal, a portion of the funds will be reinvested in the Project to ensure that we keep coming back to serve our community. 

Other ways you can help!

Even if you can't donate, you can still help! Like and promote our Facebook page (facebook.com/coffeespoonstheatreproject) and spread the word about this Indiegogo campaign! 

Measure out your life with CoffeeSpoons. Thanks so much!

story:
Short Summary

I'm a stranger asking for help to make the world a little more beautiful. My name is Ally Baldwin. I am a Theater & Performance major at SUNY Purchase. I studied Psychology for two years before I switched my major. The mind has always been fascinating to me. This project is a devised collaboration in the style of a 'happening' based on dreams. My personal goal is to direct an unrestrictive theater art, which expresses truths that may be hard to face. I hope to accomplish a sense of community and a sense of self with my art. I want to take the audience on a tour of the mind and give them a better perspective on their life. 

    I created five characters for the piece. Three of them are the manifestations of insecurities. Another one symbolizes a redeeming quality.  There is also a narrator based on Mr. Grady from The Shining.
    This show focuses on abandonment and what causes people to build invisible walls within themselves and between the rest of the world.

What We Need & What You Get

The Ringmaster's Labyrinth will take place in 4 different rooms. It is absolutely vital for the show to have a surrealist setting in each of these rooms to create a dreamlike world. The money raised will go towards the set, props, costumes, posters, and programs.

Perks!! This is a completely immersive and interactive experience. If you donate a certain amount of money, you will receive a sticker to wear during the performance so the actors can identify you. You will become a part of the show. You have the opportunity to be pulled aside and have a personal experience with one of my actors.
  • If we don't meet our goal, all of the funds raised will be going towards set.

The Impact

This project does not happen without your support. If you donate, I will personally make sure your name is in the program. Because this show would not exist without you and you deserve recognition.


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The Last Five Years

The Last Five Years by Jason Robert Brown is an emotionally moving story of two young New Yorkers who fall in and out of love over the course of 5 years.  The twist? Their story is told twice: Jamie, the man, tells his story chronologically however Cathy, the woman, tells her story in reverse chronological order.  The two only meet once during the wedding in the middle of the story.  The result is a bittersweet juxtaposition of love and loss, beautifully told through Jason Robert Brown’s music and lyrics.

 

Who Are We?

Scruffy Duck Productions is Cork’s newest theatre company and we are breathlessly excited to present beautiful, engaging theatre.  Our experienced team of seven is composed of: Mark O Sullivan, Sherelle Kelleher, Catherine Gillespie, Derwin Myers, Mike Ryan, Jonathan Twomey, Hanan Sheedy, and Yaset Acevedo.  The Last Five Years is our inaugural production and will give us the opportunity to develop professional experience, especially important since our company is composed of current or recently graduated UCC students. 

 

What Is The Plan?

The venue for our production will be the Stack Theatre at the Cork School of Music, with four performance dates from July 24th to July 27th.  The artistic team, including Tom Doyle as Musical Director, has been assembled.  All we need now is the means to bring our vision to life.  That’s where you come in.

 

How Can You Help?

Scruffy Duck Productions has hundreds of shows worth of experience; however, we need your help to make this production a reality.  Our team has already raised 50% of our production costs through company investment.  We hope to raise the remaining  €1000 through your generosity and support.  Your investment will go towards venue rental, show rights, costumes, set, music, and generally making our production as wonderful as possible.  We hope you will consider supporting the arts in Cork and bring our production to life.

 

Thank you!

Mark, Sherelle, Catherine, Derwin, Mike, Jonathan, Hanan, and Ace

story:
Short Summary

The Trophy Awards is a comedy variety show with all the glitz and glamour of an awards show. It takes place in an alternate Hollywood reality where faux celebrity presenters give out meaningless awards for absurd categories. There will be red carpets, shiny dresses, a limo with a limo cam and drunk limo girl, comedians, prizes, a band to close out the night and much more! 

The event will be held at Radio Bushwick, October 9th 2014. 8pm.

What We Need & What You Get

THIS JUST IN!: We have ALMOST reached our goal! and would love it if all of YOU helped us achieve a stretch goal of 1000 dollars by the end of this campaign!

Reaching 1000 dollars will help us do the following in addition to what we've already promised!:

- PROMOTE the show successfully with printing flyers and posters/great designs/newspaper ads etc.

- BUY/RENT equipment for LIVE CAMERA FEED DURING the show. This addition would make it possible for us incorporate the live audience into the show! Just like a real awards show.

-RENT OUT the Radio Bushwick space for more time. To go through our show cue's and such!

-GET the extra tech hands we need for the DAY OF the show

HELP US GIVE YOU THE TIME OF YOUR LIFE!!!!!! AND MAYBE WE'LL BE ALE TO DO IT AGAIN!

We are trying to fund our project to pay for the space, costumes, book a band, get some props, rent a limo, and hopefully pay some performers.

Every little bit helps! 

    Risks & Challenges

    Unique challenges we are facing is getting all of the performers we want for this epic show! Organizing live-feed camera's for the audience and for the LIMO CAM. There are a great deal of technical mishaps that may happen and we are hoping to work them all out before the show starts. This will take time, money, support, and hard work from our team. Days of sleeplessness amongst our already hectic schedules, but it'll all be worthwhile with your help!

    We will also be attempting to reach out to great performers/musicians/actors to make this night as unbelievable as possible and writing till the day of the show to ensure you're getting an AMAZING lineup, and show altogether.

story:
May we present...

Natalie Canizares and Jade Daugherty are two friends and choreographers, who have been working together for over three years. We have seen our work grow and evolve becoming richer with every performance.

We are creating a piece for Triskelion Arts' CollabFest premiering in September.

Our selected piece combines movement, a curated menu, and sound to create a multisensory experience for audience members. Working in collaboration with Chef de cuisine Jaime Young, of Atera restaurant, and musician/composer Giovanni Colantonio, “And This Is What You'll Eat” will provide each audience member with a concise, single-bite menu to be enjoyed in tandem with the events on stage.

Help us feed you...

We are seeking to raise $2,000. Your donations will go towards:

o  the cost of product, labor, and packaging ($750)

o  performance props and costuming ($250)

o  covering the cost of rehearsal space ($250)

o  Indiegogo campaign fees (4%)

o  And most importantly:  paying the chefs, musicians, videographers, dancers and all those involved!  ($750)

In exchange for your support we are offering a variety benefits ranging from handwritten thank yous to personalized shout outs, rehearsal attendance, to your own ATIWYE experience brought to your home, including  bites, DVD, and a signed menu!


Rumblings

This will be our largest project to date. Without the assistance of others we would not be able to provide the quality of performance we strive for or envision for our audience. By donating, your contribution helps to ensure a successful event with the possibility of similar performances in the future.   


Substitutions...

The next time you go to Instragram, Tweet or post, your next meal use #ATIWYE to help show your support and spread appreciation!

Or share our campaign link on Facebook!

story:
Hello, 

My name is Kalin Mitov and I am the director of this event.

I would like to invite you to participate in a unique fundraising opportunity. In partnership with Boston Dance Alliance ( non-profit 501 c 3) and North American Same-Sex Partner Dance Association we are organizing the 2014 North American Same-Sex Ballroom Dance Championship. 

Тhe Championship is not only a ballroom dance competition, but also a public declaration of the need for equality at all levels of our lives. It supports the diversity and acceptance of the youth and adult LGBTQ community.

The 2014 North American Same Sex Ballroom Dance Championship is a one-day competitive event highlighting the grace and skills of the ballroom dance contestants, and also includes social ballroom dancing and professional dance performances. It  features  disciplines like Argentine Tango, Salsa, Hustle, Country Western Polka, Two Step and West Coast Swing as well as the traditional Waltz, Tango, Foxtrot, Cha-cha Rumba, Jive  and more…(full list can be found on the website)

This event will benefit the general population- 18 years old and above; man, woman and transgender. It is open to everybody supporting the LGBTQ community. One of the main goals is to introduce ballroom dancing as a safe environment and an alternative pro-social event for the young LGBTQ. Such an event teaches them about partnership, understanding, tolerance, and responsibility not only on the dance floor but in life.

We are expecting 200 competitors from Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver Canada, New York, Connecticut, Rode Island, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Maine, Philadelphia, Florida, Maryland, Washington DC, California and many other states. The venue can host 500 spectators and most of them will be from Greater Boston and New England,  along with friends and supporters of the competitive couples.

The organizing committee and the officials are responsible for the smooth conduct of this event. The Official are: Adjudicator’s panel with a Chairman and 8 well known NASSPDA approved judges; Scrutinizing team of 2; Master of Ceremony; Audio and video technician with a DJ; Registration desk personnel and On Deck Captain. These functions are performed either by volunteers or trained personnel who accept less then their market value to help make us a success. The North America Same Sex Partner Dance Association will supervise the event with Benjamin Soenckson as  Chairman, and Barbara Zoloth (President of NASSPDA). A survey of participants, officials and spectators will provide data for continuous improvement going forward.

Event Organizing Committee:

Kalin Mitov - Director

Tedi Eaton - Community Relations Coordinator

Nordis Glasoe - Accounting and Registration

Linda Toomey - On Deck Captain and Design

Don Jaffee, MD - Fundraising and Technical Support

The primary costs are associated with the venue including associated lighting and audio visual equipment. But there is also a need to make people aware of the event, to attract attendees and competitors, and the advertising necessary to reach those audiences is quite costly.

Our revenue has not allowed us to compensate our judges at  market rates and we have not been able to reward the winners financially, as other competitions of this type do.

We lack the large sponsorships that allow the traditional dance events to survive and continue year to year, so we are looking to you to help us  perpetuate this new tradition for the LGBT community.

If we are not able to cover our costs, as was the case last year - our first year of this competition - we will not be able to repeat this valuable  opportunity for the LGBT community in the years to come, thus eliminating a rare opportunity for the LGBT community to express themselves creatively.

We are, therefore,  trying to raise $10,000 to cover the baseline costs, and if donations allow, recognize the winners with a financial reward and expand the advertising budget to reach more audiences. 


About the Director, Kalin Mitov: Kalin is not new to the same-sex ballroom dance scene, having won both US and North American Same-Sex Champion titles for the last 3 years, as well as being the European Same-Sex Champion Bronze Medalist. In December 2012, he organized a fundraiser at Club Purgatory in Provincetown, MA, raising more than $2,000 to support the It Gets Better Project, an anti-bullying initiative. He and his previous dance partner created a YouTube video about how ballroom dancing helped them to take a stand against gay bullying. The first Boston same-sex dance competition, held last year,  was a major success due to Kalin's organization of the event,  the convenience of Boston’s outstanding location and, most importantly, the inclusion of everyone, ranging in age from young college students to adult LGBT dancers. 

Most recently he was part of the adjudicators panel of the DanceSport event during the Gay Games 9 in Cleveland, making this competition an unforgettable life time experience.

If we are not able to cover our costs, as was the case last year - our first year of this competition - we will not be able to repeat this valuable  opportunity for the LGBT community in the years to come, thus eliminating a rare opportunity for the LGBT community to express themselves creatively.
We are, therefore,  trying to raise $10,000 to cover the baseline costs, and if donations allow, recognize the winners with a financial reward and expand the advertising budget to reach more audiences. 

About the Director, Kalin Mitov: Kalin is not new to the same-sex ballroom dance scene, having won both US and North American Same-Sex Champion titles for the last 3 years, as well as being the European Same-Sex Champion Bronze Medalist. In December 2012, he organized a fundraiser at Club Purgatory in Provincetown, MA, raising more than $2,000 to support the It Gets Better Project, an anti-bullying initiative. He and his previous dance partner created a YouTube video about how ballroom dancing helped them to take a stand against gay bullying. The first Boston same-sex dance competition, held last year,  was a major success due to Kalin's organization of the event,  the convenience of Boston’s outstanding location and, most importantly, the inclusion of everyone, ranging in age from young college students to adult LGBT dancers. Most recently he was part of the adjudicators panel of the DanceSport event during the Gay Games 9 in Cleveland, making this competition an unforgettable life time experience.

story:
Our Story

 

Hoopdrum is our performing arts company specializing in hoop dance and percussion, based in Carrboro, NC.  If you live in the Triangle, you may have caught Julia’s whirling trance spinning to Scott's drum beats.  Through our work, we strive to inspire and nurture our expansive, collaborative community. 

 

Hoop dance, music and other flow & circus arts share a common challenge of acquiring adequate space for advancement and sharing of skills.  After five years of working independently and five years performing together, we have taken a leap of faith to open a spacious & innovative studio for practice, teaching, performance and community events.  With 25’ ceilings and 1,000 sq ft dance space, The Flowjo will beautifully meet the need of any movement artist.   This music & movement sanctuary, one of the first primarily-hoop studios in the world, will open in February of 2011. 


The Impact

 

The Flowjo will have an emphasis on hoop dance, but will also host regular aerial dance classes, as well as an array of circus, acrobatic, dance and flow arts workshops and camps for all ages.  For locals, this studio will offer a unique, fun, healthy, challenging curriculum unavailable on a regular basis for individuals 4 – adult. 


We believe The Flowjo will enhance the community by catering to different movement and learning styles. There will be opportunities for traditional instruction available, as well as abundant opportunity for self- directed, meditative and communal practice space.   Julia aspires to start a Youth Circus, co-create monthly performance events, community outreach programs and provide scholarships to summer camps and classes.  You can help make these visions become a reality.  

 

The good news:  The Flowjo will open.  However, there are a lot of projects left to complete.  Without help, some projects may be delayed, decreasing income streams that could be necessary to sustain the space.  Due to a  hefty overhead (downtown rent, utilities and insurance), additional business loans may prevent us from meeting our expenses, especially in the beginning.  We would prefer to support more progressive outreach programs with our income rather than meet high interest loans or credit payments.   We are eager to continue devoting our sweat equity, capital and wedding gifts (thank you!) to the beautification and success of The Flowjo.  If we can avoid getting deep in personal debt, we will be able to more effectively operate & maintain this space for our community near & far.

What We Need & What You Get

 

The Flowjo project would like to raise at least $8008 to re-create this warehouse shell into a respectable, inspiring sanctuary.  The flooring is purchased, but a subfloor is necessary to protect dancing bodies from the concrete slab base.  The landlord installed a sprinkler system, bathrooms, emergency exit and water fountains to bring the space up to code, but there’s much more work ahead.  We have invested $8000 and countless hours thus far for the commercial lease, rent, aerials rigs, PA equipment, permits, sign, flooring, tools, website and management software.  We are prepared to invest another $6000 and unlimited hours to the launch and success of this project.  Unfortunately, that won’t quite cover what is left to purchase and will leave us with little cushion for unforeseeable costs in the first months.


Here's some of what we need: 

 

Sprung floor system (and labor)

Lumber for a small stage to house and protect instruments

Gymnastics mats  (4)

Crash pad for aerial (1)

Acoustic insulation materials (wood, fiber, fabric, labor)

Paint (graffiti outside…while we appreciate the art, we would like to start fresh:)

Low VOC paint for indoors (want to make it as green as possible)

Theater curtain fabric to provide privacy, energy & sound insulation

Mirrors & installation

Materials to build two long benches w/ cubbies underneath & labor

Water filtration or dispensing system for public drinking (water fountains meet code… barely)

Insurance

LED lighting

Rugs for stretch/lounge space

Yoga mats

Blankets

Desk & office supplies

 

All this will cost well over $11,000 but we've tried to make our goal here as manageable as possible.

The more refined The Flowjo is upfront, the more likely that costs of running the facility will be met and that all of the teachers using the space could feel sustained as well.  FYI, any contributions made will be available immediately for us to use in up-fitting this space.


What you get!

Aside from endless gratitude and dancing prayers, The Perks include educational offerings for the complete beginner to those focusing on hoop dance professionally.  Please peruse the complete Perks packages to the right. 


Please keep in mind that if you do not live in the Triangle area, or hoop & drum classes just aren’t for you, we pledge to provide the instruction perks you would receive to someone who could not otherwise afford these opportunities.  The Flowjo is located in a low income area where many would benefit from financial assistance for these programs.  Passing on your Perk would provide a great scholarship package!  If you choose to pay your benefit forward, we would gladly document who receives the instruction and send out videos from the student exhibitions.


Custom hoops and stickers can be mailed around the globe.

Hoop Convergence information can be found at www.hoopconvergence.org. 

Class descriptions will be available this week on www.TheFlowjo.com.


Other Ways You Can Help

Come out to The Flowjo.  Treat your bodymind to a class or attend a jam.  Host your own event or birthday party in the space.  Tell a friend.  Come help out during a beautification day.  Do you have a skill to share…do tell!  Share the website www.theflowjo.com and project with friends.  “Like” hoopdrum on facebook.  Do you have some materials sitting around in your barn that would be helpful, sweet!  Re-used materials are preferable!  Send a prayer for collaborative success.  Follow your bliss!  


Thank you so much for your time & consideration.


Sincerely,

Julia, Scott and the entire Flowjo Family

story:
Nathan Champion will be training with the bolshoi ballet in Moscow, Russia. But only with your help!


His love and passion for what he does causes him to be a disciplined hard worker. His motivation to reach into his fullest potential keeps him looking for ways to be better, and grow in every way he can at his craft.


 With your help, you are providing Nathan with the ability to see his dreams through.
But What about your dreams?


Nathan hopes that people will see his motivation, drive, and dedication to his craft as inspiration - anyone can achieve their dreams, with a lot of hard work and support from friends and family, you can achieve your dreams to.


Nathan thanks you for your support and prayers.

story:
Short Summary

We, Anne Fizzard and Virginia Roncetti, are expat Canadians, and members of the Drama Desk-nominated, Innovative Theatre Award-winning WorkShop Theater Company, located in the heart of Manhattan. We have a feast of fine plays in store for New York City theatre audiences in January 2013, with a very special reading series.

UNKNOWN COUNTRY '13: Three Plays from Canada

You may think cold, snow and ice when you think of Canada, but did you know that, from west to east, Canada is a hotbed of brilliant and provocative playwrights? They are, many of them, completely unknown in the U.S., just as much about Canada is unknown to the average American.  This makes no sense for, after all, we speak the same language, and our cultures overlap considerably.

Therefore, the WorkShop Theater Company, in association with the Playwrights Guild of Canada, plan to knock your socks off from January 24 to 26, 2013 with readings of three Canadian plays of universal appeal, with the series UNKNOWN COUNTRY: Three Plays from Canada.

LEAVE OF ABSENCE by Lucia Frangione - January 24, 2013

Leave of Absence, by British Columbia playwright Lucia Frangione, tackles issues of sexual identity in teens, bullying, spirituality and today's Catholic church.  Smart, compassionate, funny and sad, this is a play for adults. These are characters who are living out loud. Leave of Absence has won the Amnesty International ACTivist theatre competition.

OIL AND WATER by Robert Chafe - January 25, 2013

By Newfoundlander  Robert Chafe, the lyrical Oil and Water tells the tale of Lanier Phillips, the only African-American survivor of the wreck of the U.S. Truxton, in 1942, off the shore of tiny St. Lawrence, Newfoundland. Lanier, a child of the Jim Crow South, had never heard a kind word from a white person. The St. Lawrence villagers who rescued and cared for him and the other survivors, had never seen a black person before.  His St. Lawrence experience turns Lanier from an angry young man into a leader in the U.S.civil rights struggle, while remaining forever connected to Newfoundland. Robert's play Afterimage won Canada's 2010 Governor-General's Award for Drama.

AFTER JERUSALEM by Aaron Bushkowsky - January 26, 2013

Aaron is another British Columbia playwright, and with After Jerusalem, he defies expectations of what a play set in Jerusalem might be about. A down-on-her-luck school teacher travels to Israel to find love, by making herself up to be a famous actress. At a security checkpoint, she meets an Israeli soldier who is a wannabe script-writer with many tall tales to tell. Quirky, extremely funny, and yet very serious, it is clear why After Jerusalem was nominated for the prestigious Carol Bolt Award for playwriting, and for a Jesse Richardson Award (Vancouver) for best new script.

These readings will be FREE to the public. The WorkShop has generously provided the venue. The Playwrights Guild of Canada has put many resources at our disposal.

However, we are turning to you to help us cover these and other expenses:

  • stipends for the directors and actors
  • purchases of scripts
  • rights
  • printing costs
  • stationery and supplies (ink cartridges, paper, envelopes)
  • photocopying
  • postage
  • a modest reception to follow the final reading on the 26th of January

If we fall short of our target, there will be smaller stipends for the actors and directors, who work so hard, for just a stipend, not a salary. It would also mean  fewer rehearsals, which is undesireable because we want very polished readings. There would be no closing night reception. We are optimistic, though, that with your help, we will reach our target, and make this event very special.

We should point out that the current federal government in Canada ended any funding for the promotion of Canadian artists abroad several years ago. Therefore it is left up to the little guys, a handful of ex-Pat Canadians, to sing the praises in NYC of Canadian playwrights.

Your Gift  Will Accomplish Much. We KNOW This.

We know this, because we have seen it work before. We also produced UNKNOWN COUNTRY I and II in 2005 and 2006, respectively. These series' led to packed houses and standing ovations. Most valuable for the playwrights, as a result of the New York readings, their scripts found their way to people who might produce the plays.

Along with the general public, it is important that theatre professionals see these readings, so we make sure we invite these VIPs: artistic directors and literary managers of New York and tri-state theatre companies, as well as producers and directors. When they cannot attend, they frequently ask for copies of the scripts. So, the scripts end up in the best hands. We and the playwrights have created important contacts doing this work. If one of these professionals likes a script, the hope is that it will end up being produced, or that more of the playwrights' scripts will be requested, and one of those scripts will be produced. It's a matter of painstakingly sowing seeds in an ongoing way.

Lucia, Robert and Aaron are so excited. Ask most Canadian playwrights, no matter how celebrated and award-winning in Canada, if you can do a New York reading of his or her play, and the answer is always a resounding "yes, please."

We know that theatre is important to you, and therefore that bringing to light  great plays which are undeservedly under the radar, that hearing new voices is important to you. You will be able to say you saw these first, before their productions Off-Broadway and in regional theatres around the U.S.

Everyone is a winner with this project.

NO DONATION IS TOO SMALL! It doesn't have to be any of the amounts listed with the perks either. Donations under $10 are gratefully received.

If you cannot make a donation, we hope you will make some noise about our project, and use IndieGoGo's sharing tools to do so. Thank you so much for reading about UNKNOWN COUNTRY, and for your consideration!

story:
Gilding the Lily (phase one: taking root)

I’m currently writing a play about Lillie Langtry, the Gilded Age actress and celebrity who was panned by critics for her portrayal of Rosalind in Shakespeare’s As You Like It.

This is a play about her life, loves and art—about the crafting of a fabulous and mysterious persona. Could Lillie be Lillie the Professional Beauty, the notorious mistress, the brand… and still be an actress who touched people’s hearts? 

 It’s a story about love, and the things that keep us from it; about art, and the things that keep us from achieving it; about how hard it is to reveal our true selves. So far, like the beauty herself, the story is funny and sad. With your help we’ll find out how it ends (OK, I know how it ends; you’ll just have to see)! The title is “Gilding the Lily,” and it should appeal to romantics, Shakespeare-lovers, aesthetes, and people who just like celebrity gossip. 

It’s a play I’m going to perform myself, so for Lillie to take root in me means working deeply both as a writer and an actor. The creation of Lillie was a life-long project for Mrs. Langtry. My creation of Lillie won’t take that long, with your help, but it will involve a transformation of self: from myself to the fictional Lillie I am gilding. The final creation will glitter, and it will not be small. Here are the next steps:

So here’s what I need to continue “Gilding the Lily”:

$1500 to finish researching and writing the script (I need a little more time without a part time job; being an stage actor is already a full time job that doesn’t pay very well.  I have interested producers, but I don’t have a commission for the writing of the script.)

$1200 for Lillie’s specific dialect work this spring with expert voice and dialect teacher Louis Colaianni (www.louiscolaianni.com)

$1440 for six months of voice work with Andrea Haring (Linklater voice work is not merely about the production of sound; it is an approach to acting which allows us to work from the deepest, truest part of ourselves.  This work is an essential part of my exploration of Lillie.  www.thelinklatercenter.com)

$800 for workshop sessions in NYC - director honorariums and space rental (several playwrights and directors are generously donating their time to the development of the script, but this is simply not possible for some of the artists that I need to work with)

$250 for travel and housing for workshop(s) at Shakespeare & Company (Lillie’s thoughts are full of Shakespeare’s stories and language, so I will return to the home of my own Shakespearean training to work with artists who have generously offered to critique the script.)

$622 Indiegogo fees and credit card processing fees

$5,812  Total Goal

This amount covers most but not all of the costs for this phase of the project.  For example it does not include any writing, resources or research used until now or any local transportation costs.  Any amount raised over this goal will be gratefully reserved for the next phase of this project.

About the Playwright / Performer

This is Susannah's first play she has written for production. As a dramaturg, literary assistant, and actor for plays in development she has worked at Trinity Rep, Alias Stage, New Dramatists, LaMama ETC, HERE, New Georges, and the NY International Fringe Festival. She directed and helped develop the first production of Hayley Finn’s one-woman show Hysteria: Silence in Stills at the NY Fringe Festival.   

As a performer she has acted for the past ten years in the one-woman Civil War drama, The Color of War, by Mary Guzzy, a co-production of Shakespeare & Company and Ventfort Hall Association. Other classical and contemporary acting credits include: The Winter's Tale, Romeo and Juliet, Julius Caesar, Macbeth, A Midsummer Night's Dream, Coriolanus, and seven plays in Greece and New York as a guest artist with the international theater company One Year Lease, including the title roles in three versions of the Phaedra myth.  She has also performed in a number of other brand new plays in New York. Contemporary roles in Boston include: Solange in Genet’s The Maids, two turns as the primary mind in Sarah Kane’s 4.48 Psychosis, and Dot in 7 B***jobs by Mac Wellman. In Providence, in the New Plays 2000 Festival, she originated the role of Eurydice in Sarah Ruhl's early play of the same name. Her first professional stage role was in a one-person play about teen dating violence which toured New England and the New York tri-state area. Bleeding to death every day before 1000 shocked teenagers, and then making them talk about it, was a trial by fire in solo performance.

As a teacher (this will become relevant in the Perks section—yes, there are perks!) Susannah has worked with actors of all ages in New York, Boston, Providence, the Berkshires, and Dublin. She has studied, acted, trained, taught, and directed at Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, MA, throughout her professional career. She now teaches and coaches privately in New York City. Susannah graduated from Brown University with degrees in Ancient & Medieval Culture and Theater and spent a year studying theatre, education, and Irish studies at the Samuel Beckett Centre for Drama & Theatre Studies at Trinity College in Dublin. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute please post on facebook or tweet with your support, or send an email to people whom you think might be interested with your personal endorsement.

Or if you happen to know someone who would contribute an antique Victorian chaise lounge to the final production, let me know!

In these times not everybody has the luxury to contribute to artistic productions. I believe it is as important as anything we do.  

However, if you need to make tough decisions with your money I suggest the following: I contribute a small amount monthly to the education of girls in Afghanistan through Save the Children (www.savethechildren.org); my current favorite humanitarian project is called Zara Aina -- Share Life which sends New York theater artists to create stories with children in Madagascar (www.zaraaina.org); and of course there is the Red Cross.

Fine Print

All perks are fully transferrable.  For out of towners who cannot take advantage of all of these perks special arrangements can be made.
