So far, like the beauty herself, the story is funny and sad. With your help we’ll find out how it ends (OK, I know how it ends; you’ll just have to see)! The title is “Gilding the Lily,” and it should appeal to romantics, Shakespeare-lovers, aesthetes, and people who just like celebrity gossip. 
It’s a play I’m going to perform myself, so for Lillie to take root in me means working deeply both as a writer and an actor. The creation of Lillie was a life-long project for Mrs. Langtry. My creation of Lillie won’t take that long, with your help, but it will involve a transformation of self: from myself to the fictional Lillie I am gilding. The final creation will glitter, and it will not be small. Here are the next steps:


So here’s what I need to continue “Gilding the Lily”:
$1500 to finish researching and writing the script (I need a little more time without a part time job; being an stage actor is already a full time job that doesn’t pay very well.  I have interested producers, but I don’t have a commission for the writing of the script.)
$1200 for Lillie’s specific dialect work this spring with expert voice and dialect teacher Louis Colaianni (www.louiscolaianni.com)
$1440 for six months of voice work with Andrea Haring (Linklater voice work is not merely about the production of sound; it is an approach to acting which allows us to work from the deepest, truest part of ourselves.  This work is an essential part of my exploration of Lillie.  www.thelinklatercenter.com)
$800 for workshop sessions in NYC - director honorariums and space rental (several playwrights and directors are generously donating their time to the development of the script, but this is simply not possible for some of the artists that I need to work with)
$250 for travel and housing for workshop(s) at Shakespeare & Company (Lillie’s thoughts are full of Shakespeare’s stories and language, so I will return to the home of my own Shakespearean training to work with artists who have generously offered to critique the script.)
$622 Indiegogo fees and credit card processing fees
$5,812  Total Goal
This amount covers most but not all of the costs for this phase of the project.  For example it does not include any writing, resources or research used until now or any local transportation costs.  Any amount raised over this goal will be gratefully reserved for the next phase of this project.
About the Playwright / Performer


This is Susannah's first play she has written for production. As a dramaturg, literary assistant, and actor for plays in development she has worked at Trinity Rep, Alias Stage, New Dramatists, LaMama ETC, HERE, New Georges, and the NY International Fringe Festival. She directed and helped develop the first production of Hayley Finn’s one-woman show Hysteria: Silence in Stills at the NY Fringe Festival.   
As a performer she has acted for the past ten years in the one-woman Civil War drama, The Color of War, by Mary Guzzy, a co-production of Shakespeare & Company and Ventfort Hall Association. Other classical and contemporary acting credits include: The Winter's Tale, Romeo and Juliet, Julius Caesar, Macbeth, A Midsummer Night's Dream, Coriolanus, and seven plays in Greece and New York as a guest artist with the international theater company One Year Lease, including the title roles in three versions of the Phaedra myth.  She has also performed in a number of other brand new plays in New York. Contemporary roles in Boston include: Solange in Genet’s The Maids, two turns as the primary mind in Sarah Kane’s 4.48 Psychosis, and Dot in 7 B***jobs by Mac Wellman. In Providence, in the New Plays 2000 Festival, she originated the role of Eurydice in Sarah Ruhl's early play of the same name. Her first professional stage role was in a one-person play about teen dating violence which toured New England and the New York tri-state area. Bleeding to death every day before 1000 shocked teenagers, and then making them talk about it, was a trial by fire in solo performance.
As a teacher (this will become relevant in the Perks section—yes, there are perks!) Susannah has worked with actors of all ages in New York, Boston, Providence, the Berkshires, and Dublin. She has studied, acted, trained, taught, and directed at Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, MA, throughout her professional career. She now teaches and coaches privately in New York City. Susannah graduated from Brown University with degrees in Ancient & Medieval Culture and Theater and spent a year studying theatre, education, and Irish studies at the Samuel Beckett Centre for Drama & Theatre Studies at Trinity College in Dublin. 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute please post on facebook or tweet with your support, or send an email to people whom you think might be interested with your personal endorsement.
Or if you happen to know someone who would contribute an antique Victorian chaise lounge to the final production, let me know!
In these times not everybody has the luxury to contribute to artistic productions. I believe it is as important as anything we do.  
However, if you need to make tough decisions with your money I suggest the following: I contribute a small amount monthly to the education of girls in Afghanistan through Save the Children (www.savethechildren.org); my current favorite humanitarian project is called Zara Aina -- Share Life which sends New York theater artists to create stories with children in Madagascar (www.zaraaina.org); and of course there is the Red Cross.
Fine Print
All perks are fully transferrable.  For out of towners who cannot take advantage of all of these perks special arrangements can be made.

story:
Prison Bridges Summary

As an actor, director and Registered Drama Therapist, I have taught drama programs,  directed Shakespeare plays for Marin Shakespeare Company, and facilitated original theatre programs inside San Quentin State Prison and other facilitites for the past 10 years.  During my time bringing drama to incarcerated men, I have witnessed again and again how theatre serves as a powerful tool for both individual and social transformation.  At an individual level, theatre helps incarcerated men build self-expression, self-esteem, and aides them in cultivating their inner "witness" - their ability to stand back and reflect on themselves, their actions and their life choices.  At a social level, theatre helps raise awareness of pertinent themes and issues facing not only those who are incarcerated, but also for youth at risk and others impacted by a society in which poverty, greed, abuse and neglect continue to perpetuate the cycle of violence.  

By contributing to this campaign, you will be supporting a project that helps incarcerated men make a difference in the world rather than be a "burden" to society. Thanks to a $2000 CA$H Grant from Theatre Bay Area, men have already begun writing stories of transformation, in which they will share a moment in their lives that fundamentally changed how they think, perceive and act in the world.  The men will perform their stories for other prisoners at San Quentin on August 24th, 2012, thus helping to raise consciousness in the prison population. With this "Prison Bridges" project, we will create a "bridge" from within the prison to the larger community in two ways: 1) Men's stories will be performed by actors outside the prison in the "Prison Bridges Tour."  During this tour, each of the pieces the men write will be shared at six different youth and community centers, followed by a discussion about peace-building and violence prevention that will be facilitated by myself and by one or more ex-prisoners who have transformed their lives. 2) A documentary is currently being made which explores the growth and challenges the men face as they write and perform their individual pieces.  This documentary, "Prison Bridges: The Film" will be used as a social and educational tool made available to schools, community centers, rehabilitation centers as a way to provoke discussion and reflection about how to cultivate positive choices and healthy ways of being in the world.  

Budget

$7000 TOTAL

Breakdown:

$1600 for four months of drama classes and coaching to help the men expand and revise their theatre pieces

$1800 payable to three actors for touring show to six venues

$600 to assistant facilitator for leading discussion after each of the six performances

$2000 for video editing work towards creation of a 30 minute documentary film

$1000 for supplies, phone calls, tech help for each show, and production aspects of both the show tour and the film

 

The Impact

Thank you so much for supporting us with this campaign!  You are making a tremendous difference in the following ways.

- Incarcerated men will have the opportunity to create positive change in their own lives, and in doing so, encourage others to do the same.

- Youth at risk will have the opportunity to hear from individuals who have been in their shoes, and to learn from their mistakes.

- Incarcerated men participating in the project will not only grow individually, but will also be learning skills of teamwork, unity and mutual support on a continual basis.  

 

Please spread the word and let others know about our campaign!  We thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

 

Suraya and the Prison Bridges Crew

story:
How to Deal is a new, full-length play by Joel Sinensky, an award-winning young playwright based in Los Angeles. We are mounting the world premiere production this November at the El Centro Theatre, an intimate space in the heart of Hollywood. 


THE PLAY

How to Deal is, ostensibly, the story of an unstable young writer who can’t get a decent job and resorts to a dangerous criminal life in order to finance the completion of his novel. It’s also the story of the novel itself, a twisted reworking of his own life that may very well alienate everyone he knows. More than anything, it’s a story about a group of characters trying to deal with the intense pressures and anxieties that come with post-collegiate existence, about what happens when the reality of your life and the fantasy of your life have bled into each other so much it becomes impossible to distinguish between the two.  

 

It’s a comedy, by the way. 


THE PRODUCTION

This production is being financed entirely through independent means, and everyone involved (the writer, director, the production team, and the cast) are in their twenties. Our generation, thus far, has been almost entirely defined by those standing on the outside. With this production, we plan to explore what it actually feels like to be young right now. We hope to create something raw and genuine, and to give this exciting new work the production that it deserves. Truly, any contribution will help. 


Show goes up the weekend of November 10-13 at The El Centro Theatre


804 N. El Centro Ave

Hollywood, CA 90038


Showtimes: 

Thursday, November 10 -- 8PM

Friday, November 11 -- 8PM

Saturday, November 12 -- 8PM

Sunday, November 13 -- 6PM



CAST AND CREW

Director - James Rodman

Producer - Isabelle Esposito

Fundraising / PR - Annie Middleton


Starring -

Tim McGoven

Mitch Lerner

Kate Yoder

Ross Alden

Matt Wool

Erika Rankin


To buy tickets (and for more information) visit www.howtodealplay.com

story:
Our Story

Last summer, Alligator Mouth Improv met a performing artist from the Netherlands who runs his own improv group overseas. He invited us to perform with them! We want to be able to make the most of this trip, and it's certainly not free...


The Impact

Every time we perform, we invite our audience to "Come with no expectations, and leave with a greater sense of what's possible." Our work is no ordinary stage entertainment - it's an improvised journey that goes deep into real themes and ideas provided by audience members.


What We Need

I set a $2,000 goal that will cover many of our basic needs in Amsterdam - food, lodging, and some travel costs. We've been lucky enough to have a portion of the airfare donated, but we're hoping to break even on this trip, and that will require some extra support. Our hosts have been generous enough to offer some lodging, but we won't be with them the whole trip. Your donations will help us make the most of this wonderful opportunity.


Other Ways You Can Help

I know this website has some share tools, and it would be really great if you'd help spread the word about Alligator Mouth Improv, and this trip in particular. Truly, any word-of-mouth support is helpful!

story:
UPDATE: We now have 9, that's right NINE full scholarship students! We are going to be adding a full class of new scholarships in the next few weeks!


Our Story

Sky-Marie has had a dream to use dance to better people's lives for well over a decade. At the age of 18 she felt that God gave her a vision that dance could impact both the dancer and the audience at a very deep, heart level, that it could even transcend barriers like language and cultural differences and social status, that it could be used as a tool to bring healing and unity where brokenness and discord exist. So, she began experimenting with the art as a medium for social and personal growth. She went to the University of Oklahoma and double majored in dance and social anthropology, worked really hard, graduated with honors, made a lot of exciting progress, and... then life happened. With the years came children and responsibilities and "real life" and eventually her dream seemed entirely too distant, too difficult, too impossible to pursue. So, as many of us do with our dreams, she basically shelved it...

Suddenly one day, the impossible became possible! At the end of December this year we were making our family plans and goals for the upcoming year when a new organization, Early Spring Arts Conservatory, just "happened." This was not planned, it really just came together in a matter of days. Sky-Marie was simply looking for space to start dancing again on her own, or maybe with a few friends, small steps towards reclaiming her original vision. Those small steps turned into a 3,500 square foot dance space with 3 dance studios and 2 classrooms! The space is large enough to house the dance company she's dreamed of directing, as well as offer dance classes for students in the community, and serve as a space to create visual art. Also within a matter of days, all the right people to help run such a wonderful place also came into line. Just like that.

Our goal is to create a conservatory that will provide truly excellent classes that identify and nurture a student's unique gifting and talent. It's Sky-Marie's desire that no student be turned away if they have the passion to learn, regardless of income, ability, or physical limitation. We want to create really quality classes for students of all ages, special inter-disciplinary classes geared towards the homeschool community, classes for adults, classes for individuals with special needs, and advanced classes that will feed into a professional dance company. We want to offer scholarships for students who can't afford tuition. We want to impact the community with thought-provoking, cutting-edge performances. This will not be a "competition" studio, or a glamor studio that fosters a competitive mentality but a place where students are trained to serve and bless others through their talents. In addition to dance we are offering classes in voice, acting, musical theatre and the visual arts.

We will be opening the conservatory on February first. We are putting the puzzle pieces together to make the Conservatory a 501(c)3 non-profit foundation. This will enable us to focus on the student rather than the "bottom line". We hope to offer many scholarships and work/study programs. We also will use the conservatory to reach out to the community at large through performances in the many area social gatherings. We will also be home to an independent Irish Dance company.


The Impact

Donations to our campaign will free us up to focus on the art and the artist. We currently have funding to cover expenses such as rent and utilities in the space. Our current resources will be able to provide immediate full scholarships for 3 very deserving, serious dance students who have approached us for help in funding. We want to offer more scholarships to more students. In particular, there are many very deserving homeschooled students who would like to enroll, and some students with special needs. We need funding to pay the great teachers who want to teach these students. The students are ready. The teachers are ready. The space is *almost* ready. But we need your help!


What We Need & What You Get

Currently we need at least $4000. This money will go towards the purchase of a new PA system for each studio (while they have beautiful floors and mirrors we currently have no sound in the studios). Paint to paint the lobby, the halls, the classrooms and the studios.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please post this link to your facebook page and email it to your friends. Help us spread the word!

Other Ways You Can Help
Please post this link to your facebook page and email it to your friends. Help us spread the word!

story:
REFERENCES TO SALVADOR DALI MAKE ME HOT is a story about love, lust and longing. 

a lonely housewife finds solace with a music-playing moon. lust rises between a house-bred cat and a wild coyote. her soldier returns with a dark secret & the desperate struggle to rekindle their passion explodes.. but will love be enough?

WHO:coryphaeus theatre company began three years ago -- and we haven't stopped! we've presented both original and classic works to the new york theatre community to acclaim. currently our revolutionary piece 'the threadbare sex' is in it's third successful run. 
WHAT:coryphaeus is thrilled to announce their fall production of REFERENCES TO SALVADOR DALI MAKE ME HOT by the incomparable jose rivera.
WHEN/WHERE: REFERENCES will be produced at the gene frankel theatre, in Manhattan. it will run for 8 performances from SEPT 6 - 11th, 2011. tickets are available at smarttix.com and at the door.


HOW: REFERENCES is a phenomenal play. it is rarely done but widely loved. so to do it justice, we need your help. any contribution, big or small is greatly, greatly felt. producing theater is an expensive business and we are blessed beyond words to have the generous patrons we do.  now let's be real, we all like a little incentive and this is no exception! see below what comes sealed-with-a-surrealist-kiss, when you contribute! 
and as always, posting to your facebook, emailing our links out, passing the word along and coming to see the show are just as important and much appreciated means of support! <3

story:
Short Summary

Playwright Pia Wilson has a long history with Horse Trade and The Fire This Time Festival. She wrote, directed, and produced her first show in Horse Trade Theater Group's Red Room Theater in 2007. Pia was a first year playwright of The Fire This Time Festival, and in 2011 her play, THE FLOWER THIEF, recieved a full length reading as part of TFTT. Horse Trade and The Fire This Time Festival proudly present the first full length production of TFTT, Pia Wilson's THE FLOWER THIEF. HT Artistic Director Heidi Grumelot is directing the play during its 9-performance run August 2nd-19th. The space: The Red Room.  Full circle. 

The Fire This Time is excited to mount its first full length production. In order to do this we need to raise funds to pay our collaborating artists for all of their hard work - this is why we need your help! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Just a little bit from our friends can help us push forward an important voice from a new generation of great playwrights. Help us fully realize the mission of The Fire This Time Festival:

The African American experience is not represented solely by one voice or one style. Horse Trade Theater Group and The Fire This Time Festival provide a platform for talented early-career playwrights of African and African American descent to explore challenging new directions for 21st century theater. 

By helping us bring THE FLOWER THIEF  to the stage, you will be personally participating in the 'move beyond common ideas of what's possible in "black theater."' Our total production budget is $9,000, HT and friends of HT have contributed $5,400. We still need to raise $3,600. These funds will go towards paying for the work of designers, actors, and production staff. 

If you help us we want to shower you with flowers, thank yous, tickets, drinks with the Cast at KGB Bar Opening Night, and even a pie baked by the playwright herself (she makes amazing pies)! 

 

The Impact

We believe all artists should be paid for their work. At HT our core value is that our artist payout each month is more than our administrative salaries. We have been operating this way for 14 Seasons. The Fire This Time Festival was created with the same value in mind and we view this full length production as an opportunity to pay more artists. 

Approximately 70% of our production budget is people:  the actors, the playwright, the director, the lighting designer, the set designer, the costume designer, the sound designer, the stage manager, the graphic designer, the board operator... Help us support them by supporting their work with your contribution. Whatever you can give will go directly toward paying the artists. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to help us with a donation, we understand. We can use your help with getting the word out about the show and our fundraising efforts. 

Facebookit, tweetit, talkaboutit. Share this link with your friends!

 

And that’s all there is to it.

Horse Trade and The Fire This Time Festival proudly present the first full length production of TFTT, Pia Wilson's THE FLOWER THIEF. HT Artistic Director Heidi Grumelot is directing the play during its 9-performance run August 2nd-19th. The space: The Red Room.  Full circle. 
The Fire This Time is excited to mount its first full length production. In order to do this we need to raise funds to pay our collaborating artists for all of their hard work - this is why we need your help! 
 


What We Need & What You Get
Just a little bit from our friends can help us push forward an important voice from a new generation of great playwrights. Help us fully realize the mission of The Fire This Time Festival:


The African American experience is not represented solely by one voice or one style. Horse Trade Theater Group and The Fire This Time Festival provide a platform for talented early-career playwrights of African and African American descent to explore challenging new directions for 21st century theater. 


By helping us bring THE FLOWER THIEF  to the stage, you will be personally participating in the 'move beyond common ideas of what's possible in "black theater."' Our total production budget is $9,000, HT and friends of HT have contributed $5,400. We still need to raise $3,600. These funds will go towards paying for the work of designers, actors, and production staff. 
If you help us we want to shower you with flowers, thank yous, tickets, drinks with the Cast at KGB Bar Opening Night, and even a pie baked by the playwright herself (she makes amazing pies)! 
 


The Impact
We believe all artists should be paid for their work. At HT our core value is that our artist payout each month is more than our administrative salaries. We have been operating this way for 14 Seasons. The Fire This Time Festival was created with the same value in mind and we view this full length production as an opportunity to pay more artists. 
Approximately 70% of our production budget is people:  the actors, the playwright, the director, the lighting designer, the set designer, the costume designer, the sound designer, the stage manager, the graphic designer, the board operator... Help us support them by supporting their work with your contribution. Whatever you can give will go directly toward paying the artists. 
 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you are not able to help us with a donation, we understand. We can use your help with getting the word out about the show and our fundraising efforts. 
Facebookit, tweetit, talkaboutit. Share this link with your friends!
 

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
This is our project:

Irse hacia el norte (Going Northbound) is a theater investigation project about immigration. Three legal travelers from different countries of origin will share a route with immigrants without documentation. There will be a profound exchange with the people and the real migrant experience.

We will start our journey from the west of Guatemala, traveling through Mexico and the US. Stopping at migrant shelters, spending time with migrants and giving theater workshops. As the play “Irse” is being performed it will also be transforming itself with every travel experience. At the end of our journey, we will share this artistic investigation based on the real experience with the audience of New Orleans. After this the play will be toured through Guatemala and in the future we plan to go to the Netherlands.

Questions

I am here. But I am not allowed to be here. I am nothing. I have no social security number. I am unwanted. I have no identity. Yet I walk. Yet I work. Who am I?

In San Diego it might be easy to ignore illegal immigration, yet every San Diego resident depends on immigrant workers. New Orleans was reconstructed by mostly Latin-American immigrant workers after Katrina. Inhabitants of Acuyacán, Oaxaca, Mexico might be bothered by the neverending flow of immigrants, yet it is their own compatriots and Central Americans that suffer the consequences of the economical malaise that effects them all, crossing through their town.

Tens of thousands of Mexican and Central American migrants cross illegally to the United States annually. Not being able to feed their children or pay for rent, living in communities that are deteriorated by gang violence drives them to risk losing limbs, being robbed and raped and even drowning or dying in the desert. Families are torn apart.

Is it worth the risk everything to get to the other side? Is it worth it to let your children be smuggled over the border in the trunk of a car?

 Whose fault is it? Is it the drug cartels, the failing Mexican and Central American governments, or the U.S. government or is it the people that shouldn’t even go anywhere illegally?

Is it absurd that a little book decides where we can and cannot be, and that Americans can touch American soil without a visa, whilst Guatemalans can’t? Or is it good and necessary for states to protect their borders?

What is a state anyway? And what is a nationality? Is it purely bureaucratic, or also related to deep emotions and a feeling of belonging? What happens when a person moves away from a place where he belongs to a place where nobody will give him that feeling of belonging?

The theater groups Artzénico, Armadillo and Goat in the Road Productions try to find answers to those questions and presenting them in their play “Irse” along the way to the final destination; the New Orleans Fringe Festival.

Purpose

We are determined to share the real life migrant experience with non-migrants in communities that are affected by the migration issue. And thus bring locals and migrants, that are physically in the same spot, together through theater.

We also want to connect with the migrants along their way. Offering hope and perspective through theater and passing on their story to worldwide audiences to raise awareness and contribute to the migration dialogue. We share the belief that theater brings content and humanity together; we try to reunite the global issue with human emotion.

The play “Irse” will share the findings of the investigation through live internet communication, that contrasts with real walls that protect borders. Through personal stories and experiences from artists and migrants. And through scenes that make the crossing of a desert or river, the anxiety of being caught and the pain of not being able to see your family because you don’t have the right papers tangible. 

Participating groups

The initiative is started by Artzénico, from Quetzaltenango (www.artzenico.org). In cooperation with Armadillo (www.armadillo1.com) from Quetzaltenango, Guatemala and Goat in the Road Productions (www.goatintheroadproductions.org) from New Orleans, Louisiana.

Sustainability
The participants of “Irse hacia el Norte” propose to make their journey a practice of new models of artistic sustainability. The most powerful tool of this new tactic is bartering; exchange of a performance for food, bus passes for publicity, etc. As well as other types of fundraising methods.  

Your donation

This is where you come in! The 1750 dollars we would like to raise through Indiegogo will go to travel expenses along the way. They will cover flight tickets for the participants in the U.S. and back to Guatemala and for local travel expenses along the way.

What else can you do

Any help you can give in kind is welcome! A place to stay, a meal, a ride, a beer, a place to rehearse. There are a lot of things you could do, please contact us at: info@artzenico.org

More information

For more information please visit us at our blogs and watch our video: 

English: 

http://vimeo.com/42481913

www.goingnorthbound.wordpress.com

 

Español: 

http://vimeo.com/42420513

www.irsehaciaelnorte.wordpress.com

story:
The Night Owl Players

The Night Owl Players was founded in 2013 by Shanna Sartori and Katelin Dickson with the goal to produce theatre that encourages creative growth as actors, producers, and individuals. We have successfully produced two shows in New York, The Importance of Being Earnest at the Producer's Club and Sunday on the Rocks at Access Theater. The dark comedy, U.S. Drag by Gina Gionfriddo, is our newest production and opens on January 14th in the Black Box at Access Theater.  We are thrilled to be hard at work on our next show and thankful to have two prior successes under our belts, which (we are happy to announce) has allowed us to book a two-week run in a really beautiful venue! 


U.S. Drag follows two young women trying to scheme their way through Manhattan while trying to figure out what it means to matter in a modern day society. Along the way they volunteer for a community advocacy group whose objective is to catch an elusive serial attacker named 'Ed' who is roaming the streets of the city... 

$2,500

We would not have been able to produce our past shows if it hadn't been for the overwhelming, generous support we have received from all of you. The goal of $2,500 will go towards the cost of the rental and rehearsal space, lighting design, costumes, set, and props. Your generous donations will not go unnoticed and a few perks include tickets to the show and an invitation to an exclusive opening night reception with the cast and crew. 

Thank you for your continued support over the past few years. You have helped make our dream of producing theatre in New York a reality and we are thrilled to bring U.S. Drag to the stage!

story:
The Listeners is a new play from writer Matthew Freeman and director Michael Gardner (Brandywine Distillery Fire) premiering at The Brick's first Resident Artist Season this February.  We're very excited about it and hope you can help us bring it to life!  If you can help us reach our goal by New Year's, we will be able to give you the best possible version of a play which is unlike anything you have experienced before.  


Your generous tax-deductible contribution will give us the opportunity to afford the full production we hope to present you with in a few months.  For those of you in the theater world, you know how expensive it currently is to mount professional work in New York. For those of you who are theater fans, we have great expenses for even the most modest production.  


Even the smallest amount is greatly appreciated!


Plus, if you donate, you'll receive special supplemental materials!  Audio recordings of monologues that take place before the play begins.  This is exclusive content which will introduce you to the mysterious world of the play.  


Thank you so much for considering!


Matt & Michael



THE LISTENERS


FEBRUARY 4 - 14 at The Brick


Part of The Brick's first Resident Artist Season.


When two drifters arrive at Sistine’s door, she offers them mismatched coffee cups and something called breakfast. Outside the dogs are barking. Probably dogs. The drifters are now lodgers. They meet the family. There’s a house and people live in it. Vegetables in the garden. Board games. History. Stories. Rituals. Songs. No, not songs. We don’t sing songs here. We’ve lived this way for centuries. Or decades. Anyway, a long time. We know how to survive.


Nothing is coming to get us. Nothing makes a sound. Because if there were a sound, we would have heard it.


Starring Robert Honeywell, Jay Leibowitz*, Sarah K. Lippmann*, Moira Stone* and Stephanie Willing.

*appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association

story:
This Project In a Nutshell I will travel to Puerto Rico over spring break to be a guest director at Nuestra Escuela, an award-winning school in the democratic education movement. This is the beginning of the next chapter for Jester Educational Theater as I work to make a difference in the lives of kids around the world. Ultimately, I will take performers and colleagues to share these cultural-theatrical adventures. To get this Grand Scheme started, Kevin goes to Puerto Rico!

The Back Story My passion is doing drama with kids. As a veteran public school teacher, I found I was getting enough kid contact, but not enough musical theater, so a few years ago I started Jester Educational Theater and have since been happily directing outstanding young performers and putting them on stages throughout the Pacific Northwest. This work continues on and I love it! Many of you supported a Kickstarter campaign in the early stages of Jester Educational Theater, and your support was invaluable--

Where I Stand Now The time has come to begin realizing the broader vision of Jester Educational Theater and take this enterprise on the road, literally, and pursue my dream of doing drama throughout the world. I love creating rich and exciting experiences for others--and for myself as well, as I get to be there in the middle of it watching it unfold. It's challenging and hard and beautiful and mysterious--who knows how the experience will affect any of us in the long run? This is the essence of a deep and rich education, and this is what I'm drawn to bring about.

And in March it begins in earnest when I journey to Puerto Rico.

A Few Logistics This project will need $1,600 to complete. The expenses are straightforward: airfare, lodging, food and ground transportation--that's about it. The sum is a bit more than I'll likely need to allow for the unexpected and emergencies. I will stay at the guest house at Nuestra Escuela, considerably reducing the cost of lodging and food.

Risks I'm supposed to talk about risks for the sake of transparency, which I'm all for, but I'm not sure where the risk is...Nuestra Escuela is expecting me, the airlines are still operating, and I have a passion-filled dream to live. I'm sure there's risk somewhere--I'll add it when I think of it.

What You Will Get Out Of It I have some fun perks to offer at different levels of giving, including an inscribed copy of my cartoon book,  "Making a Difference in the World Today," and a copy of my Limited-Edition, Graphic Novel Travelogue of the experience in Puerto Rico (obviously not yet created). I love offering perks, but mostly what I hope you get out of supporting this project is a satisfaction that your faith and confidence in my work will benefit young people around the world through exciting, cross-cultural drama experiences for years to come.

This is my dream.

It starts in Puerto Rico.

Join me.

Support this project! Here's how--

Check out the perks and make a tax-deductible donation right now.

Let your friends and family know--send the link on!

And don't forget to watch the short video I made specially for this campaign--I think you'll enjoy it!

Thank you!

story:
SYNOPSIS

Un homme apprend qu'il va mourir. Refusant d'attendre la fin à l'horizontale, il décide de partir, debout, à sa rencontre. Il laisse tout derrière et s’exile dans une terre qui ressemble au début ou à la fin des temps, où les glaciers chevauchent les volcans. Dans un camping, une femme propose de lui prêter main-forte dans son projet. À bord du même sac de couchage, ils prennent la route vers l'ultime destination.

MISSION

Je suis hypocondriaque. Depuis la tendre enfance, j'ai dû me diagnostiquer des dizaines de cancers. Je me souviens que très jeune, lorsque j'ai appris que l'on pouvait tomber malade, et même mourir, je me suis senti profondément trahi. Pourquoi goûter au plaisir d'être en vie, si l'on doit éventuellement le perdre ? Pourquoi jouir d'un corps en santé s'il doit éventuellement vieillir, souffrir et tomber malade ? J'étais révolté. En vieillissant, j'ai non seulement réalisé que l'hypocondrie est un phénomène répandu, mais qu'en plus, celui-ci semble s'exacerber depuis quelques années avec le développement de la technologie. À mes yeux, il est indéniable que la surabondance d'information via internet et les médias sociaux favorise le développement de l'anxiété et de la paranoïa dans la population en général.

C'est ce constat qui m'a poussé à vouloir parler de l'hypocondrie. Non seulement parce que j'en souffre, mais parce que le phénomène semble prendre de plus en plus d'ampleur. À l'exception notable du Malade imaginaire de Molière, il me semble que c'est un sujet qui reste assez peu exploré théâtralement, malgré qu'il semble toucher de plus en plus de gens. Pas seulement l'hypocondrie, mais l'anxiété en général, ou de façon plus globale, la peur. Cette peur qui envahit de plus en plus nos vies paradoxalement hyper connectées, mais aussi séparées de la réalité. Peur de l'autre. Peur de perdre. Peur de manquer quelque chose, de manquer de quelque chose. Peur de rester ou de partir. Peur de mourir. Peur de vivre. Peur de s'engager dans la vie.

« LES HÉBERTISTES » - MANDAT ET HISTORIQUE

Composé de Mary-Lee Picknell et de moi-même, Nicola-Frank Vachon, Les hébertistes est un collectif d'artistes de la région de Québec réuni pour la première fois. Cette collaboration est issue de l'intention de poursuivre ma réflexion et mon travail d'écriture théâtrale entamés au sein du Soucide collectif, une compagnie de création collective de Québec fondée en 2005 avec Catherine Dorion et Virginie Leclerc. Les deux spectacles créés par cette compagnie (Quand le sage pointe la lune, le fou regarde le doigt et Kukipik Doikipu), écrits collectivement via l'improvisation, avaient rencontré un accueil très chaleureux. Il s'agissait dans les deux cas d'un théâtre clownesque lapidaire et éclaté s'attaquant aux travers d'une société de plus en plus déconnectée et déshumanisée. Fort de cette expérience, je veux cette fois-ci poursuivre ma réflexion et mon exploration des thèmes qui me tiennent à cœur, mais d'une toute autre manière. C'est encore une fois un duo féminin/masculin. Les dialogues sont directs et francs. Le réalisme et la poésie s'entremêlent allègrement. L'apocalypse plane, mais avec humour. Mais cette fois-ci, c'est du théâtre d'auteur, fruit d'une réflexion plus personnelle et d'un travail plus rigoureux autour de la structure et de la langue.

POUR NOUS AIDER

Afin de mener notre projet à terme, nous avons besoin de votre aide! C'est pourquoi nous avons sélectionné avec soin de précieux collaborateurs qui, en échangent de vos dons, vous offrent toutes sortes de chouettes surprises, pour tous les goûts, et tous les portefeuilles!

***Chaque dollar compte!***

Vos dons nous permettront d'acheter costumes, accessoires, décors, ainsi que supports techniques et technologiques, qui nous permettront de donner vie à l'histoire imaginée par Nicola-Frank. Nous sommes très excités de vous présenter le fruit de notre travail. Voilà maintenant deux ans qu'HYPO existe dans nos têtes, dans nos coeurs, et sur le papier. Nous avons très, très hâte qu'il existe devant vous :)

- Les Hébertistes

 

ÉQUIPE DE PRODUCTION:

Un texte de Nicola-Frank Vachon

Mise en scène: Maryse Lapierre

Interprètes: Mary-Lee Picknell & Nicola-Frank Vachon

Concepteurs: Keven Dubois, Philip Larouche, Marianne Lebel & Jessica Minnello

Assistance à la mise en scène: Shanya Lachance Pruneau

En vieillissant, j'ai non seulement réalisé que l'hypocondrie est un phénomène répandu, mais qu'en plus, celui-ci semble s'exacerber depuis quelques années avec le développement de la technologie. À mes yeux, il est indéniable que la surabondance d'information via internet et les médias sociaux favorise le développement de l'anxiété et de la paranoïa dans la population en général.
C'est ce constat qui m'a poussé à vouloir parler de l'hypocondrie. Non seulement parce que j'en souffre, mais parce que le phénomène semble prendre de plus en plus d'ampleur. À l'exception notable du Malade imaginaire de Molière, il me semble que c'est un sujet qui reste assez peu exploré théâtralement, malgré qu'il semble toucher de plus en plus de gens. Pas seulement l'hypocondrie, mais l'anxiété en général, ou de façon plus globale, la peur. Cette peur qui envahit de plus en plus nos vies paradoxalement hyper connectées, mais aussi séparées de la réalité. Peur de l'autre. Peur de perdre. Peur de manquer quelque chose, de manquer de quelque chose. Peur de rester ou de partir. Peur de mourir. Peur de vivre. Peur de s'engager dans la vie.
« LES HÉBERTISTES » - MANDAT ET HISTORIQUE
Composé de Mary-Lee Picknell et de moi-même, Nicola-Frank Vachon, Les hébertistes est un collectif d'artistes de la région de Québec réuni pour la première fois. Cette collaboration est issue de l'intention de poursuivre ma réflexion et mon travail d'écriture théâtrale entamés au sein du Soucide collectif, une compagnie de création collective de Québec fondée en 2005 avec Catherine Dorion et Virginie Leclerc. Les deux spectacles créés par cette compagnie (Quand le sage pointe la lune, le fou regarde le doigt et Kukipik Doikipu), écrits collectivement via l'improvisation, avaient rencontré un accueil très chaleureux. Il s'agissait dans les deux cas d'un théâtre clownesque lapidaire et éclaté s'attaquant aux travers d'une société de plus en plus déconnectée et déshumanisée. Fort de cette expérience, je veux cette fois-ci poursuivre ma réflexion et mon exploration des thèmes qui me tiennent à cœur, mais d'une toute autre manière. C'est encore une fois un duo féminin/masculin. Les dialogues sont directs et francs. Le réalisme et la poésie s'entremêlent allègrement. L'apocalypse plane, mais avec humour. Mais cette fois-ci, c'est du théâtre d'auteur, fruit d'une réflexion plus personnelle et d'un travail plus rigoureux autour de la structure et de la langue.
POUR NOUS AIDER
Afin de mener notre projet à terme, nous avons besoin de votre aide! C'est pourquoi nous avons sélectionné avec soin de précieux collaborateurs qui, en échangent de vos dons, vous offrent toutes sortes de chouettes surprises, pour tous les goûts, et tous les portefeuilles!
***Chaque dollar compte!***
Vos dons nous permettront d'acheter costumes, accessoires, décors, ainsi que supports techniques et technologiques, qui nous permettront de donner vie à l'histoire imaginée par Nicola-Frank. Nous sommes très excités de vous présenter le fruit de notre travail. Voilà maintenant deux ans qu'HYPO existe dans nos têtes, dans nos coeurs, et sur le papier. Nous avons très, très hâte qu'il existe devant vous :)
- Les Hébertistes
 
ÉQUIPE DE PRODUCTION:

Un texte de Nicola-Frank Vachon
Mise en scène: Maryse Lapierre
Interprètes: Mary-Lee Picknell & Nicola-Frank Vachon
Concepteurs: Keven Dubois, Philip Larouche, Marianne Lebel & Jessica Minnello
Assistance à la mise en scène: Shanya Lachance Pruneau

story:
The Basics

Help Bring SKANKY ME FROM KANKAKEE to the Hollywood Fringe Festival! 

Fire Baton Twirling, Football Hero, Good Son, Bad Boy, Clown, Bully...How many identities have you been on the way to finding out who you are?

A tale of courage in the face of an disapproving world, SKANKY ME  is an original, one man, rock musical of one boy’s passage to self-love and acceptance. It is a humorous tale about navigating the perils on the path to one’s sexual identity, set against the backdrop of the Sexual Revolution in narrow-minded middle America.

Major Themes: Bullying, Sexual Discovery, Sexual Identification, Self Love and Being True to Self.

  • My name is Marc Francoeur - I am an actor and musician and have done theater, composing,  and writing for the past 25 years. I recently premiered SKANKY ME in the "Los Angeles Writer's Center Solo Show Festival" in April of 2014.  
  • WHAT IS THE HOLLYWOOD FRINGE FESTIVAL? http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/learn
  • OFFICIAL SHOW WEBSITE: SKANKYME.COM
  • More on Marc Francoeur in NEUX MAGAZINE:
    http://issuu.com/neux/docs/neuxmag_vol2_2_fnl/115?e=2728813/8962433
  • SKANKY ME was written in an effort to effect more Compassion. The goal of SKANKY ME is to create more Compassion, Acceptance, Tolerance, and Love - for ourselves and others, despite our differences.
  • By helping to get SKANKY ME to the HOLLYWOOD FRINGE FESTIVAL - you will be supporting a show that helps to empower LGBTQQ youths, adults, and EVERYONE else that has ever felt like an outsider to find and own their voice!

SKANKY ME needs your help to fund this new theatrical solo show!

Here's the skinny:

  • The goal is to raise $5K or more to hire a director, a choreographer, a pit band, and back up singers and to get the necessary equipment that will be used in the production. There are also recorded tracks that accompany the show.
  • PERKS!!!! From honorable mentions in the program - to a wonderful autographed Christmas CD of "UNDER THE CHRISTMAS TREE" to a hotel stay for 2 in Los Angeles to sit front row center at a performance of SKANKY ME in the Hollywood Fringe Festival in June of 2015.
  • All funds raised will go toward the production to offset the costs. Theater can be very expensive to produce so any help is AMAZING!

Your Contributions Have A Huge Impact

SKANKY ME was created to inspire people to increase their love for one another - despite their differences:

  • Through entertainment, humor, dance, and spoken word I create a wave of change that helps to heal and inspire everyone!
  • We can all create more space for change - so, whatever you are able to contribute, know that it is going to help create a more compassionate world!
  • SHARE • SHARE • SHARE!!! Let your friends know about SKANKY ME and this campaign! That is a huge contribution!

Risks & Challenges

This goal is not an easy one. There are many hurdles and pits that may be encountered in producing this theatrical spectacle. 

  • By building the proper team of theatrical and music professionals, SKANKY ME has greater potential to move beyond the Fringe Festival into larger venues.
  • I am committed to making this work - come hell or high water!!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share the campaign with your friends and associates, especially if you have a rich millionaire friend who loves to fund theater :) 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to help me get the word out!

Thank You! We are all in this together! Let's make this a better world - where we can all be our true selves! BE TRUE TO YOU!!!

story:
"Every parent of a teenager should see this play. It gives a painful reminder to us all of what it is like trying to find your place in the world..."

Short Summary

"BRB" is an original theatre play by Australian stage and screenwriter, Kirsten Stoddart. It is inspired by the true stories and experiences of teenagers dealing with global issues like self-acceptance, sexuality, social pressures and relationships. Directed by seasoned Irish theatre and screen director, Jessie Kirby, and starring a fresh, young cast of Irish young people from just 16 years old, "BRB" received empassioned responses from audiences and critics alike at its debut at the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, hitting nerves and stirring memories of what it really is like to be a young person trying to decide what you will make of your life. 

"BRB" is a landmark production, written by and for young people the world over. The cast and crew is dedicated and passionate about the work, and we're really keen to spread the messages of our play as far as possible, beginning with Ireland and the UK. 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We have a cast and crew of 10 people - we are a small but passionate group! We want to take our important theatre production to audiences, young and old, around Ireland and the UK. This is where we need funding - for travel expenses, venue hire and advertising materials (posters, flyers and ad spots). 

If we don't get to €10,000, your contributions will go towards our Irish tour basics: food, accommodation and travel. 

Our current budget prediction for the tour is €18,500. Every little bit helps!

The Impact

"Nothing had prepared me the power of the live performance...Every parent of a teenager should see this play. It gives a painful reminder to us all of what it is like trying to find your place in the world."

"BRB" deals with the important issue of youth mental health. It addresses subjects that are often not spoken about in public, or even within families. We want to open the door to conversations that could save lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not have the cash to spare, and we get that. If you would like to help "BRB" get on tour, please Like us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/BRBThePlay), follow us on Twitter (www.twitter.com/BRBThePlay) and share this page with your friends.

story:
Short Summary

The establishment of the Onyx Center for the Performing Arts will support and  develop the performing arts for a diverse audience.  By showcasing the performing arts through a culturally diverse lens, Onyx will nurture young artists, present premiere performances, and support the development of a stellar high school for the performing arts in Harlem.

Founder and Executive Director Evelyn Collins is a passionate advocate for the inclusion of the arts in the public schools and throughout the world. With over 25 years of experience in secondary education and colleges, she has developed performing arts curriculum, and an authentic arts integrated instructional approach that has yielded first generation college graduates.

As Executive Director of the Harlem Ensemble Company she has developed new theatrical works, designed and led fundraising initiatives, wrote - and was awarded grants, and wrote and directed theatrical productions that showcased the African-American experience in musicals and plays for a multicultural audience. She recently completed Part 1 of her documentary film "Dreaming in Color" which screened in October 2013 in NYC, and earlier in May 2013 successfully toured her original musical "Born to Sing" in association with her sorority Alpha Kappa Alpha, Inc.

In creating Onyx Center for the Performing Arts Evelyn has assembled an experienced team of artists who share her passion in: honoring and celebrating the legacies of African American artists through Onyx Honors; showcasing performances and productions; and nurturing the next generation of young artists through professional training and performances.Contributing to this campaign will support the continuation and celebration of the performing arts.

The development of the Onyx Academy for the Performing Arts will provide an opportunity for creative high school students in Harlem to excel academically and artistically as they begin the journey to become life-long learners and patrons of the arts. The mission of Onyx Academy for the Performing Arts is to "create a focused and high performing culture that prepares students for success in college and conservatories, and enhances passion for the performing arts through a rigorous college prep curriculum and intensive training in the arts."

Additionally, contributors will support the dream of sustaining and encouraging future work by African American artists whose contributions to our American landscape have gone unsung.

What We Need & What You Get

Our initial campaign requires $25,000. We will host additional fundraisers for an additional $75,000 through  other arts initiatives.

Funding to this campaign will support:

  • The first annual awards ceremony Onyx Honors 2014 which will recognize the contributions of eight (8) important African American artists, and celebrate their contributions to the culture of America.
  • A performing arts program for youth ages 11-21 that prepares them to excel as performers in theater and dance productions.
  • Supporting the research and development of the Onyx Academy for the Performing Arts, a high school designed for disadvantaged youth residing in Harlem.
  • The presentation of performances by multi-cultural artists from throughout the country.

We have perks for various levels of contributions including tickets to our inaugural celebration of the Onyx Honors in June 2014 in NYC.

The Impact

By contributing to this campaign you will support the continued artistry of the performing arts by African American professionals and youth in their early stages of development.  The creation of the Onyx Center for the Performing Arts is a vital and necessary addition to New York City - the cultural capital of the world. The idea of contributing to the dreams of young people and honoring the legacies of creative artists is an integral desire that is deeply embedded in our heritage and in the hearts and souls of patrons of the performing arts.


 “Art is a nation’s most precious heritage. For it is in our works of art that we reveal to ourselves and to others the inner vision which guides us as a nation. And where there is no vision, the people perish.”

–Lyndon Johnson, on signing into existence the National Endowment on the Arts

story:
BREAKING NEWS:

"To Live, Darling" is now called "O Réjane." Our trailer shoot went beautifully and we'll post a link to the trailer here when the edit is complete. Our presentation of scenes at Bootleg Theater went smashingly. This campaign has covered all of our production costs because we came in under our projected budget! To support us further, please donate tax deductibly through fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas, and we'll still honor all the perks listed here.

“TO LIVE, DARLING:” WORKSHOP ET TRAILER

"To Live, Darling" tells the story of comédienne Réjane, from humble to haute, using text, movement, music and the plays that made her famous during the Belle Époque. Following the success of our spring "To Live, Darling" workshop, the Bootleg Theater is co-producing a presentation of selected scenes from the show. During rehearsals, NoodleHaus will shoot, then produce our first ever video trailer.

Director Christopher Sivertsen, Writer/actor Ilana Turner and actors Cara Pifko, Joe Will and Cecilia de Rico return. Joining the team* is UK Designer Alex Berry, who is costume and set designing the September 12th presentation and trailer shoot. These days, even plays need trailers to market the show and introduce the material to theatres, producers and people of interest around the world. (*Musical collaborator Adrien Reju and Dramaturg Tonia N. Sutherland remain an invaluable part of The Réjane Project team; they will just not physically be in LA for this workshop.) 

WHAT EXACTLY NEEDS FUNDING

All funds donated to The Réjane Project’s “To Live, Darling” through this campaign will fund our September rehearsals, presentation and trailer shoot in Los Angeles. Every dollar we raise means we are one step closer to having a complete show – rich in quality and high caliber talent – to present to live audiences. Our goal for full production is fall 2014.

Huge things have already been generously donated. Our co-producer, The Bootleg Theater, is providing rehearsal, performance and shooting space. NoodleHaus is donating a producer, camera crew, lighting, editorial and post-production for the trailer. Generous friends have furnished lodging for our out-of-towners. 

The additional $2500 we need to raise through this campaign will cover the following:

1. The sound guy – To record live sound for the trailer, we need a sound engineer with good audio equipment.

2. Travel costs – We are sooo lucky to have international collaborators on our team, but the logistics of travel and board are not so lucky. (Miles are also welcome.) 

3. Sets, costumes and props – Our designer will create set pieces, costumes and props for use in the shoot, which will likely also be used in the show's full production.

4. Board - Lodging for our international collaborators has already been generously donated, but they still need to be fed. Physical-theatre makers are a hungry bunch.

Please join our Legion of Donors! Private donations have made The Réjane Project possible. The Réjane Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of The Réjane Project must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by the law. No amount is too small – seriously.

THE REJANE PROJECT - C'EST IMPORTANT!

The Réjane Project was born when Ilana Turner sat in her friend’s living room staring at a Toulouse-Lautrec drawing and a Boldini painting of the French actress Gabrielle Réjane. Réjane, it turned out, was her friend's grandmother. So began five years of Réjane Project research and the resulting play "To Live, Darling."

“To Live, Darling” incorporates original text, text from the plays that made Réjane famous in her time, and original music by Réjane’s great-great granddaughter Adrien Reju. European Director Christopher Sivertsen’s staging is developing from his lauded physical theatre style. “To Live, Darling” celebrates a woman who lived before her time both on–stage and off–, and whose reality frequently mirrored the (sometimes equally) groundbreaking characters she played on stage. 

Although Réjane’s story unfolded over a hundred years ago, many of this plays‘ themes are still familiar, embattled and entirely applicable today. As a working mother whose insatiable quest for artistic growth fed herself, and the artistic and sociopolitical worlds around her, Réjane set a precedent for the world we know today. As Tina Fey said, “The life of a working parent is constantly saying 'This is impossible,' and then you keep doing it.” Réjane did it 125 years ago, and as she did, her work and life evolved into something we would recognize as modern today.

Said Rico Gagliano of the Dinner Party Download, "I saw scenes from 'To Live, Darling' at a showcase of new work, and was struck by its humor, intelligence and style -- kind of Howard Hawkes meets Moulin Rouge. Can't wait to see a full production that gets to play with the piece's ingenious backstage/frontstage structure."

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you can't financially donate to The Réjane Project, you can help!

  • Please, please share this link with people - every mention helps The Réjane Project be seen by more people. You can use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Like The Réjane Project and Réjane on Facebook. Follow us on twitter. 
  • Come see us September 12th, 7:30p, at the Bootleg Theater.
  • Go see any live theatre and talk about it!

Réjane, it turned out, was her friend's grandmother. So began five years of Réjane Project research and the resulting play "To Live, Darling."
“To Live, Darling” incorporates original text, text from the plays that made Réjane famous in her time, and original music by Réjane’s great-great granddaughter Adrien Reju. European Director Christopher Sivertsen’s staging is developing from his lauded physical theatre style. “To Live, Darling” celebrates a woman who lived before her time both on–stage and off–, and whose reality frequently mirrored the (sometimes equally) groundbreaking characters she played on stage. 
Although Réjane’s story unfolded over a hundred years ago, many of this plays‘ themes are still familiar, embattled and entirely applicable today. As a working mother whose insatiable quest for artistic growth fed herself, and the artistic and sociopolitical worlds around her, Réjane set a precedent for the world we know today. As Tina Fey said, “The life of a working parent is constantly saying 'This is impossible,' and then you keep doing it.” Réjane did it 125 years ago, and as she did, her work and life evolved into something we would recognize as modern today.
Said Rico Gagliano of the Dinner Party Download, "I saw scenes from 'To Live, Darling' at a showcase of new work, and was struck by its humor, intelligence and style -- kind of Howard Hawkes meets Moulin Rouge. Can't wait to see a full production that gets to play with the piece's ingenious backstage/frontstage structure."
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Even if you can't financially donate to The Réjane Project, you can help!

Please, please share this link with people - every mention helps The Réjane Project be seen by more people. You can use the Indiegogo share tools.
Like The Réjane Project and Réjane on Facebook. Follow us on twitter. 
Come see us September 12th, 7:30p, at the Bootleg Theater.
Go see any live theatre and talk about it!

story:
My name is Roy Gaynor and I live in Bournemouth in the UK.

In 2013 I staged a brand new musical I have written called No Pasarán! It is about the Spanish Civil War and the bravery of the volunteers of the International Brigades and of the Spanish people. It is also a story of friendship, love and hope for the future.

In 2005 my beautiful son Simon Gaynor died from a brain tumour. Since Simon died I have raised tens of thousands of pounds for The Brain Tumour Charity* for brain tumour research.

I wrote No Pasarán! is to raise more money for the charity but although we got really brilliant audience feedback, we did not sell enough seats to make a profit for the charity.

Here are a few examples of what our audiences said about No Pasarán!

"Wow, what an evening! No Pasarán! was absolutely fabulous. The story was amazing and so expansive and the songs and music were brilliant !" Estelle Gamby

"I thought the musical was fantastic and an amazing feat." Charlie Salter

"The whole production was excellent, exciting and dramatic. The music was amazing and the cast were better than I have heard in any  London West End musical." Janette Skinner 

"The show was amazing and the level of the songs and singing we're fantastic; the story was very moving as well."  Jeremy & Jennie Hollands

Hear the music and see the cast:

I want to stage the show again in 2014 but I spent all my money on the first production so I need your help to take No Pasarán! to bigger audiences and achieve our goal of raising a lot of money for cancer research.

Longer term, I will tour No Pasarán! around the UK and then into other countries to create a continuous flow of funds for the charity so your contribution will do much more than a direct donation. By helping us to grow awareness and build momentum, we will be able to help brain tumour sufferers for many years to come. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need £30,000 to stage No Pasarán! again. This will be spent on a bigger theatre, better costumes and make-up, upgraded sound and lighting systems and of course greatly improved marketing so that we get bigger audiences.

If we do not reach our Indiegogo funding goal then all the money we do get will be spent on the best possible production we can achieve for the money so that whatever happens we will raise money for the charity and build awareness and momentum for the future.

If we exceed our Indiegogo funding goal then we will use the extra money to help fund our UK tour so that all the money we get will go towards raising even more money for the charity in the future.

We will openly show our accounts, listing all our funding, ticket income and expenditure on our website so that you can see exactly where your money is being used and the results we achieve.

We think that contributing to the cause of brain tumour research is a great reward but we also know that many people like to get something tangible in acknowledgement of their contribution. Please take a look at the perks we will give to you. 

The Impact

In the UK over 9,000 people are diagnosed with a brain tumour each year and brain tumours are the biggest cancer killer of children and adults under 40.

In the US more than 180,000 brain tumours (malignant and benign) are diagnosed each year. They are most common in adults between the ages of 40 and 70 and in children between the ages of 3 and 12. The picture is much the same in most parts of the World. Please help us to reduce these dreadful numbers. 

What is it really like for brain tumour sufferers and their families?

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help us financially, then you can still contribute by telling everyone you know about our cause and about No Pasarán! Help us build awareness, momentum and our audience numbers. Use the Indiegogo Share Tools to spread our message.

Find out what else is happening in your neighbourhood and if you can, get active in supporting your local brain tumour fund raising initiatives with your time, imagination and energy. 

Thank you for reading about my work, plans and goals and for contributing to our cause.

Roy Gaynor

story:
About This Effort

The Greater Sleepy Hollow Tarrytown Chamber in conjunction with The Tarrytown Merchants' Council and The Village of Tarrytown are bringing hanging flowering baskets to Broadway this Spring! The Village of Tarrytown has generously contributed towards the baskets, BUT… we still need to raise an additional $5,400 to help cover the cost of the 84 baskets, 42 brackets, and the cascading geraniums. Thank you for helping to make and keep Tarrytown beautiful!

Here are some of the images of the baskets so you can see what we are ordering. They are very similar to the baskets now hanging on Main Street, except these are double baskets instead of one central basket.

We have selected 17" by 9" metal baskets with decorative brackets that will be filled with Red Cascade Ivy Geraniums.


Sponsors who contribute $150 - the cost of one full basket set - will receive a plaque on the lamp post, and all sponsors will be thanked on the Chamber Website!

When you (or your company) sponsor a Hanging Basket your name will be featured on a small plaque affixed to the lamp post where your basket hangs! 

For full sponsorship and all other levels of support from $25 and up, we will include your name under our contributors list for this effort on the Chamber website. 

We take great pride in our town and how it looks and feels – and we know that you do too! It certainly does “take a village” – and boy what a village we have!

If you are not comfortable or do not wish to pay by credit card online, please show your support by making out your check to The Greater Sleepy Hollow Tarrytown Chamber with Hanging Basket Sponsor in the Memo line and drop off or mail to:

W@tercooler, 21 North Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591 (2nd floor, above Mr. Nick's)

Thank you!!

story:
THE PROJECT:

To present a staged, choreographed, lit and costumed workshop production of Siren’s Den, a new rock musical, in April 2016 in NYC.  The show will be performed in the East Village at Under St. Mark’s, an exclusive 40 seat venue with an underground rock club vibe.  Audience feedback will help to further develop the piece for future festivals and larger productions.

THE SHOW:

Siren’s Den is a full length rock musical with book, music and lyrics by Rori Nogee (Star of Off-Broadway’s acclaimed Showgirls, the Musical! and writer of Down This Road).   Siren’s Den is a cautionary tale about the emptiness of fame, the blindness of love, and the healing powers of writing through the darkest times.  The 23 original songs in the score are in the vein of 90’s rock meets Spring Awakening and Rent, with haunting melodies and story-driving lyrics.  The cast is comprised of 12 powerhouse triple threat performers.

MULTIMEDIA:

Check out sneak peeks of the songs on Soundcloud!

https://soundcloud.com/sirens-den-musical

"Siren's Den" is featured in the blog, Call Me Adam!  Read the article here:

http://www.callmeadam.com/interviews/2016/2/18/call-redialed-rori-nogee-sirens-den.html#.Vsag2lKJnzK

THE GOAL:

We hope that the presentation of this musical will be an invaluable experience to all involved.  The writer will see and hear her work on its feet and gage the reactions of its first live audience; the audience will see a world premiere of a piece in development and give constructive feedback to further improve the show; the actors will have an opportunity to perform professionally on a NY stage and create a new work from the ground up. 

THE PLOT:

Siren’s Den is a dark, modern twist on the myth of the ancient Greek sirens who lured sailors to their deaths with their songs.  Here, the turbulent sea is the music industry, and the siren is Skylar Cole, a seductive indie rock singer in NYC.

Skylar’s biggest fan is Remy Morgan, a young, aspiring singer who finds that her songwriting is fueled by her time spent with Skylar.  Although Remy and Skylar form an immediate bond, their attempts at connection are thwarted by Skylar’s hungry fans, the Vultures, her possessive personal assistant, her suspicious boyfriend, and her own sordid past.

Soon, Remy finds herself drawn into a world of drugs, lust and empty promises, where  some idols don’t deserve pedestals and some dreams come with dire consequences. 

Will Remy find success?  Or will she fall prey to Skylar’s siren song forever?

WHERE THE MONEY GOES:

All of the money raised will go to funding the workshop production.  Expenses include:

-Paying the 12 actors

-Paying the creative team

-Paying the musicians who help make arrangements for the backing vocal tracks

-Paying for the transcription of sheet music

-Paying for the use of the performance space in the East Village

-Paying for 2 weeks of rehearsal space, which includes large dance studios to choreograph the explosive dance numbers

-Paying for audition space to cast the talented actors

-Paying for a piano accompanist for the singing auditions

-Paying for the printing of scripts for the entire company

-Paying for the printing of advertising postcards

-Paying for the printing of audience programs

-Paying for costume pieces to complete the look of the show

-And most importantly, it will help to make a dream come true!

PROJECT HISTORY:

Siren’s Den has been in development since 2012.  It received a table read at CAP 21 Studios in May 2014, and 15 minutes of the show was presented as part of the West Village Musical Theater Festival in June 2014.

CREATIVE TEAM:

Rori Nogee(Book/Music/Lyrics):As a performer, Rori has appeared on Broadway (Joseph…Dreamcoat), Off-Broadway (Showgirls, the Musical!), in national and North American tours (Disney Junior’s, Chuggington, Live!) and in regional productions including Rent(Maureen), Grease(Rizzo), Gypsy(Mazeppa), Murder Ballad(Narrator) and Arizona Broadway Theater’s upcoming Rock of Ages(Regina). Rori has also appeared in the NYC Fringe and Midtown International Theater Festivals and on America’s Got Talent. Her voice can be heard on the Love Quirks concept album. She can currently be seen in Truffles! at The Cutting Room. 
As a writer, Rori’s play, Down This Road, was selected for readings with Sink or Swim Rep, Chelsea Rep Lap, and Identity Theater’s Self-Aware Reading Series. Her concept musical, Fragments, was presented at Don’t Tell Mama. She also has two completed screenplays and is currently writing two other full length plays entitled Borderline and Aftershocks.  Rori’s training includes The Lee Strasberg Institute, Circle in the Square, and the LAByrinth Theater Intensive. She started writing music at 16, which incidentally, is also the year she first fell in love.

Marishka Phillips(Director): Broadway actress, accomplished director, and thespian guru, Marishka S. Phillips is an actor’s actor with an extraordinary wealth of talent.  A native of Brooklyn, New York, Marishka began performing at age of eight, and by the time she was thirteen, was cast in the European tour of Raisin, a musical version of the popular play A Raisin In The Sun. Upon graduating from Springfield Gardens High School, Mariskha honed in on her skills at the prestigious Alvin Ailey School of Dance, the Broadway Dance Center, and Fordham University, where she studied theater arts.    As an actress, singer, and dancer, Marishka is bona fide triple threat, and has performed and toured with Sean P.Diddy Combs, Christian Castro, and CeCe Winans, just to name a few.    As an acting coach, in 2011, Marishka founded the Marishka Phillips Theatrical Preparatory. Having coached and trained some of the Hollywood’s biggest names, including Deborah Cox, Kerry Washington, Terri Vaughn, Rafael Sadiiq, Tasha Smith and Elizabeth Rohm, Marishka’s ingenious acting method combines the traditional art of story telling through a spiritual connection.    On screen, she made her directorial debut with Love Always, Eartha, a short film that takes an in-depth look at the life of Eartha Kitt in 1955.  Marishka lives and resides in New York City, and is also an official New York Casting Director.   And has penned a dramatic screenplay entitled, MELINDA, currently seeking funding.

William Bailey(Choreographer/Costumes):William has done choreography for multiple recording artists. As well as being a part of Broadway national tours and Broadway cast recordings, he's been on shows like Watch what happens live with Andy Cohen. He has also choreographed shows like Cats, High School Musical, and a spot on Nickelodeon, and been dance captain for multiple shows including Fame, Freckleface Strawberry, and Once on this Island. William also is a prominent drag queen in NYC that goes by the name Jada Valenciaga, which you can see in the upcoming documentary "Dragged" and a new film called "party of one"

Ricky Romano(Musical Director): Ricky is an active Music Director, Piano Instructor, and Vocal Coach in the New York Metropolitan area. He is currently the Music Director of the Off-Broadway revival Ruthless! The Musical at St. Luke’s Theatre, working in tandem with it’s original book writer and composer, Joel Paley and Marvin Laird, respectively. Aside from theatre, Ricky is a sought after pianist/keyboardist for vocalists, bands, and recording studios. Previously, he was the keyboardist/vocalist for Flat Five, an alternate rock band. They have performed extensively throughout the Tri-State area inducing appearances at The Chance Theatre, The Bitter End, Jones Beach Theatre, and The Hard Rock Cafe in Times Square. Ricky received a bachelor’s degree in Music Business and Business Administration from SUNY Potsdam. Other Music Directing credits - Off-Broadway: Ruthless! The Musical (Triad Theatre), Choices: A New Rock Musical (2012 West Village Musical Theatre Festival). Industry Readings: Love Quirks. Regional: Gypsy (Yorktown Stage), [title of show] (Westchester Sandbox Theater).

Stage Manager: Lauren Arneson

Musical Arrangements: Frank Perri and Jaden Nogee

Lighting Design: James Prez Carter
