story:
The DC Stunt Coalition returns to the sands for more brutal gladiator combat at Spartacon 2!

 

The Red Serpents LLC have brought on the DC Stunt Coalition Gladiators team to once again fight for honor and glory in the arena of Spartacon 2! This production is an opportunity for members of our organization to learn and grow as fight performers, and gives veteran members a chance to keep themselves sharp while bringing astonishing, brutal entertainment to thousands of fans. We are using this campaign to help support our performers and crew, as well as provide extra ways to connect with fans!

 

There is no greater thing than standing victorious in the arena.

The DC Stunt Coalition (DCSC) has brought on by Red Serpents, LLC. to perform the official live action gladiator fights for the only official U.S. Spartacus-themed fan convention, Spartacon.

 

For the last few months, DCSC has been in production of their next astonishing gladiator fight show. It has been a challenging road, requiring all of us to sacrifice time, money, and give up all things cake-like in order to become the Champions you'll be seeing on August 13th and 14th at the Waldorf Arena.

 

 

We need your help to show appreciation to this marvelous collection of incredibly talented stunt performers and action actors as they give blood, sweat, and tears upon the sands for your entertainment.

 

We've already performed incredibly well-received and successful shows at MAGFest, AwesomeCon, and Otakon. Spartacon is our next stop on the road to glory!

 

This campaign is being produced in an effort to support our cast, give the audience a chance to interact with us in some very unique and awesome ways, all to insure our excitement and inspiration when producing future shows.

 

If you can offer us your patronage, not only will we reward you with special tribute items, but we'll also shout out your name in the arena, in front of thousands of fans and even the original cast of the hit Starz television series, Spartacus.



 

By giving us your support this time around, you're insuring not only the success of this performance, but helping to fund future performances from the DC Stunt Coalition by showing that there is in fact an audience for these kind of bad-ass, non-stop action spectaculars for all fandoms and genres.

Help Our Ludus! Become a patron of our gladiators, and join us in glory upon the sands!

The DC Stunt Coalition (DCSC) is aiming to raise just $1,000 to go towards paying our production crew and the cast a fair reimbursement for their hard work and long hours spent putting this show together.

 

Every performer has purchased at least one personal training weapon (a Cold Steel training gladius valued at $22), as well as costume stunt shoes ($26 a pair), and paid 3 months of dues towards DC Stunt Coalition in order to afford training space and time ($60 per person). We want to do our best to reimburse our gladiators for these training costs.

 


 

Anything we can profit on will also go towards the DC Stunt Coalition coffers - the publicity from this campaign, as well as your continued support and patronage, will help us to make bigger, better shows in the future. Not just for Spartacon, but for MAGFest, Otakon, AwesomeCon, and more. We'd love to perform at all of these events, but without a source of crowd funds, we can't afford to do all of them! Help us take our show on the road.

Funds from this campaign will also go towards producing OFFICIAL DC Stunt Coalition Gladiator T-shirts, tank tops, and photo cards (to be signed at SPARTACON), so that we can better promote our brand at the event, and allow for a more interactive connection with our fan base. We want to make you guys a part of the action!

 

Your donations will allow us to spend time at the event meeting-and-greeting with you, the fans, by providing us with better accouterments to our Ludus Suite.

 

Even if we can't reach our entire goal, we'll be splitting what we raise between our production crew, as well as putting it towards providing the above mentioned perks to the fans.

 

More than anything, we want YOU, the audience, to be a part of this show, whether that means wearing our colors with our bad ass, Spartacus: Blood and Sand inspired T-shirt, or by taking home a signed photo post card featuring our own gladiators in their incredible costumes, as created by Motley Maker Designs. Our costume designer, Rachel, has already put in over 100 hours of unpaid time to create 15 unique, genuine leather-and-rivet Gladiator costumes - including tributes to Spartacus, Crixus, and the Shadow of Death himself, Theokolese, and even original characters to introduce to the sands this year!




 

"Nothing in this world is impossible when heart and mind are put towards it!"

Fight shows like these give members of the Coalition an opportunity to sharpen their skills immensely with a specific goal over a short period of time. Training is intense, and requires a lot of sacrifices on the part of the performers and crew.

 

Many of our members train every weekend in the hopes that one day they'll be professional Hollywood stunt performers, theatrical stage combatants, or notable action actors. For many, this is just a first step towards achieving a career in the entertainment profession.

 

Your support helps them to push themselves to the limit in the pursuit of this goal.

"A man must accept his fate, or be destroyed by it."

 

We want it to be known that we're going to all of this effort to put on a unique and enthralling experience for fans of Spartacus and gladiator fights everywhere! DC Stunt Coalition has a presence on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, as well as our official website. Share our content, like and favorite our posts, and if you feel so inclined, tag, tweet and share it to the actors from the original television show like Liam McIntyre and Manu Bennett, so they know what kind of amazing tribute is being done towards their legacy.

 

IndieGoGo also has plenty of Share tools for you to use! Click those!

Spartacon 2 is in the DC area on August 13th and 14th, 2016. If you can show up, you can join the crowds and cheer us on, stop by our merchandise booth, say hi, and tell us how much you enjoyed the show. If you want us to come back again, witness our epic gladiator fights, and answer that age-old question:

"ARE YOU NOT ENTERTAINED!"

Gratitude!

Cast and Crew of the DC Stunt Coalition

story:
Helden gesucht!

 

Willkommen in der Zeit - Helden sind bereit.
Seid ihr soweit...?
Heldenzeit 

                                                           -Wir sind Helden-


 

Wir sind das "Junge Musical Leverkusen e.V." und sind auf der Suche nach Helden, die uns und unser nächstes Projekt “Big Fish – das Musical” unterstützen wollen.

 

  • Wer wir sind? Das "Junge Musical Leverkusen e.V."  ein gemeinnütziger, junger, dynamischer Verein, der seit Mai 2008 Musicals auf die Bühne bringt.
     
  • Dank deiner Unterstützung, können wir eine tolle Geschichte noch toller machen, die Ticketpreise gering halten und so ein Theatererlebnis für jederman anbieten.
     
  • Wir arbeiten ehrenamtlich und fördern Jugendliche in ihrer Kreativität, Selbstständigkeit und stärken ihr Selbstbewusstsein.
     
  • Mit unseren Beiträgen tragen wir zur Erhaltung und Unterstützung des kulturellen Angebots unserer Region bei.
     
  • Mit deiner Unterstützung können wir:

- Die Technik bezahlen und die Rechte auch.

- Unsere Dozenten fair vergüten.

- Kostüme, Bühnenbilder und Requisiten erstellen.

- Unsere Darsteller verpflegen und das Orchester füttern.

- Dir einen unvergesslichen Abend bereiten.

Du unterstützt junge Leute, die über ein Jahr in mühsamer Arbeit, in ihrer Freizeit ein Stück auf die Beine stellen, um dich mit einem Lächeln nach Hause zu schicken.

 

 

Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst


 

  • Unser Ziel sind 15.000 Euro
     
  • 50% des Ziels gehen allein an die Technik für eins der zwei geplanten Wochenenden.
     
  • 20% gehen an die Miete des Theaters.
     
  • 10% unseres Kampagnenziels können wir für Kostüme für über 30 Darsteller verwenden. Alles natürlich handgemacht, da unsere Mitglieder in allen Bereichen tätig sind, nicht nur auf der Bühne.
     
  • Mit weiteren 10% des Kampagnenziel können wir ein multifunktionales Bühnenbild zaubern, dass die Welt in der Big Fish spielt zum Leben erweckt.
     
  • 5% gehen an die Requisite und weiter 5% gehen an die Maske, die unsere Darsteller nicht nur gut aussehen lässt, sondern vor den Shows auch noch mit motivierenden Worten aufbaut, bevor es dann los geht.
     
  • Unsere Dozenten für Tanz und Regie kommen alle aus dem professionellen Darstellerleben und werden bei uns fair vergütet. Du kannst uns dabei unterstützen, weiterhin Darsteller zu beschäftigen und so die Qualität unserer Shows hoch zuhalten. 
     
  • Unsere unvergleichlichen Angebote können dir ein heldenhaftes Erlebnis bescheren. Für jeden ist etwas dabei. Für die Feierhelden veranstalten wir bei dir eine unvergessliche Heldensause, mit Band oder ohne. Der bescheidene Held kann sich mit einem T-Shirt von uns schmücken, oder in unserer Helden- Hall of Fame verewigen. Vielleicht bist du aber auch unser Held des Tages und wirst Hauptsponsor und wir platzieren dich auf unserem Ticket, Plakat und Programmheft, sowie auf unserer Homepage.

Wir sind dankbar für jede Unterstützung.

 

 

Die Folgen

 

Mit deinem Beitrag unterstützt du unsere Helden auf der Bühne und wirst selber zum Held:

 

  • Wir sind auf dich angewiesen, damit der Verein ein niederschwelliges Angebot bleiben kann;  für alle unsere Mitglieder und auch Zuschauer.
     
  • Mit Big Fish haben wir eine Geschichte gefunden, die erzählt werden muss. In keinem Theaterstück gibt es so viele Charaktere, in denen man sich und seine Eigenheiten wieder finden kann.
     
  • Auf einfache und eindringliche Weise werden wir an die Themen:
    Familie, Zusammenhalt, Ehrlichkeit, Vergänglichkeit und Liebe herangeführt ohne mit dem moralischen Zeigefinger auf uns zu zeigen.
     
  • Unter unseren vergangenen großen Produktionen befinden sich:

- Natürlich Blond (2016)

- Aida (2015)

- History of Musical (2014)

- Die Schöne und das Biest (2013)

- Lampenfieber² (2012)

- Der kleine Horrorladen (2011)

- Lampenfieber (2010)

  • Darüber hinaus findet man uns bei kleineren Konzerten, auf dem Weihnachtsmarkt, in der Fußgängerzone, oder bei anderen Veranstaltungen.

 

 

Risiken & Herausforderungen

 

Bei Risiken und Nebenwirkungen, fragen Sie ihren Arzt oder Kampagnenberater...

 

  • Hinter einem großen Projekt stehen viele Leute, das birgt immer das Risiko, dass jemand abspringt, jemand erkrankt oder irgendetwas schief läuft. Doch unser grandioses Team ist über die Jahre zu einer kleinen Familie zusammengewachsen mit einer ganz besonderen Dynamik.
     
  • Jede Hand in unserem Team packt dort an, wo Hilfe benötigt wird. Sodass alle Schultern dieses Projekt tragen.
     
  • Unsere Doppelbesetzungen und Swings garantieren immer ein spielfähiges Ensemble.
     
  • Die enge Arbeit mit dem Kulturbereich unser Stadt garantiert uns einen reibungslosen Ablauf unserer Shows und der Organisation.

 

 

Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann


Spread the word:

  • Du kannst nichts spenden? Möchtest uns aber trotzdem unterstützen? 
     
  • Kein Problem erzähl doch einfach von unserer Kampagne oder werbe für unser Stück! Wir freuen uns auf Unterstützung auf jede erdenkliche Weise.
     
  • Vielleicht möchtest du uns auch hinter der Bühne, beim Kostüme nähen, Bühnenbild bauen oder Requisiten basteln helfen. Schau doch mal auf unserer Homepage vorbei, dort findest du einen Ansprechpartner. Keine Scheu schreib einfach eine Email.

 

Vielen Dank, dass du dir die Zeit genommen hast und bis hierhin gelesen hast, wir freuen uns dich demnächst bei einer unserer Aufführungen zu begrüßen.

Falls du noch Fragen oder Anregungen hast, freuen wir uns über deine Email an: marketing@jungesmusical.de! 

#seiderHeld

story:
Who We Are:

The Parul Shah Dance Company is a Brooklyn-based Kathak and contemporary dance company that harnesses the expressive power of movement to explore questions around belonging, identity, and empathy. Our work aims to create shared experiences and lasting connections between performers and audiences. 

What We Do:

Established in 2006 by artistic director Parul Shah, our work has deep roots within the North Indian classical dance form of Kathak. We also step outside the form’s parameters to discover different ways of moving that reflect our world today. Our repertoire spans both classical and contemporary dance vocabularies, and our influences include our own experiences and observations as much as our training. We are especially driven to shining a light on marginalized stories, and are committed to outreach and education through studio classes, workshops, and lecture demonstrations.

Currently in our 15th season, we have performed around the world and at home to critical acclaim, including the first Fall for Dance Festival at City Center, the Dancing the God's Festival at World Music Institute, and residencies at both New York Live Arts and Mass MoCA. 

As we continue to grow, our goals are simple: to produce work that speaks to and connects with many people, to promote dialogue, and to dance. 

What We Need:

We were recently awarded a grant through the Mertz Gilmore Foundation that provides rehearsal space at Eva Dean Dance in Park Slope, Brooklyn. We are grateful for this opportunity and will be using this space to expand our current work in progress, "Enduring Silence," which will premiere at Erasing Boarder's Dance Festival in August 2017. The piece illustrates the physical hardships and inequities faced by women around the world under the canopy of tradition. "Enduring Silence" takes its inspiration from the resiliency and strength of these women, using the many gaits and gestures found in all Indian classical dance forms that have evolved to depict women in dance.

We are asking for your support to cover basic costs, including artist fees, costume design, and music composition, to develop this work in progress. Music composition is of particular importance since "Enduring Silence" is performed to live music and requires significant rehearsal time with musicians that is not covered by performance fees. 

This is our first crowd funding effort and we greatly appreciate any contribution, big or small. If you cannot donate, you can still help out by sharing this campaign with friends and family. Your efforts will support a community of artists who have great respect for their audiences and who are challenging conventional notions of South Asian dance.

story:
Site Dance, technology, and the Stage Come Together for Dance Canvas season 2014-2015! 

Since 2008, Brittany Whitmoyer has been creating dance professionally and sharing it with the world. 2008 was the year she began bnw:dance, a contemporary company that has been called "a solid pickup troupe that's serious about concept, craft and execution." (Time Out Chicago). Since then, bnw:dance has been seen in NYC, Richmond, VA, Chicago, Washington DC, Philadelphia, and London. 
In 2012 Whitmoyer put a pause on bnw:dance to focus on receiving her MFA in Dance, which she completed in 2014. 
Back in choreography action and in a new city, Whitmoyer is proud and honored to be selected as a Dance Canvas choreographer for the 2014-2015 season. This opportunity will allow her and her dancers to push further into the exploratory and work with new concepts of mixing both film and dance in a collaborative setting. 
site. is Whitmoyer's newest work and will be premiered during the Dance Canvas season, at Rialto Center for the Arts, January 23-24. The process is based on the generation of "site specific choreography." Though this is a performance for the stage, the choreography will be conceptualized from different areas all over the city of Atlanta. These pinpoints will be filmed, and ultimately projected behind the dancers throughout the performance. Each movement and every intention in their steps will come from a park, a street corner, or even a sign, from different neighborhoods throughout Atlanta.  
Our ultimate hope is for the audience to find a newfound love for their community and surroundings, the way site dance often assists with, though the power of movement. 
Dancers for site.:
Hudson Frisby, Pablina Lopez, Sarah Stokes

Your Contribution and How You Can Help!

We are asking for $1000.00. We know that seems like a lot, but a little goes a long way in support of the arts! Here are some of the things your generous donation will go towards:

  • Rehearsal space- So we can continue to create our work and put on an amazing show in January!
  • Artist fees- So we can pay our hard working dancers! This one is pretty important!
  • Production Fees- The technological side of our work, filming and editing and all the equipment that it requires!
  • Costuming Fees- So our dancers look amazing on the beautiful Rialto stage!

    Other Ways You Can Help!

    We understand that not everyone can help us monetarily. There are other ways you can help us get site. the funding we need to be a great success!

    • Spread the word! Share this page! Email it, post it on social media- get the word out!
    • Come see the show! Dance Canvas' season is at the Rialto Center for the Arts, January 23-24, 2015. Check out www.dancecanvas.com for information!

story_txt:
Site Dance, technology, and the Stage Come Together for Dance Canvas season 2014-2015! 
Since 2008, Brittany Whitmoyer has been creating dance professionally and sharing it with the world. 2008 was the year she began bnw:dance, a contemporary company that has been called "a solid pickup troupe that's serious about concept, craft and execution." (Time Out Chicago). Since then, bnw:dance has been seen in NYC, Richmond, VA, Chicago, Washington DC, Philadelphia, and London. 
In 2012 Whitmoyer put a pause on bnw:dance to focus on receiving her MFA in Dance, which she completed in 2014. 
Back in choreography action and in a new city, Whitmoyer is proud and honored to be selected as a Dance Canvas choreographer for the 2014-2015 season. This opportunity will allow her and her dancers to push further into the exploratory and work with new concepts of mixing both film and dance in a collaborative setting. 

site. is Whitmoyer's newest work and will be premiered during the Dance Canvas season, at Rialto Center for the Arts, January 23-24. The process is based on the generation of "site specific choreography." Though this is a performance for the stage, the choreography will be conceptualized from different areas all over the city of Atlanta. These pinpoints will be filmed, and ultimately projected behind the dancers throughout the performance. Each movement and every intention in their steps will come from a park, a street corner, or even a sign, from different neighborhoods throughout Atlanta.  
Our ultimate hope is for the audience to find a newfound love for their community and surroundings, the way site dance often assists with, though the power of movement. 
Dancers for site.:
Hudson Frisby, Pablina Lopez, Sarah Stokes Your Contribution and How You Can Help!
 We are asking for $1000.00. We know that seems like a lot, but a little goes a long way in support of the arts! Here are some of the things your generous donation will go towards: 
Rehearsal space- So we can continue to create our work and put on an amazing show in January! Artist fees- So we can pay our hard working dancers! This one is pretty important! Production Fees- The technological side of our work, filming and editing and all the equipment that it requires!
Costuming Fees- So our dancers look amazing on the beautiful Rialto stage!

  Other Ways You Can Help! We understand that not everyone can help us monetarily. There are other ways you can help us get site. the funding we need to be a great success! 
Spread the word! Share this page! Email it, post it on social media- get the word out! Come see the show! Dance Canvas' season is at the Rialto Center for the Arts, January 23-24, 2015. Check out www.dancecanvas.com for information! 
 We thank you in advance for ANY and ALL support and look forward to another amazing dance adventure!

story:
The BLUE HAWAII SPECTACULAR will be a rockabilly, fun and sun, weekend event & variety show featuring some of the best and most unique acrobatic, vaudeville and burlesque acts from all over the US at Next Act Theatre, 255 S. Water Street, in Milwaukee, WI on Sept. 13th, 14th and 15th, a salute to the campiness of the 1960's beach movie genre and The King himself.

Such great acts as Gravity Plays Favorites, Tomahawk Tassels, Pouty Petals, Vince V Vice, Molotov Maybelle, the Hale O Malo hula dancers, Gypsy Geoff, Francesca Alfresca, Sir Pinkerton, and physical comedian Micheal Guthrie have committed to this show. I am still in talks with even more great talent, and hope to bring you the best show possible.

Hi, my name is Alice Wilson-Stuart, a local producer from Milwaukee. I've recently started my own production company, Rockabilly Girl Productions, and just completed my first successful show/event under that banner (Horror-O-Rama.) The Blue Hawaii Spectacular is near and dear to my heart, as I was struck by inspiration, when on my honeymoon, I saw the "Viva Elvis" Cirque du Soleil show in Vegas. I thought of all the great performers I know locally, and across the country, and really wanted to build a fantastic show for Milwaukee. I've always wanted to start a rockabilly weekender, and while this 3 day event will have aspects of that, it also combines my first true love, theatre.


Here's a quick rundown of the weekend:

Fri. Sept. 13th & Sat. Sept. 14th: 7:30P - Blue Hawaii Spectacular Variety Show at Next Act Theatre

Sat. Sept. 14th: 2-6P - Party at Next Act Theatre with live music, food, vendors, car show and Miss Blue Hawaii Pin Up Contest! FREE, No admission fee for this part of the event!

Sun. Sept. 15th: 12noon-2P - Pig Party at Smoke Shack, our fabulous sponsor! FREE, No admission fee for this part of the event!

Sun. Sept. 15th: 2P - Blue Hawaii ALL Elvis Impersonator Contest/Show aka Mr. Blue Hawaii

These Indiegogo funds are needed for box office & theatre staff, travel and accomodations for national acts, entertainment for our Saturday shindig, as well as promotional and marketing materials and airtime.  If the goal is reached, The Exotics, an amazing local surf band, will be able to be hired as "house band" for the variety show, which would be awesome! I am hoping to make the "Spectacular" an annual event, with a different theme each year.

If you're on the fence about donating, I hope the "perks" being offered will move you to contribute, from an Indiegogo exclusive designed tee shirt to coffee mugs to bowling shirts, and even tickets.  If you cannot contribute, I sure would appreciate it if you could pass on the word to your friends, or anyone you may know who you think would enjoy this rockin' good time. Indiegogo makes it easy with their sharing tools!
Thank you for reading this, and I hope to see you Sept. 13, 14 & 15th at Next Act Theatre. And if you see my husband in a grass skirt, thank him for me for all his support.

story:
What is this campaign about? 

Welcome to Sophie’s campaign! We are so excited to have you here. My name is Diana Westphal and together with my dear colleague Federica Rangel, we are bringing a play about peaceful resistance against nazi Germany to life in New York.

“Sophie Scholl- The Final Days”, written by Fred Breinersdorfer and Betty Hensel, follows the siblings Hans and Sophie Scholl, who form a resistance group named The White Rose in 1943. Together with a group of college friends, they secretly print and distribute anti-nazi flyers that call for a peaceful overthrow of Hitler. They are apprehended and we follow them through their days of interrogation and imprisonment, all the way to their final trial.

Why this story and why in New York?

Sophie and Hans grew up in southern Germany, in the city of Ulm, two blocks away from where I grew up. The courage the siblings and all members of the White Rose found within themselves, made them my heroes ever since I was a kid. Now, as a young theater artist living in New York, I want to build a bridge from Ulm all the way to the United States, by sharing one of Germany's most inspirational stories from her darkest time in history. I want to not only commemorate the White Rose’s almost inexplicably brave resistance, but also pose the question that Sophie has made me ask myself again and again: what would I have done in her place? What am I doing today?

By contributing to this campaign, you can help us strengthen transatlantic cultural exchange, understand how resistance can look like, and allow us to reevaluate what freedom of speech, religious freedom, and democracy mean for us. Furthermore, this play is a powerful study about privilege, and the impact we can have when we hold it. This production examines how Sophie and her friends fought against a  power structure that systemically would have benefited them. Their story feels as potent as ever, given the current political and cultural climate and the global conversation around privilege today. 

We, the production team Federica and Diana, are very excited to make our dream come true and produce this world premiere of the English version of "Sophie Scholl- The Final Days.“ The two of us became friends and collaborators during our conservatory training at the Stella Adler Studio of Acting in New York City. As graduates of '18, we are grateful to now find ourselves with the time, resources, energy and the support of our school, to be able to produce this play which is so relevant and personal to each of us. 

What difference will your contribution make?

  1. You will enable two young artists to offer new and international work to the New York audience.
  2. You will allow the audience to experience a story about non-violent political resistance and to be inspired by the courage and moral strength of the White Rose.
  3. You will be among our vital first contributors, enabling us to begin our journey with this play. We will be documenting this production through video and photos, which will then allow us to apply for larger artist grants next year. 
  4. We have hopes to traveling to England and other countries. To make that happen, it's vital to document this very first production. That way our play can grow and be presented in other countries. We want to share Sophie’s story with as many more people as we can, and this is our first step to do it.
  5. Your contribution is an investment to uphold the centuries-old struggle for democracy and for political and religious freedom. Be a part of a celebration of courage and let us together contribute artistically and peacefully to our democratic way of life. 

What do we need?

We are trying to raise $12.000 for this off-off-Broadway production. Our budget is calculated as following: 

Theater rental: $2000

Rehearsal space five weeks: $3600

Crew wages: $2800

Production design light, sound & set: $1200

Marketing: $1000

Rights for play: $800

Insurance: $600 TBD

Total: $12.000

We are lucky to have been offered a very good price for a sixty seat newly renovated space in the heart of Manhattan's theatre district. 

What we can offer you:

$40: Your name on our set! 

$80: A postcard of the play signed by cast and producers

$150: A handwritten thank you card from our team

$250: Your name appears on the program

$300: The first five will be invited to attend the first reading with the full cast and director

Full item: If someone wants to sponsor a whole item of the budget, you will get a credit as executive producer for the whole play.

What are our challenges?

Since the two of us come from different parts of the world, it is challenging to include our multiple communities, languages and backgrounds into this process. How do we connect a Venezuelan and a German community in one project?

Another really exciting challenge is to involve people who are not personally connected to German history. That itself is the reason and reward of our work: to spread this inspirational story, to share this act of resistance, and identify its universality.

Our last challenge lies in the very nature of the content we make, because we want to honor the serious and true story of this play, all while motivating and lifting up our contributors. We are trying to create positive seriousness. So in circumstances of darkness and terror, we challenge ourselves and all of you to keep shining the light on courage and strength.

What is our risk?

Our risk is that we aren’t able to create a play as complete, visually rich, and captivating as we  think it deserves.

What would we do if we don’t reach our goal?

If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will have to lower the production value, which means that we won’t be able to transport the audience as swiftly into the place and time this play is set in. The artistic vision of the designers will be compromised by a lower budget. We will, however, definitely make this play happen, even if we have to come up with very creative solutions.

What qualifications do we have to overcome these hurdles?

We think we can do it by sharing diverse and personalized content for specific groups, in all different languages. We will have to keep in mind each person, company or organization that wants to contribute, which means we will market it to a broad field. Therefore, please bear with us when we post in German, Spanish or even French- that will be one way of reaching different audiences and bringing everyone in!

We also are highly organized. We create timelines and deadlines and we meet them.

In terms of skills, we bring in a very diversified education: Federica studied corporate communication and worked in fundraising for NGOs for years, which makes her our expert in media and outreach. Diana studied international relations in four different languages, which means I’m responsible for keeping our content and vision alive, and also for translating the play from German to English with the assistance of bilingual American colleagues.

Lastly, through our time at the Stella Adler Studio and our work in theaters all around the city, we can rely on a network of highly skilled theater professionals from all disciplines, who are supporting us along the way.

We think that your contribution, combined with our experience, professional network, and love for the theater, will enable us to successfully realize this project. Here, the most important ingredient is YOU.

Without a challenge there is no growth. That’s why we invite you to trust and believe in us and in this play the same way we do. Let’s grow together. Let’s bring Sophie’s story to life, together. Let’s defend and celebrate our democracies, together.  

If we get 300 people to contribute $40, we already reach our goal. Be one of them and contribute today!

What are other ways you can help?

If you can’t contribute today, there are other great ways you can help us.

Share this campaign through the Indiegogo share tools.

Share this campaign on your Facebook and Instagram account.

Email your friends about it.

Spread the love, share the story, and of course, come see the show this summer!

Anything helps and we deeply appreciate your commitment and contribution in any shape and form.

 

In gratefulness and humility, AvrenimCreatives, aka

Federica Rangel

Diana Westphal

story:
Familial Movers / Foreign Stories researches the boundaries of movement within virtual reality filmmaking, and elicits empathy for the experience of foreignness. Wampler’s research into the translation of dancing bodies into first person point of view film, allows the participant to feel as if they themselves are the performer. Each collaborator/performer working on the project has had their own experience with foreignness, whether that be feeling foreign in a different country, in their own hometown, or within their own bodies. These oral narratives inspired a series of choreographic duets which physicalize their experiences to be embodied by the visitor/participant. While the curated, virtual reality experience allows for a large amount of physical embodiment, this project also aims to reduce resistance to foreign people, places, and situations by allowing the viewer to realize that, while in different capacities, the experience of foreignness is unavoidable and universal. The piece was first presented at the Hind Gallery in Richmond, VA funded by a 2018/2019 VCUarts Undergraduate Research Grant.

At Dusklit Interactive Art Festival, the participant can not only “try on” a dancing body, but empathize with them and dive into the world they’ve created through speech, sound, and kinesthetic space. With one to three participants embodying different dancers at the same time, the participants’ movement around the space creates a new performance of the piece in and of itself which can be observed from the outside visitor.

If you're unable to donate, please spread the word to others who might be interested in attending or supporting!

story:
The Story

THE ARTIST = a graduate from the #1 Historically Black College in America, Spelman College [in Atlanta, GA] + a B.S. in Mathematics + an innate ability to analyze, constantly + a desire to create and teach + an M.F.A in Acting.

The above equation is ME... in a nutshell!! I recognized, while attending a prestigious graduate level summer program before my Senior Year, that although I had a natural gift and enjoyed Math, there was no longer a desire to pursue it as a career.  I had been interested in Theater since High School, however I wasn't sure it was more than a hobby until...Spelman.  I loved being on stage, which helped me conclude... I wanted to be in Actor, it was that simple. Thus, my Senior Year, at Spelman, was not only a year of discovery but also a year of growth.  After graduating in May of 2005, I decided that I would dedicate the coming year to honing my craft and preparing for Graduate school.  And in that year off, I participated as a Performance Intern at one of Atlanta's prominent Theater Companies and was coached by one of my Professors, Crystal A. Dickinson.  She not only supported me but invested her time and dedication to ensuring my success.  And thus, I graduated from The New School for Drama in 2009 with my M.F.A in Acting.  So as a well-rounded individual who understands the demands and challenges of one's craft, I bring this play, CHAIN, to you.  I welcome this project with the same fervor I welcomed acting into my life.  SO Bring IT ON!

WHAT =  the play, CHAIN + the artist, Me + the director, Crystal.

I first discovered the play, CHAIN, at Spelman College. The Drama Department was paying homage to the playwright, Pearl Cleage, by performing her plays during that school year.  Crystal directed two of them, CHAIN and Late Bus to Mecca.  She initially asked me to audition for the role of Rosa Jackson [in CHAIN] but I was unable to, due to Graduate school auditions... funny how things work out:)  But what I loved and appreciated about this play, when I saw the closing night's performance, was its grittiness and realism.  The fact that this story was told through one person's perspective, a 16-year-old girl, was [and is] incredible; and its connection and relevance to my life was undeniable.  This story hit very close to home, with drug abuse being something that I've dealt with in my own family.   Therefore it was not only a personal story for me but an issue for my community on a grand scale.  Because of that, I've always wanted to perform this play but, frankly, doing a one-person show was a fear of mine.  However, I am currently at a place personally and in my career where I want to conquer my fears.  I want to embrace this year living my life faithfully and fearlessly.  Thus, I am bringing this play to the stage, while addressing the universal themes of addiction and peer pressure, the accessibility to drugs in major metropolitan cities, and the impact of drugs in families, and most importantly its youth.  I believe that drugs often accelerate the development and maturity of a child, it almost robs them of their innocence and naivete.  This play will bring that idea to the forefront and face the community as a whole to reevaluate how our actions and choices affect our future generations.  This topic is relative and I'm grateful for the opportunity to attack this material and, not to mention, how I LOVE having my dear friend, teacher, and mentor, Crystal, directing it:)  I guarantee that all who experience this production, will empathize with the power of addiction and how drugs can affect a community on a sensitive level when it involves the children.      

 

WHERE =  4 performances (June 9th, 10th, 11th @ 8pm and June 12th @ 7pm) + Theatrelab (137 West 14th Street, New York, NY 10011). 

This professional production will tackle material that is challenging and poignant and be used for the general audience as well as educational and community outreach purposes targeting youth groups, summer programs, and schools.  CHAIN will be used as a creative way to discuss and explore the power of drug abuse and the affect it has on the youth of our community.  A talk back discussion will take place after one of the performances and 10% of the ticket sales will be donated to an organization that embraces drug awareness and facilitates proper intervention for families affected by addiction.    

 

THE IMPACT

This production will not only stand as a theatrical performance, it will serve as a platform that will inform and touch many.  The pertinence is unique and the impact will be incredible.  Your participation in this project can help us get one step closer to enabling the community's awareness of the impact drugs have in our neighborhoods and in our families.  It will get us closer to taking drugs off the streets and out of the hands of our youth... the future.  So help make a difference! 



THE NEED 

Ok so where is your money going, you ask!? LOL! Well.... all contributions will be used towards the specific financial obligations of producing and performing this show.  This includes renting the theater space, Set/Set Design (furniture, building, etc...), Props, Costumes, Lighting/Sound Design and Operator, Marketing/Publicity (fliers, promotion/press kits, mailings/invites), Photography, Staffing, Supplemental Fundraising Events, Transportation (moving set pieces to and from the theater space), and Legalities (royalty rights for the show).  If the necessary funds are not raised, this production will have to be postponed until we have what's needed to make it as poignant and provocative as it has the potential to be.  And, for those who choose to donate there are PERKS! YAY!!!


Questions?? Send to CHAINtheplay@gmail.com.


PLEASE PASS THE WORD ABOUT THIS SHOW!  WITH A COMMUNITY EFFORT A CHANGE CAN HAPPEN! So share this production on your Facebook, Twitter, and/or other online accounts! Thanks so much!
story_txt:
The Story
THE ARTIST = a graduate from the #1 Historically Black
College in America, Spelman College [in Atlanta, GA] + a B.S. in Mathematics +
an innate ability to analyze, constantly + a desire to create and teach + an M.F.A in Acting.
The above equation is ME... in a nutshell!! I recognized,
while attending a prestigious graduate level summer program before my Senior Year, that although I had a natural gift and enjoyed Math, there was no
longer a desire to pursue it as a career.  I had been interested in Theater since High School, however I wasn't sure it was more than a hobby until...Spelman.  I loved being on stage, which helped me conclude... I wanted to be in Actor, it
was that simple. Thus, my Senior Year, at Spelman, was not only a
year of discovery but also a year of growth.  After graduating in May of 2005, I decided that I would dedicate the coming year to honing my craft
and preparing for Graduate school. 
And in that year off, I participated as a Performance Intern at one of Atlanta's prominent Theater Companies and was coached by one of my Professors,
Crystal A. Dickinson.  She not only supported me but invested
her time and dedication to ensuring my success.  And thus, I graduated from The New School for Drama in 2009
with my M.F.A in Acting.  So as a
well-rounded individual who understands the demands and challenges of one's
craft, I bring this play, CHAIN, to you.  I welcome this project with the same fervor I welcomed acting into my
life.  SO Bring IT ON!

WHAT =   the play, CHAIN + the artist, Me + the director,
Crystal.I first discovered the play, CHAIN, at Spelman College. The
Drama Department was paying homage to the playwright, Pearl Cleage, by
performing her plays during that school year.  Crystal directed two of them, CHAIN and Late Bus to
Mecca.  She initially asked me to
audition for the role of Rosa Jackson [in CHAIN] but I was unable to, due to
Graduate school auditions... funny how things work out:)  But what I loved and appreciated about this
play, when I saw the closing night's performance, was its grittiness and realism. 
The fact that this story was told through one person's perspective, a
16-year-old girl, was [and is] incredible; and its connection and relevance to my life was undeniable.  This story hit very close to home, with drug abuse being something that
I've dealt with in my own family.   Therefore it was not only a personal story for me but an issue for my
community on a grand scale.  Because of that, I've
always wanted to perform this play but, frankly, doing a one-person show was a fear of
mine.  However, I am currently at a place
personally and in my career where I want to conquer my fears.  I want to embrace this year living
my life faithfully and fearlessly.  Thus, I am bringing this play to
the stage, while addressing the universal themes of
addiction and peer pressure, the accessibility to drugs in major metropolitan cities, and the impact of drugs in families, and most importantly its youth.  I believe that drugs often accelerate the development
and maturity of a child, it almost robs them of their innocence and
naivete.  This play will bring that
idea to the forefront and face the community as a whole to reevaluate how our
actions and choices affect our future generations.  This topic is relative and I'm grateful for the opportunity to
attack this material and, not to mention, how I LOVE having my dear friend, teacher, and
mentor, Crystal, directing it:)  I
guarantee that all who experience this production, will empathize with the
power of addiction and how drugs can affect a community on a sensitive level
when it involves the children.       
 
WHERE =  4 performances (June 9th, 10th, 11th @ 8pm and June
12th @ 7pm) + Theatrelab (137 West 14th Street, New York, NY 10011).  


This professional production will tackle material that is challenging 
and poignant and be used for the general audience as well as educational
 and community outreach purposes targeting youth groups, summer 
programs, and schools.  CHAIN 
will be used as a creative way to discuss and explore the power of drug 
abuse and the affect it has on the youth of our community.  A talk back 
discussion will take place after one of the performances and 10% of the 
ticket sales will be donated to an organization that embraces drug 
awareness and facilitates proper intervention for families affected by 
addiction.    

  
THE IMPACT
This production will not only stand as a theatrical performance, it will serve as a platform that will inform and touch many.  The pertinence is unique and the impact will be incredible.  Your participation in this project can help us get one step closer to enabling the community's awareness of the impact drugs have in our neighborhoods and in our families.  It will get us closer to taking drugs off the streets and out of the hands of our youth... the future.  So help make a difference!  

THE NEED  

Ok so where is your money going, you ask!? LOL! Well.... all contributions will be used towards the specific financial obligations of producing and performing this show.  This includes renting the theater space, Set/Set Design (furniture, building, etc...), Props, Costumes, Lighting/Sound Design and Operator, Marketing/Publicity (fliers, promotion/press kits, mailings/invites), Photography, Staffing, Supplemental Fundraising Events, Transportation (moving set pieces to and from the theater space), and Legalities (royalty rights for the show).  If the necessary funds are not raised, this production will have to be postponed until we have what's needed to make it as poignant and provocative as it has the potential to be.  And, for those who choose to donate there are PERKS! YAY!!!
Questions?? Send to CHAINtheplay@gmail.com.

PLEASE PASS THE WORD ABOUT THIS SHOW!  WITH A COMMUNITY EFFORT A CHANGE CAN HAPPEN! So share this production on your Facebook, Twitter, and/or other online accounts! Thanks so much!

story:
The Réjane Project is based on the life and work of Réjane, the most lauded comedienne of the Belle Époque. Last fall, director Christopher Sivertsen and I (writer/creator Ilana Turner) led a workshop (funded entirely by private donations) in L.A. with musical collaborator (and Réjane’s great-great granddaughter) Adrien Reju, and a company of actors. The workshop culminated in a showing of scenes, movement and music. 


Having found Réjane’s story as a friend of her descendants, I was taken with how ahead of her time Réjane was and how she struggled to balance her passion for work and her children. As an artist with a daughter myself, Réjane inspires and fascinates me. Her family has given me unfettered access to photos, letters and archives. I’ve also made good use of the French and American libraries and visited the theaters Réjane played and her country home in France. Reading the plays she performed, it became clear that for Réjane, life did equal art.


Text from Réjane’s plays that parallels events from her own life has been carefully culled and edited. The Réjane Project is a collage: an actor could be speaking lines from an exisiting Réjane play, text I’ve written or a combination thereof, so that ‘onstage’ and ‘backstage’ worlds crash together - just as they did in Réjane’s life. For more on the project, please visit www.rejaneproject.com


This month, Dramaturg Tonia N. Sutherland and I have been invited to present a fancy paper on how our research fueled the creation of an original work at an even fancier academic conference. We are also in the final round for an NYCWAM Collaboration Award. Also this month, Christopher and I are ‘retreating’ to work on the script in preparation for the next phase: a full workshop to make The Réjane Project a stylized, physical, textual, period and modern sensory feast. This $999 is the last chunk we need to fund our 'retreat' and the travel expenses to present the research paper in Seattle.


Donations of any amount are (so very) appreciated and have the power to keep The Réjane Project moving onward and upward. The Réjane Project is a sponsored projected of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions in behalf of The Réjane Project may be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by the law. In addition to our eternal gratitude, all supporters will be listed in the program, when the show premieres, as members of our:


LEGION OF DONORS

Chevalier (Knight) $500+ 

Officier (Officer) $250 - $499

Commandeur (Commander) $100 - $249 

Grand Officier (Grand Officer) $40 - $99

Grand Croix (Grand Cross) $5 - $39   


VIP perks will be distributed when the show is staged, if applicable given the perk. VIP perks lessen how much of your contribution is tax-deductible so, while we are thrilled to provide them, you can turn them down to receive a deduction for the full amount of your donation if you must donate at https://www.fracturedatlas.org/donate/2791


Donations from people like you have made the continued growth of this project a reality. We are *this* close to being established enough to apply for big-league grants. Your support makes that next step possible.

story:
What


The very talented Katie Northlich with her show "The Panic Diaries" was selected to take part in the prestigious New York Fringe Festival 2011 which ran from 8/12 to 8/28.


Over 900 shows apply every year for only 200 places in the Fringe and 'The Panic Diaries' was one of them.  Being selected for the Fringe was a unique, focused opportunity for Katie to demonstrate her talent.

Katie is the 4 time winning National Monologue Champion. The eight monologues which comprise the “Diaries” were written by her and were performed during her and have won National Awards.   She is currently a senior instructor at the New York Film Academy.

The Impact

The Panic Diaries was awarded one of the prime venus for this year's Fringe Festival, based on the Fringe Committee's preview of the show, and upon Katie's reputation within the Performance community of New York City.

What We Need

We need to cover all show expenses for The Panic Diaries to move forward including: producing fee, publicity relations which include press releases, postcards, clothing for crew, mailings; crew fees, tech fees, transportations fees, and set expenses.

Note:  Any amount at all gladly accepted!  The site defaults to $100. Not tax deductible.

Please see thepanicdiaries.com for more info.  Also refer to FringeNYC website, fringenyc.org. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Follow us on Twitter and if you're in New York, go see the show!!

=======

About the Show

THE PANIC DIARIES is a combination of award-winning monologues and essays written by Katie Northlich that have received critical acclaim in New York City.  In THE PANIC DIARIES, Northlich embarks on a journey to examine her existence through “flat-out funny” characters until she’s forced to face her greatest fear: herself.  She leads her audience through a story that’s at once both universal and personal, dissecting her relationship with panic.  “We feel her pain.  Her eternal despair and hope are palpable,” NYtheatre.com has written of Northlich’s solo performance.

Preview: link ;

About Katie

Katie Northlich is an unprecedented Four-Time National Manhattan Monologue Slam Champion.  She presently has a regular Monologue show at The PIT, The PIT-OLOGUES, and she is debuting her explosive new collection of monologue and essay, *The Panic Diaries, at the 15th Annual NY International Fringe Festival in August, 2011.  

She teaches Monologue and Solo Performance at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe and is on faculty at the New York Film Academy.  

She is a commissioned monologue writer and was recently a full Meisner Scholarship student with JoAnna Beckson Studios, NYC.  

Credits:
NEW YORK: One, Two, Whatever You Do (The Actors' Studio;) Twelfth Night (Princeton Repertory;) And Then Like Ophelia (Princeton Repertory;) Arturo's Window (The York Theatre.)  TV: The Food Network, Discovery Channel, VH1, AMC, Virgin Mobile and the Mid-Atlantic Sports Network.  COMEDY/SOLO PERFORMANCE/INTERNATIONAL:  Stand Up NY, New York Comedy Club, Caroline's on Broadway, Upright Citizen's Brigade, The People's Improv Theatre, Undergound At Gene Frankel, The Makor, Stage Left Studio, The Bowery Poetry Club, Gotham City Improv, Parkside Lounge, The Nuyorican Poets Cafe, Comix, Don't Tell Mama's, and La Sala Mirador. As a dancer Katie toured Europe, and was a recipient of a Jazz Dance award from the prestigious Interlochen Arts Conservatory in Interlochen, MI.  UC Irvine: BA, Drama. www.thepanicdiaries.com

Some Reviews

NYTHEATRE.COM: Katie Northlich directs herself in Bethany Larsen's Manhattan: Greater and Greater Things, a heartfelt monologue about the ever-changing face of the Big Apple. Northlich is extremely comfortable and flat-out funny in this bittersweet diatribe of a lifelong love/hate relationship with her city. The language of the piece and the confident timing of the delivery are in perfect sync. The speaker is a native New Yorker. We feel her pain. Her eternal despair and hope is palpable.

THE PRINCETON PACKET: Katie Northlich is wonderful... her comedic talents readily apparent. Look for great things in her future.

MANHATTAN MONOLOGUE SLAM: Actress Molly Shannon sat front row center in New York City's latest MMSlam... judges huddle and go with their gut instinct... after a short deliberation Katie Northlich was awarded the win in a show that featured everything with material from Shakespeare to George C. Wolfe's The Colored .

JESTERJOURNAL.COM REVIEW: A talented creator of comic characters, Northlich makes each of them very different people, displaying a clear skill at crafting multiple personas.  As a result, "Character Forum: A Thesis" becomes more than just a showcase, but a comedic work as developed as any comedic play with multiple actors and a playwright's script would be.

story:
Hello Apronites!


The Apron Theatre Co. has all sorts of projects in the works.
Community service events, cabarets, and three (that's right, three!) productions of new plays planned for the spring. 
For these ventures to thrive, we need the support of our community.
There are a bunch of ways that you can help us (you're doing some of them already). 

We need:


Emotional support
Logistical support
Spiritual support
AND
Monetary support

Our community is at the heart of our organization. It's due to your support that we have continue to grow and succeed.

Thank you!
The Apron Theatre Co.

story:
What Is Girly Girl?

Hello! My name is Lily Chrones and I use they/them pronouns. I am the Co-Founder/Artistic Director of The Euphoria Theatre Project, a new company that aims to highlight the LGBTQIA+ experience by putting intersectionality at the forefront of everything we do. I am also the creator of my one person show, Girly Girl!

The show is a mixed media performance which I first conceived as a film for my senior capstone in 2020. Unfortunately due to COVID-19 I wasn't able to perform Girly Girl on the stage and had to completely reimagine it to be shared remotely.

My collaborators and I are thrilled that we get an opportunity to finally bring Girly Girl to life on the fringe stage, but we need your help!

 

What We Need & What You Get!

In order to bring Girly Girl to the fringe stage, we need your support! With your generous donations we will be able to:

  • Pay our creative team for all of the hard work they are doing.
  • Cover our venue and travel costs.
  • Cover our costume, wig, prop and scenery expenses.
  • Cover marketing and advertising fees.

We crunched the numbers and found that the lowest amount we can feasibly ask for is $4,500 to bring you the absolute best! Any donation at all would be greatly appreciated. The following donation tiers receive special appreciation:

  • $15 - You get your name in our virtual program!
  • $25 - You get your name in our virtual program plus super cute package of lilypops (lollipops) designed by me!
  • $50 - You get all of that plus an exclusive link to the filmed performance.
  • $75 - You get all of that plus a signed Girly Girl poster by me!
  • $100+ You get all of that plus you get to be an executive producer for Girly Girl.

 

The Impact

As you may know, there is so much theatre that centers around queer and transgender tragedy and I strive to create work that highlights queer and transgender joy and resistance. Through all of the art that I create I seek to abolish the binary and create new ways of storytelling that encompass and highlight fluid identities, ideally sparking critical conversations that lead to actionable change. 

Girly girl is a story about perseverance, joy, innocence, loss, love, passion, denial, acceptance, confusion, and clarity. I want anyone to be able to watch this show and say “Wow I do that!” Or “I know someone like that!” My goal is not only for people to learn what being non-binary is, but to discover that we are more than our gender identity. We are complex, unique individuals who exist next door even if you don’t know we do, and come in all shapes and sizes.

Just like gender cannot be assumed, life cannot be planned and Girly Girl highlights what happens when a child influenced by social media plans their life before even knowing who they are. More than anything Girly Girl is meant to tell my story, so maybe I can inspire people to think differently about the gender roles and expectations we place on children, or to simply think about us non-binary folk at all.

By supporting Girly Girl you are helping uplift marginalized voices by bringing this queer coming-of-age story to the stage. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position where you can donate but still want to support us please consider following us on social media and giving us a follow, like and share! 

  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/theeuphoriatheatreproject
  • Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/theeuphoriatheatrepro...
  • Website: theeuphoriatheatreproject.com (updates coming soon)

Thank you so much for your attention, your support means everything to us!

story:
We’re All In This Together

“It has always struck me that what New Jersey really needs is a good, all-purpose arts web site, with active social media engagement.”  

That's what one prominent entertainment writer from a major newspaper in New Jersey recently said to me... It's also my goal for New Jersey Stage.  About 7 years ago I ran a print publication called Upstage Magazine that covered the arts throughout Central New Jersey.  That publication covered the arts in ways the mainstream media couldn't afford to.  In the years that have passed, more and more newspapers and magazines have cut their staffs with those covering the arts among the first to go.  I believe in the arts, and believe the arts deserves and relies upon media coverage.  I'm plunging back into covering the arts full-time again and hope that some of the artists, theatre companies, and performing arts centers that will benefit from that coverage help contribute to this campaign.  We're all in this together.

This time around, I'm cutting the cord from print.  Despite being a long-time print guy, I believe it's time to go digital.  I'm excited at the possibilities of including audio, video, and interactive features inside a magazine. I look forward to working with social media to have articles and complete issues travel around the world and reach more people than any print publication ever could.  And I'm excited to give arts organizations and artists their opportunity to shine again.

Digital publishing also allows me to keep my costs down, which means I'm able to offer great advertising opportunities for extremely low costs.  Ad prices will start at just $25 for two weeks advertising online or an 1/8 page ad in the digital magazine. 

That's why I'm saying that we're all in this together.  By helping me launch this new digital magazine and website, you're helping artists and art organizations throughout the state.  Whether you are an artist or you enjoy the arts (going to a show, a concert, a poetry reading, etc.), you'll benefit from New Jersey Stage.


  Click here for info on the old magazine...

Why We're Doing This Campaign and

Where The Money Will Go

I know digital magazines are something new and not everyone will understand why we're abandoning print, but I believe digital publishing isn't the future, it's the present.  Digital is the perfect complement to social media and is a great way to showcase the arts (from backstage interviews to music videos and photo galleries).  Unfortunately, going digital has its own challenges.  The main challenge is simply letting people know we exist.

When I published Upstage Magazine, I had dozens of those boxes on busy street corners where people could pick up an issue.  That was incredible exposure 24 hours a day -- sort of like a little billboard in a downtown area.  I can accomplish the same thing with online marketing.  In fact, I believe I can build an audience in even less time with a digital magazine than a print one if enough marketing is done. So, marketing is where the majority of campaign money will go.

Content is the second place.  As a writer, I believe in getting paid for my work and I want to pay writers as well.  Contributions to this campaign will help me build a nice staff of freelance writers to keep the magazine content at a very high level.  The better the content, the more readers we'll have.

The third area is with the various costs associated with digital publishing itself.  These include special subscriptions to software, web hosting, credit card transaction subscriptions, and design costs.  These costs may a fraction of what print publishing costs are, but they add up as well.


The Long Story

We have plenty of great incentives to offer fans of the arts from tickets to upcoming plays and concerts to autographed books and CDs to New Jersey Stage t-shirts.  There are special advertising packages for arts organizations and businesses as well. And if you're interested in hearing the whole story, please read on...

New Jersey and the arts go together… they really do.  If there’s one thing New Jersey should be proud of it is the artists and dreamers who grow up and live throughout the state.  We also have an impressive list of events taking place every week from small clubs and theaters to performing arts centers and basketball arenas, the problem is keeping up with it all.  And it’s a growing problem…

Newspapers and magazines throughout the country are cutting staff in order to reduce expenses, and media within New Jersey is following suit as well.  Unfortunately, coverage for the arts is usually among the first places cut.  Two decades ago, newspapers regularly covered community theatre productions.  Today, community theaters are simply ignored and theatre fans should consider themselves lucky if they find coverage of the State’s many Equity companies in the mainstream media.  Coverage for theatre (and really all of the arts) is generally found among bloggers who once were paid reporters, but are now reporting simply as a hobby.  

If professional theatre in a region near Broadway is difficult for the media to cover, what chance do you think dance companies or poetry readings or even rock and roll clubs featuring largely unknown, up-and-coming artists have for coverage? There are some media outlets that still have writers covering these beats on occasion, but far less often than before. The arts just isn’t profitable enough for the mainstream media to cover.  Their pages cost too much to print to give coverage to venues and artists who don’t advertise with them.

This is why there is a need for New Jersey Stage.  I’m an old-school publisher who believes it is time to cut the cord with print.  For roughly five years, I ran a print newspaper called Upstage Magazine that covered the arts throughout Central New Jersey.  We covered art, music, film, theatre, comedy, dance, poetry, literature and more.  Many times, we provided the first coverage these artists ever received.  In some cases, the only coverage.  This was because we cared about the arts more than we cared about covering something that would guarantee an ad sale.  In the end, this approach was vindicated with three Asbury Park Music Awards for Top Music Journalist and one for Top Music Publication, becoming the only publication other than The Aquarian to ever receive that award.

I still love the way a print magazine looks, but I believe the traditional business model doesn’t work anymore.  I’ll miss the smell of fresh ink when I pick up the papers, but won’t miss breaking my back delivering the issues.  After my time with Upstage, I went on to cover the automotive industry but the arts organizations kept sending me their press releases and asking for coverage of their shows and events.  So I started a website called NewJerseyStage.com and published their releases as a hobby.  Every now and then when I had time I would add some features or artist interviews.  Six years later, I noticed that the website was beginning to attract a very strong number of visitors — tens of thousands each month.  I decided it was worth it to return to the arts and give it another shot.  I’m essentially bringing back Upstage as a purely digital magazine.  And, I believe its time to go digital.

Digital magazines have many advantages over print.  For one thing, they are a lot less expensive to produce; they’re far better for the environment, without physical copies to recycle or that get thrown away; they offer the use of audio, video, animation, and photo galleries; and, perhaps most importantly, they are the perfect complement to social media.

Just imagine someone reading an article they like in a digital magazine.  With the click of a button, they can simply email a link or the actual magazine to a friend.  They can post the link on social media sites like Facebook or Twitter and help spread the word to thousands instantly.  Articles can literally circle the globe — within a few minutes, more people could read that article and get copies of the magazine than you could ever print!

One prominent entertainment writer from a major newspaper in the state recently told me, “It has always struck me that what New Jersey really needs is a good, all-purpose arts web site, with active social media engagement.”  

That’s exactly what I’m trying to do with New Jersey Stage.  My goal is to create a monthly digital magazine and daily website that promotes the arts and utilizes social media in ways the mainstream media simply doesn’t understand.  The website currently adds articles and news every day to go along with the largest arts event calendar in the state.  Both the website and magazine have been designed with tablets and mobile phones in mind.  Users can easily add events to their phone or computer calendar, email event listings and articles to friends, and read everything for free.  That last part is something you may have noticed is changing within the mainstream media.  More and more newspapers are allowing people to only read a few articles for free each month, hoping to force people into subscriptions.  That’s the old school mentality and it is what is killing the industry.  It also winds up hurting arts organizations who now have less readers than before.

Anybody that has ever worked in publishing has always known that the future was online and digital.  Unfortunately, too many people in the industry continue to fight that inevitability.  If you are a fan of the arts — if you enjoy going to live events or are an artist yourself — please make a contribution to this campaign.  New Jersey Stage has a plan to help promote the arts and thrive in the new media era.  The website and magazine will offer advertising at rates that arts organizations can afford and provide the coverage they need.  Every contribution is greatly appreciated and will help us successfully launch a new digital magazine that can change the way arts is covered in New Jersey. With your help, it will.

Other Ways You Can Help

Trust me, I know times are tough and I understand if you're unable to make a financial contribution right now.  But if you believe in the concept behind New Jersey Stage please help spread the word.  I'm proud to have so many great arts organizations donate tickets to us for this cause.  It shows me that these organizations welcome our return.

Please post the link to this page on your Facebook or Twitter pages and tell your friends.  And please, keep supporting the arts wherever you live...

story:
Me & My Monkey Redux: The Canadian Tour

Hello Everyone:

I am Bradley Spann and I am raising funds to tour my show, Me & My Monkey, across Canada. I am one of five international winners of the Canadian Association of Fringe Festivals (CAFF) Lottery. Each year the CAFF Lottery selects five Canadian acts and five international acts. Winning the CAFF Lottery is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.  I will now be performing my one-man show at fringe festivals in the following cities: Montreal, Ottawa, Edmonton, Calgary, Winnipeg, and San Francisco. Yes, San Francisco because it is also a member of the Canadian Association of Fringe Festivals.

How I Became A Monkey's Uncle

Last year I wrote, produced, and performed my show in the Boulder International Fringe Festival. Me & My Monkey is an autobiographical story about growing up a little south of South Central, Los Angeles in 1970’s with four sisters, a brother, divorced parents, exotic pets, and comic books. I got a grant to produce my show and I ran a successful Indie Go Go campaign to cover costs as well. 

This was my first time writing and producing a show. I received plenty of positive audience reviews on the fringe website and from the other fringe artists who saw my show. It was a humbling experience and very encouraging. I am still grateful to my audiences and my peer for their support. 

Right after my show closed I enter the CAFF Lottery. I entered hoping I would win. Once I applied I never thought of it again. A month later I got a call informing me I had WON! WHAT? HUH? I was shocked and delighted. I would be touring my one-man show across Canada!

How You Can Be A Monkey's Aunt Or Uncle

As I wrote above The CAFF Lottery is a once in a lifetime opportunity. For the past few years I have attended and performed in fringe festivals. In the process I have met artists who make their living touring shows to fringe festivals in Canada and across the globe. This has since become a dream of mine to follow in their footsteps. This is where you come. I seeking to raise $10,000 to cover the following expenses:

  • Theatre fees - A Monkey needs places to perform.
  • Director fee - A Monkey needs direction.

  • Travel expenses - A Monkey has got to travel.
  • Food - A Monkey has got to eat.
  • Accommodations - A Monkey has to sleep.
  • Promotion - A Monkey has to talk about his Monkey self.

Thus far I have raised $3000 in donations. This includes a frequent flyer ticket, help with  setting up a blog, consultation on promoting my show, poster design, help in launching this Indie Go Go campaign, and a couple of nights stay on a sofa in San Francisco. I am also applying for a traveling grant which could net me $2500.

Other Ways You Can Help A Monkey

If you are short on funds but would still like to help here are ways you can:

  • Frequent flyer miles
  • Accommodations
  • Buying tickets to see my show
  • Telling your friends to see my show
  • Food

Me & My Monkey thank you for taking the time to look at my campaign. I will see you in Canada!

--Bradley Spann

story:
"Brooklyn Boy" can continue to inspire audiences with your help! 

Inspired by the life true stories of Steven Prescod, "Brooklyn Boy" is a riveting, and emotionally impactful, one man show that tells a coming of age redemption story, as he journey's from young boy to manhood.

But Steven is just one of many young people, who have an important, and inspiring, story to share. Through supporting his performance, and workshops with young people through The CityKids Foundation, our goal is to inspire other young people across the country. Through cutting edge arts and leadership training, CityKids can allow other Brooklyn boys, Bronx boys, Queens girls… young people all across the city, the country, the world, to have an opportunity to turn personal growth into opportunities for social change through the arts.

Steven was presented the opportunity to avoid prison by taking part in an alternative to prison program that placed him at The CityKids Foundation, a nonprofit youth organization with an arts component that introduced him to the world of acting. This is where Steven met his mentor Artistic Director Moises Roberto Belizario who took Steven under his tutelage and developed his stories into a gripping 90 minutes tale of love, family, the streets, gang violence and self-acceptance. 

The CityKids Foundation is very proud to support "Brooklyn Boy", and to kick of it's 30 year celebration continuing the work of supporting young people in recognizing the power of their voice.

Your support will help fund the continued development, opportunities to workshop his performance with audiences, and production costs for Brooklyn Boy in order to get his amazing work to a larger audience, and a portion of your contribution will help The CityKids Foundation to continue to help the voices of young people be heard.

CityKids' plan is to stipend, and begin developing youth trainers in January, to hit schools in all 5 boroughs and beyond - empowering these schools with a safe space model and arts/leadership workshops by February 1st. We're continuing the work CityKids' has done for the past three decades, empowering young people to inspire each other to positively impact their lives, their communities, and the world. 

“When ever I perform this work I only wish that I reach that young person that may be drifting down that path, and that I inspire them to chose themselves over the streets” - Steven Prescod

If you have other ways you would like to help, just share & spread the word (it's the Brooklyn way), or visit www.citykids.com to let us know other ways you would like to help, but please remember every dollar gets us closer to out goal!

story:
Hi I’m Meg Wolfe. I’m a choreographer based in Los Angeles, and I am raising funds to support the creation of my latest project, New Faithful Disco. 

The amazing collaborative team includes dancers taisha paggett and Marbles (Rae Shao-Lan), composer Maria de los Angeles “Cuca” Esteves, and scenic/costume design by Gregory Barnett.

ALL donations directly support this creative team as we move into the next phase of New Faithful Disco, leading to the premiere in fall 2015. After our initial explorations and a recent work-in-progress showing at the Live Arts Exchange Festival, we are ready to dive back into rehearsals. Right now, we have a few exciting opportunities coming up!

  • December: a week-long creative residency at REDCAT in Los Angeles, CA
  • January 9 & 10: in-progress performances at the FRESH Festival, San Francisco, CA
  • February: one-month residency, Performance Works NorthWest. Portland, OR

My goal is to raise $6,500  to help to cover the expenses for the collaborating artists—for their participation in the creation process, and to travel to the FRESH festival in San Francisco and the residency in Portland, while helping move this project towards its premiere. 

It's an important stage in this project—and a rapidly approaching one!

Your donation brings meaningful compensation to artists who are forging exchange in the face of real economic barriers.

I am thrilled about these invitations and the opportunities they bring to my artistic process, as well as to my ongoing mission to connect West Coast artists in dialogue and performance. New Faithful Disco is our vehicle for sustenance and progress—give us a little stardust for our disco ball!

Please share our message, help us get on the road, and carry it along.

Yours in the boogie,
Meg Wolfe

+ + + 

More info about NFD can be found here: 
http://showboxla.org/2014/10/22/new-faithful-disco-2/

and a Q&A on the creation process, here:
https://anotherrighteoustransfer.wordpress.com/2014/09/22/meg-wolfe-new-faithful-disco-bootleg-theater-september-13-15-2014-qa-with-the-artist/
