and a Q&A on the creation process, here:https://anotherrighteoustransfer.wordpress.com/2014/09/22/meg-wolfe-new-faithful-disco-bootleg-theater-september-13-15-2014-qa-with-the-artist/

story:
POP

Prodigal Opera Productions is a non-profit organisation which workshops, produces, and provides outreach for new musical dramas and their interpreters, and which seeks to enrich artistic dialogue through the reanimation of an opera culture in contemporary life.

The Prodigal Opera Theatre

Prodigal Opera Theatre (POT) produces annually, at least one musical theatrical work including opera, classical musical theatre, passion plays, ballet, mixed media, and experimental theatre. In each production, POT endeavours to enrich the local arts culture by providing a perspective which increases understanding of a work, its historical relevance, and contemporary intersubjectivity.

We are debuting the Theatre with our "Exposition" on April 25th. The night will include scenes from operas which represent the unique and formative approach POP takes to the repertoire, including :
  • J.S. Bach's Saint Matthew Passion
  • Conrad Susa's Transformations
  • Olivier Messiæn's Fin des Temps
We will also showcase POP's workshop arm with a fourth-wall obliterating look at a scene from Frank La Rocca's St Rita (in progress) which we will workshop and refine right before your eyes.

How You Can Help

Exposition Night is POP's salutation to the world of theatre. From this point we will grow and cultivate the dynamic community of opera to produce full productions of the works seen at our event and others like them.

  • The cost to produce this night of dramas is $5,500. This includes the cost of renting our spectacular theatrical space, lighting and technical design, as well as the most important cost, compensating our amazing musicians (yes, the singers, too!) for their hard work and talent.
  • Proceeds from the night's ticket sales go towards funding our Inaugural Season, which promises to be a tour-de-force of innovative and substantial operatic production.
  • Our donors enjoy some wonderful perks, including invitations to special events and even more "behind the scenes" activities. But the greatest reward is of course being a part of the movement to Bring Opera Home, keeping it alive, fresh, vibrant, relevant and central to artistic life.
  • For every dollar we fall short of our goal, we are that much further away from funding our upcoming projects. Sustaining the arts isn't always about a few donors making hefty contributions, sometimes it takes a village, a community of the invested donating whatever they can.

Breakdown : Where Your Money Goes

Through your support, we can produce a marvellous evening's entertainment and edification as well as jumpstart our mission.

  • $2,000 goes towards the rental of our space, including fees and staffing.
  • $1,200 goes towards technical needs such as lighting design and piano tuning.
  • $2,300 (the largest portion) goes towards paying for our talent (singers, the band, rehearsal piano and coaching).
  • Any and all funds in surplus of $5,500 will be added to ticket revenue to provide seed money for our inaugural season.

What Does "Bringing Opera Home" Mean?

Maybe you already love opera, but worry about its financial and/or cultural solubility moving into a future with more and more immediate forms of entertainment?

Maybe you don't know much about opera, but you love music and you love drama, and you are fascinated by how the two meet and mingle?

Maybe you don't really care for opera (all that showmanship, endless singing and silly stories), but suspect that there's a better way of exploring "opera" that means something to you and to society?


Opera, whatever we ultimately define that word to mean, can only continue so long as it is a vital part of our culture. That vitality doesn't just happen, it takes work. It takes education, it takes commitment. And of course, it takes funding. We know opera can seem extravagant, but with the support of the community, opera can become a part of life, a regular ritual and familiar friend.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Iyun Ashani Harrison and I am the artistic director of ASHANI DANCES. Throughout my education at the Juilliard School and Hollins University; my professional career with Dance Theatre of Harlem, Ailey II and Ballet Hispanico; and my teaching at Goucher College and The Ailey School, I have developed a passion for choreography and assisting young dance artists launch their performance careers.

In our Baltimore Debut, ASHANI DANCES will perform at The Baltimore Theatre Project from October 14 - 16, 2016. The company will present Love Me/Leave Me Alone for its Baltimore debut. The concert is a collection of danced vignettes that take inspiration from five Edward Hopper paintings and provides the audience with a voyeuristic glimpse into the lives of seven city dwellers. This year’s concert features young DMV talent with alumni from Baltimore School of the Arts, Goucher College, Governor’s School of the Arts and Virginia Commonwealth University.

Contributing to ASHANI DANCES' campaign will help to underwrite the costs of our theater rental, advertising, production expenses: costume design and construction, musical commission fee, lighting design, technical staff fees and dancer salaries.

What We Need & What You Get

ASHANI DANCES needs to raise $7,000 to cover our production expenses. This is how they break down:

Your gift of $500 will help provide compensation for one (1) of our six (6) dancers who will perform in our concert ($3000).  

Your gift of $1000 or more will contribute to:

Baltimore Theatre Project rental ($3,000)

Publicity: posters, postcards, advertising ($1,000)


WHAT YOU GET!!!!!!!

Give $50 and you will receive a signed copy of the ASHANI DANCES' season poster. 

Give $100 and you will receive a signed season poster, a reserved seat at the opening night performance of ASHANI DANCES' Baltimore Debut and you will be listed as a "Friend" of ASHANI DANCES in the concert program. 

Give $500 and you will receive a signed season poster and season t-shirt. Your name will be listed in the season program as: "Production made possible by a generous donation from (your name here)". Attend one rehearsal of your choosing and a reserved seat at the opening night performance of ASHANI DANCES' third season and you will be listed as a "Gold Donor" in the season program.

Give $1000 or more and you will receive a signed season poster, season t-shirt, attendance to any/all rehearsals and performances of your choosing, an invitation to the season cast party and your name will be listed in the season program as: "Platinum Donor for Ashani Dances" and you will be invited to join the advisory board of ASHANI DANCES!

The Impact

We would like to share some of the positive feedback about ASHANI DANCES' concerts in Seattle prior to relocating to Baltimore.

Alice Kaderlan of The Seattle Times writes, 

"Ashani Dances Is On The Rise ... Harrison, with three very different works. Together, they showcased an artist of diverse talents with sophisticated musical tastes and an understanding of how to use a bare stage to full effect. Appearing at the Broadway Performance Hall, Harrison relied on lighting, rather than expensive sets, to enhance the mood and energy of his ballets. The costumes were simple but effective ..." 
http://seattletimes.com/html/thearts/2023801915_ashanireviewxml.html?syndication=rss

Gabrielle Nomura of Seattle Dances writes,
"The result is a company [Ashani Dances] on par with Seattle’s elite in contemporary dance: Spectrum Dance Theater and Whim W’him,Harrison’s international experience and classical background presents a refreshing niche in Seattle’s contemporary dance market; his technical, virtuosic dancers are appealing to both dance aficionados, as well as the general public." 
http://seattledances.com/2014/06/harrison-helps-dancers-soar-at-ashani/

Ciara McCormack of Seattle Dances writes:
"Harrison’s The Leaves Have Fallen ... lifts and transitions were seamless, a constant connection between the dancers carrying them from one set to the next ... the structure of the piece rose to the surface, highlighting the identities of the characters and reflecting the development of their dialogue. The work’s vocabulary and the magnetic ebb and flow of the dancers’ spatial relationship implied an intimate relationship, which can easily be construed as a depiction of romantic struggle and loss. Harrison stressed in the talk that his mentorship of a younger dancer and the experience of sending him off to a new opportunity inspired the piece. At its heart, Leaves is a tough conversation between two people who love and respect each other, who rely on each other, yet have separate paths to follow." 
http://seattledances.com/2014/05/veteran-dancers-take-seattle-dance-project-home/

Dean Speer of  Critical Dance Forum writes, 

"Not only did Harrison show off what the dancers can do, the dancers showed off his truly excellent dances." 

http://www.ballet-dance.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=37023

Michael Upchurch of the Seattle Times writes,

"Last weekend I described Ashani Dances as "a promising new local dance company." Scratch that. This troupe is exceptionally accomplished, and their showcase of three new works by artistic director Iyun Ashani Harrison is a knockout. Most of the dancers have an affiliation with Cornish College of the Arts where Harrison teaches (some are graduates, some still students). All have strong, agile ballet skills which are given an intoxicating Afro-Caribbean twist in "Artifact," a joyous, sassy, intricate homage to what Harrison calls "the beautiful traditional dances of my childhood in Jamaica." Local composer-percussionist Ben Morrow penned the dance-propulsive score. Sean Rosado and Sam Picart are reasons alone to catch this while you can."

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially but are still interested in helping, here is how you can do so:

Share our campaign on your social media pages.

Volunteer to help us in the front of house on the weekend of the performances by selling company merchandice and handing out programs. 

Volunteer to help us load into, and out of the theater.

Help us publicize our concert.

story:
OUT

OUT is the story of Glen, a 17-year-old who comes out of the closet in Montreal in 1977 at the height of the disco era. Although not yet out to his parents, he learns how to survive in the discos, joins a Gay Youth Group, has awkward romantic entanglements, and then he and his best friends end up at the Gay Pride March in New York City, where their lives are changed forever. There are about twenty-five characters in OUT and they are all played, simultaneously, by Dora Award-nominated actor Greg Campbell. They include Mary Poppins, some of the characters from The Boys In the Band, infamous homophobe Anita Bryant, and one of the Village People!

This show takes place in the early days of gay liberation, and is a hilarious and moving celebration of what it meant to be out in a world that completely shunned LGBTQ people. It is a great way for younger queer people to learn the history of their community, and a visceral reminder for older folks of what it was like when just showing up at a Gay Pride March was an act of courage. It was also the era of hedonism, disco music and fashion, and the beginnings of pride!

The Journey

I wrote OUT because I grew up in the gay discotheques of Montreal, and it was a joyful, golden time that I wanted to commemorate. 

It was produced at the Fringe Festival in 2016, and received great reviews. Then the show was picked up by the Best of the Fringe, and was mentioned in the NOW Fringe Wrap-Up as one of four “Best New Plays” of the Fringe. Due to this success, I wanted to remount the play and knew the ideal venue for it was Buddies In Bad Times. They welcomed us as a guest company in their season and I’m thrilled to be presenting the show in the longest-running LGBTQ theatre in North America. This year is Buddies’ 40th anniversary: the theatre began in 1979, and our play is set in 1977, so it couldn’t be produced in a better place or time.

The Team

Greg Campbell - Writer and Performer
Clinton Walker - Director and Dramaturge
Melissa Cameron - Stage Manager
Steven Lafond - Sound Designer
Hope Thompson - Graphic Designer

Adam Barrett - Projections Designer

The Expenses

We got partial funding, from the Canada Council, but are still far short of the total we need to put on this show. I am producing this show mostly by myself. I am looking for ways to finance the show, while assisting with the social media campaign, rehearsing the play, and all the while working my day job. If we don’t reach our target, we will put whatever donations we get to good use in getting the show on stage.

We need money to pay the six artists and designers a union wage for the four weeks of rehearsal and performance. This is our biggest cost, around $12,000. The rental of the theatre costs about $3300. Rehearsal spaces will cost at least $750, and advertising and social media will be about $1000.

Any donation you can give will be of great benefit to the production of this show, and everyone involved in it. If everyone put in $5, we would reach our goal in no time! Plus check out the perks with each amount!

"LIKE" our Facebook Page and "FOLLOW" our Instagram Page for the latest updates on the show.

story:
NORTH OF MIND w/ DON ROSS
a live contemporary dance and music event 
featuring Carleton U artist-in-residence, DON ROSS

created by Jordan Samonas and Dennis Bass
Friday April 13th | 8 PM
Dominion Chalmers United Church, Ottawa ON
Tickets available here: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/north-of-mind-w-don...

| graphic design by Meaghan Murphy @heymeagh
| campaign video by Zak Aubin @aubinz

We need your help:

With your support we will be able to see our vision realized. Funds will help offset administrative costs such as promotion efforts, studio time, set production, artists honorariums and AV equipment rental.

Where your support goes: 

  • Venue rental & insurance
  • Artist Salaries (Choreographer, Dancers, Graphic Designer, Photographer, Videographer)
  • Lighting Designer and Audio Engineer Salaries
  • Printing Fees (Printing programs, posters, postcards)
  • If we don't reach our goal, we will still use your support! No amount is too small!
     

What the impact is:

  • We will be able to produce our event, cover our costs and pay our artists 
  • You will help us towards our goal of breaking even or perhaps turning a small profit!
  • You will be investing in our creative process and valuing art
  • As small scale producers, with your help we will reach a larger audience in Ottawa
  • You are supporting a fresh, unique, and original live music and dance collaboration

What happens if we don’t meet our fundraising goals:

  • We still produce our show!
  • We don’t pay ourselves (wa-waaaa)
  • We take a loss and we pay costs out of pocket
  • We consider other career options...

Other Ways you can Help:

If contributing to this campaign isn’t a possibility for you, we  understand and hope that you might consider sharing this event with your network.

Ultimately we are interested in producing fresh and unique performance experiences and we want to be a part of a larger movement that values local, grassroots music and dance production. You can support and be a part of our #iheartliveart movement too by using our hashags and sharing our indiegogo page or Facebook event with your friends and family. Tag us on social media! #iheartliveart #northofmind 

As young emerging artists, we aim to provide platform for local, live dance and music events. Our event is a community-based initiative; we cherish contributions from local dancers and musicians, willing to give of themselves on-stage and in rehearsal, and are so grateful for the people willing to get up and out to see and support live art. Your support would be key to our success moving forward and would contribute to a community-positive message that this performance aims to foreground.

We are grateful for the time you have taken to learn more about our project. If you’d like to follow us for more updates, you can find us on social media. We’re always happy to hear from folks should you have any questions or just want to chat about music or dance!

With Gratitude,

Dennis & Jordan

www.dennisbassmusic.com
Facebook:  Jordan Samonas | Dennis Bass 
NORTH OF MIND w/ DON ROSS Facebook Event
Instagram: jsamonas | dennisbassmusic
Email: northofminddance@gmail.com

Tickets: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/north-of-mind-w-don...

story:
This is All Just Temporary will open at the Anacostia Arts Center on Saturday, January 20th  and will run through Sunday, February 10th.  To fully realize this work's layered artistic languages, Convergence Theatre seeks the support of DC Theater patrons and the artistic community through this grassroots campaign. Through this campaign, Convergence Theatre will be able to: 

 - Extend artistic offerings to non-profit organizations devoted to assisting caregivers, persons with disabilities and their families

  - Provide accessible, affordable theater to a wide audience in the DC community (under $20)

- Be able to fully compensate all  the artists/designers/directors working on this project and purchase needed materials.

Past production partnerships demonstrate Convergence Theatre's commitment to community engagement and social justice. Partners such as Domestic Violence Resource Project and Stop Modern Slavery DC were just two organizations that joined with Convergence to activate theater outside the performance.  For This is All Just Temporary, Convergence continues to extend performance into practice, making it possible for everyone to be an active force for change by providing activities and resources. We are excited to be joining forces with the following organizations through our production: 

The Arc of the District of Columbia

The Arc of Northern Virginia

Breaching the Fourth Wall

Art Enables

Nu Sass Productions

Hissing Black Cat Theater / The Den

Bellwether Behavioral Health

Walk One Day In Our Shoes

Anacostia Arts Center

We know that partnerships make it easier for the individual audience member to be a part of the change they see onstage.  We saw this happen with the Raising Our Voices event, our March 2017 community workshop that was a direct outcome from our production of Witch.  Help us be the change we need in the world today!  Donations of any amount are greatly appreciated.  Please also help us share the word - post on social media, share in an email, and join our conversations on our Facebook page.

story: Camp Death Productions is asking for funds for our Fourth World Premiere, Legend of the Weresquirrel!! A campy hilarious send up of the classic Jaws. Every dollar you donate will go straight into costuming our hilarious cast and building a set that will take you to the town of Shellton, Fl where the hungry and dangerous Weresquirrel lurks to wreck havoc on hapless campers and redneck hunters.  We run at the Margo Jones Theatre Jun 17-26 for nine performances. Find us at https://www.facebook.com/CampDeathProductions/

story:
Hello, welcome, and thank you for visiting our fundraising campaign!  

 

About Kelsey Bergstrom Young (Director/Choreographer)

The arts have been the very air I have breathed since birth.  The daughter of a musician and a poet, educated in arts magnet schools, I took to the embodied performing arts by age ten.  I was performing professionally in the theatre by age 11, and by high school was choreographing and directing while singing, dancing, and acting my heart out.  I have a BA in Theatre Arts and Literature from New York's Sarah Lawrence College, and am a short six months (and this project!) away from earning my MFA in Dance:  Creative Practice.  Between my two degrees I took a hiatus from performing, and devoted myself entirely to a prodigiously successful career in the culinary arts.  Art has been my life!

This broad exposure in the realm of expression, and the interdisciplinary nature of my own artistic identity, places me in a unique position to create innovative processes as well as products.

Our Project

I am working with a cast of seven brilliant performers, creating a new process of art-making that walks the line between acting, dance, and personal transformation.  This work will be presented in two performances, a short excerpt at Napa's Lincoln Theatre on January 27, 2017, and in its 30-minute entirety at the first MFA in Dance Festival at Saint Mary's College, on June 17 and 18, 2017.  But this work reaches far beyond these two performances.

This is the work that my entire life has been leading me to do-- yes, making original work to perform and share, but this work is really exploring the potential that artistic process has to heal and transform both he who enacts it, and he who bears witness.  This work takes the disciplines of art, dance, and somatic therapies, traditional dance and acting techniques, creative writing, and improvisation to forge a new path in art-making, and we hope, to reach our audience in new and meaningful ways.  

Your support will provide the means to take our work from the studio and place it on the stage, as well as extend the reach of this creative process to include designers in lighting, costume, sound, and set, as well as the composition of original music.  Most importantly, your support will reimburse our incredible performers for their 10 month devotion to this project and process.

Even if we do not reach our fundraising goal,

every penny that we do raise will be instrumental in actualizing this project.  

Here's a clear break-down of how the stated $8,000. fundraising goal will be used!

- Costume design and construction

- Lighting design

-Original musical composition

-Set design

-Expense reimbursement for cast of seven

The Impact

The successful completion of this project will accomplish so much more than earning me my MFA-- although that is no small thing!  It acts as a major stepping stone on my road to actualizing my purpose in this world, which is to bring more art to more people, to shine light in the dark-- but most importantly, to empower people that by engaging in the creative process, they have the power to shine that light themselves.

Other ways to help!

 

If you are not in a position to pledge financial support, it would be instrumental to our success if you share this campaign with anybody who you think might wish to help!

story:
Please scroll down for more information about BICT Fest 2016 

What is BICT Fest?

The Bangkok International Children’s Theatre Festival 2016 (BICT Fest) is Thailand’s first international performing arts festival for young people. Our goal is to cultivate creativity, connect cultures, and inspire children through professional theatre works from all over the world. BICT Fest will also provide a platform for intercultural exchanges for artists and audiences and creative learning programs for young people and their families.

Taking place in the heart of Bangkok at Bangkok Art and Culture Centre (BACC) from June 21–July 3, 2016, BICT Fest aims to become a biannual family event of high-quality performing arts experience. The organizers are Arts on Location and Democrazy Theatre Studio in partnership with BACC and The Japan Foundation, Bangkok. 

Why now?

Thailand’s unstable economy and volatile politics make it more important now than ever that children in this country can participate in experiential learning outside the classroom. Space for freedom of expression is essential to human development, including to the growth of young minds, their character, and beliefs. We believe that theatre provides this space where learning can trigger the imagination and help children grow into curious and creative individuals with an understanding of themselves and empathy for others. As audience members, children are engaged physically, mentally, and emotionally as they experience lives and stories different from their own.

“At BICT Fest, children will be encouraged to grow up inspired by the diversity of life’s experiences and to see the world from different perspectives through theatre.” 


Organization member



Equal Opportunity

BICT Fest believes in equal opportunities for children from all socio-economic backgrounds. Without subsidy, the actual cost of festival tickets would be restrictive. We are striving to ensure that ticket prices make shows and workshops accessible to everyone, and that activities around the festival are free of charge whenever possible.


We need your help!

Making BICT Fest a reality is extremely challenging when the Thai government gives little to no support to the arts. A total of 6,000,000 Baht or 170,000 USD is needed to cover the costs of BICT Fest 2016 and we’ve been working since August 2015 to raise funds from international organizations, trusts, and foundations, embassies, and corporations.

We have covered over 50% of the total budget and we still need your help to raise 30,000 USD to make BICT 2016 become a reality.


Your pledge will contribute to:

-  Daily expenses for international and Thai artists

-  Production equipment: materials for sets, props, light and sound rental

-  BICT Fest staff salaries: administrative staff, interpreters, technical and management teams

-  Travel and food for festival volunteers

-  Expenses towards helping disadvantaged children to see the shows and join the festival activities

What you can get:

Apart from being a support to help make Thailand's first children theatre festival a reality, you will also receive a choice of our gifts.

“Top Perks to Pick” from  
Friends of BICT Fest  in the Arts!

In just one click, you can own a piece of collectable contemporary art by Thai artists and help fund BICT Fest 2016!”

BICT Fest releases a collection of artwork by Thailand’s top illustrators, painter, and photographer. These widely established and internationally exhibited artists are “Friends of BICT Fest” who have generously donated their work in support of this campaign. 


BICTCollectible Art: PaintingTS

Title: "Untitle", 2016

Artist: Tongkarn Samathakorn

watercolor painting on paper
Size: 20.6 x 30 cm

Tongkarn made this freshly painted watercolour on paper especially for BICT Fest 2016 Indiegogo fundraising campaign.

Known as "Organic Water Colour Artist", Tongkarn solely paints with colours that she made herself from organic flowers. She started using them a few years ago. After her recovery from cancer, Tongkarn wanted to find alternative, non-toxic ways to continue creating her artwork.


BICTCollectible Art : Painting 1

Title: Flower blooming from a cup of tea

Artist: Peeticha Kongrit

watercolor painting on paper

Size : 14.5x16  cm

The reason I like to drink flowering tea so much is because of the luscious fragrant it brings to the heart just like blossoming flowers.


BICTCollectible Art : Painting 2

Title : My Mysterious Summer

Artist: Peeticha Kongrit

watercolor painting on paper (printed version)

Size : 17.7x12.6 cm


Childhood adventure in the summer is always enchanting and memorable. Once when we still believe in mystical world, just by entering a small hut in the middle of a forest could become a journey full of magic.


BICTCollectible Art : Giclee 

Title: 4th Plinth

Artist: Oat Montien

Pastel Giclee Print on Paper

Size : A1 (unframed)

This work is inspired by Elmgreen & Dragset's sculpture "4 Plinth" on Trafalgar Square in London. It was a very hot day. 

Oat Montien is, in his own word, "An Illustrator lost in between myths and memory, dreams and reality."


BICTCollectible Art : Painting 3

Title: The Celebration is Beginning

Artist: Peeticha Kongrit

watercolor painting on paper

Size : 28x19 cm

From a point of view of an adult, circus performed by kids could be full of hickups, as expected from amateurs. However, one thing which makes this circus performance unique is that it is full of joyful vitality and freedom.


BICTCollectable Art: Collage YB

Title: “Posthumous Papers of a Living Author”, 2014 

Artist: Yodchat Bupasiri 

Drawing and collage on wood

Size: 30 x 40 cm.


Illustration for the cover of the book of the same title written by Austrian writer, Robert Musil. The book was the last volume Musil published before his sudden death in 1942, and this is the first Thai translation of his work. An internationally exhibited and award-winning artist, Yodchat attempted to transcribe the nuances of the time and place, Musil’s emotion, and his writing style through a collage of surrealistic imaginary drawing upon the stories, depicting his state of mind. 


BICTCollectable Art:Painting PK

Title: “Wrath of the Titans”, 2013

Artist: Pisitakun Kuantalaeng 

Ink on Paper

Size: 42x60


This is one of its series in the solo fantasy art exhibition Wrath of the Titans at Speedy Grandma Gallery in Bangkok, and a sequel to the 2009 Art exhibition Clash of the Titans.  As the gods lose control over the imprisoned Titans and Perseus is called once again, this time to rescue his father Zeus, overthrow the Titans and save mankind.


BICTCollectible Art: Diptych1

Title : The Dream of mind, February, thee (it), 2009

Artist: Namsom Supanan

woodblock, Silkscreen

SIZE (cm) : 55x83 cm.


BICTCollectible Art: Diptych2

Title : The Dream of mind, Feb, to bind Date : 2009

Artist: Namsom Supanan

woodblock, Silkscreen

SIZE (cm) : 55x83 cm.


This poetic diptych is part of Namsom’s series of paintings from her ongoing concept about dream and reality and the line between the two worlds, centering on the theme of femininity versus masculinity. These two paintings depict a surreal yet vivid imaginary world where desire and emotion are blended.

You may want to pick just one painting, and it is absolutely possible.


BICT Collectible Art: Photo

Title: “Love Will Tear Us Apart”, 2013

Artist: Tada Hengsapkul 

AP 1/2, printed on Bamboo paper (Awagami Factory)

Size: 14.66in x 22.00in

Recently appeared in Forbes’ 2016 30 Under 30 Asia: The Arts, Tada has exhibited his works in Australia, China, and New York. This photograph was taken during his personal project in Myanmar.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • You may love our project but just can't contribute financially

    That's OK. 
    You can still support BICT Fest by sharing our campaign with your friends and family. Copy and paste this link into your social media accounts: 


Please help us get the word out and contribute to making Thailand’s first international performing arts festival for children a success!  

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
What is Hazard? And Who are We?

Hazard is a new play to premiere at the Minnesota Fringe Festival this August. 

Megan Burns and Eric Norton are theater makers in Minneapolis. They are employing other young theater makers in Minneapolis to put up a new play about women in the rural south. 

We are committed to putting up new work that is empowering to young people and different perspectives. We are excited to share this premiere with the Minnesota Fringe Festival, and to show you our other projects we've got cooking for the future!

Hazard's Origins

Hazard began as a year and a half ago as a play told by one character that grew into three character's shared journey of self discovery, and the challenges of connecting to another human being. It's a play about art, and uneducated or forgotten people on the peripheries of society. It deals with violence and its consequences. It's a story we really want to tell, and we hope that you can help us make that possible. 

What We Need & What You Get

Ok so here's how it works:

  • 30% goes to paying actors. Since there are only four actors in our project, that's a lot! We have a team of professional actors from the Twin Cities, which is exciting, so let's make it worth their time! We believe that artists should be paid for their work, and this fantastic cast certainly deserves that.
  • 20% goest to tech expenses. Because making stuff costs stuff! We already have beautiful drafts of what the set and costumes will look like, and frankly, we need the raw material to make that happen. 
  • 36% goes to our technical staff. We have a team of rockstars on our side! We have a professional Director, Marketer, Stage Manager and Set Designer. This is a passion project for them, and they are being so generous with their time, and they deserve to be paid! Support them!
  • 14% goes to promotional material. We need to get people in seats! we need money to print/advertise/spread word/throw parties! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute today? Now worries!

  • Share our campaign on Facebook! Twitter! Instagram! MySpace! Maybe not MySpace...We really want more than anything to get the word out so we can fill as many seats as possible. 
  • Come see the show! When Fringe does roll around there's a lot to do and see, but we hope that Hazard makes it to the top of your list! Which leads us to...
  • Come to the Fringe Festival! This year it's $22 for a day pass which gets you to any number of shows for a whole day! That's right ANY SHOW, ALL DAY! Fringe Shows are under an hour, so you can knock out a lot in that time. And the Fringe Festival is a big part of the vibrant Minneapolis Theater Community, so come out and support independent work! 

See you at the Fringe!

And the Fringe Festival is a big part of the vibrant Minneapolis Theater Community, so come out and support independent work!    See you at the Fringe!

story:
Hosted in Downtown Brattleboro VT the Southern Vermont Dance Festival is accessible to all.  From dance enthusiasts to dance professionals there is something for everyone.  Attendees can purchase festival passes, tickets to performances or participate in the dozens of free community events that are offered throughout the four days in an effort to build the downtown community of Brattleboro.

All activities take place in the downtown area, encouraging attendees to utilize local businesses for dining, activities, and shopping.  Performances are held in local businesses on the main streets leading attendees into our local shops, museums and restaurants.  Dancers are encouraged to buy local goods and to enjoy all of the local wonder that Brattleboro has to offer.  Additionally, people are encouraged to enjoy local farm stands, hikes, bike routes and more.  

SVDF is about community, education and economic growth.  It was designed from one persons vision to revive the downtown community after it was plagued by a major fire and Tropical Storm Irene, destroying many of the area business’s and making for a long road to recovery.  This festival aims to create an extensive educational experience  and awareness about our thriving performing arts community while encouraging travel and even relocation to the Southern Vermont area.  SVDF is about community building and awareness and makes for a wonderful summer event for people from out of town as well as our local community!  There is something for everyone!

Please help us reach our goal by donating. It is a wonderful way to support a local festival works hard to support its community.  We deeply appreciate your generosity.

story:
Namaste!

We are equal not because we say so, but because we act so.

From more than three years now we have been working in Taapu- "A Creative Adventure".  Taapu (Island in English) is our attempt to voice our strong belief in equality through action. 

Taapu is a professional play with children with disabilities as its main actors. This is a story of many layers; at one level it is a story of children in a fantasy island where they journey together for a different, magical land. On a deeper level, it is a conflict of differing beliefs, of believing in what is told is right or exploring to find out the truth yourself. It is a battle of authority and principles, and a story of losing childhood innocence.


(Taapu- A dream)

Our own journey with these children has been nothing sort of an inspiring fable kept alive not by resources but dreams. Now, we want to share this magical journey with all by staging the play in a theatre hall. 

"What are you helping us achieve?"

The apt ending to any art form is being able to showcase it to a larger mass of audience. When we started, we started with the dream of staging our play in a theatre hall. Without any outright cause, normally attached with the use of marginalized group, we want this drama to be an expression of equality - through action.

By contributing to this initiative, you are helping us achieve our dream bound together with these children for some years now.

The Impact

Taapu- A moving Island is a Pathshala Dream, helped by the enthusiastic acting and passionate participation of children with disabilities. The play is our strong attempt to voice our belief that people with disabilities are no different after all, given proper platform. 


It gives a new professional dimension to people with disabilities and somehow sensitizes the issues of people with disabilities with a shimmering light of hope, expressed through art- that captures imagination.

story:
Hi! I’m Lauren, a New York-based writer and actor. My one-woman show: “Lauren White Wants You!” has been selected to be a part of the 2014 United Solo Festival. This is the first time I’ll be performing my own work in New York, which is very exciting, but in order to make it happen, there are some costs that need to be met.

What is “Lauren White Wants You!”? 

The original inspiration for the show came when I was studying abroad and started speaking with people that were very vocal about politics but didn’t vote. I was interested in the seeming disconnect between belief and action. I found that the overwhelming response from people who had chosen not to vote was that they felt their one vote could never make any kind of real difference in the world. Therefore, I wanted to create a show that would demonstrate the immediate effect that a person’s actions could have on a community and other people’s lives.

Why is the show worth seeing and/or supporting?

"Lauren White Wants You!" focuses on the unique impact that only you can have on the world and how your responses to the world around you matter. This show is about discovering who you truly are through reactions to power, group dynamic and anonymity. It’s taking on society’s rules of what can and can’t be discussed and attempting to see yourself and the world around you as it truly is.

What we need:

In order to make the show happen, we need to raise $2000 to pay for theatre insurance and fire coding, rehearsal space, equipment, transportation, promotion and marketing, compensation for the creative and technical teams, and lots more. This project has been a big undertaking, and it’s taken a lot to get it this far, so any help that you can give is so greatly appreciated and will go a long way towards making this show a reality. I’ve also included perks for donators that you can check out in the sidebar.

How else can you help?

Please follow us on social media and share this page. Helping get the word out is always appreciated!

The show opens on Oct 22nd at 7:30PM at Theatre Row in NYC, looking forward to seeing you there!:)

story:
English:

Hi, my name is Vinicius Silva.

Ever since I was 5 years old, I have the dream to be a ballet dancer. With hard work and commitment, now I see my dream is possible.

In January, I took part in one of the biggest ballet competitions of the world, Prix de Lausanne. Being there was already one of my greatest accomplishments. 

I was one of the few finalists of the competition and received a scholarship to study at one of the most renowned ballet schools world-wide, The John Cranko Schule in Stuttgart, Germany. Although, the scholarship doesn't cover the plane ticket, which is really expensive for my family's financial situation. 

That's why I come through this page to ask for anything you can offer.  

Any amount will help me make my dreams come true! 


Português:

 Olá, meu nome é Vinícius Silva.

Desde os meus 5 anos de idade, tenho o sonho de ser bailarino. Através de muita perseverança, hoje vejo que esse sonho é possível. 

Em Janeiro deste ano participei de um dos maiores e mais conhecidos festivais de ballet do mundo, Prix de Lausanne. Estar lá já foi uma grande vitória.

Fui um dos poucos finalistas do concurso e recebi uma bolsa de estudos para estudar dois anos em Stuttgart, Alemanha na John Cranko Schule. Porém, a bolsa não cobre a passagem e é muito cara para minha situação familiar.

Por isso venho, através deste, pedir para me ajudar com o possível.

Qualquer quantia ajudará a tornar meu sonho realidade!

Se houver algum problema com o site, deixo minha conta bancária:

Agência: 1850 Caixa Econômica

Operacão: 013

Conta poupança: 00015336-9

story:
NEW GOAL: $9,000

Thanks to you we have officially hit our goal with a few days to spare!

We would love to continue climbing to a new goal of $9,000. With these additional funds, we will be able to make this a more fully realized production. Our sets will be better, our marketing more developed, and most importantly, we can reserve studio space for rehearsal. Be assured, your donations will be put to good use, and remember -
no amount is too small!

Thank you again for this enormous outpouring of support. We can't wait to share this production with you!



An understudy rehearsal for the Broadway premiere of Kafka's undiscovered masterpiece. One afternoon to get it right. There's just one problem - nothing goes right.

See how the existentialism of Franz Kafka and the intangibility of theatre collide in Theresa Rebeck's hilarious comedy,
The Understudy.

The show must go on...right?


WELCOME

Greetings Friends, Family, Colleagues, and Indiegogo Browsers,

Welcome to our campaign. We are raising funds for a production of Theresa Rebeck’s The Understudy. This three-person comedy is going up at The Secret Theatre in Long Island City, Queens from May 28 through June 1. Follow us on Twitter, and visit our website here!

You can help make this show happen!

THE BACKSTORY

Simply put, this production stems from a place of love and the need to create theatre. It was born out of a group of artists known as The Fishbowl Collective. In December of 2012, Muhlenberg College alumni founded this Collective, a group that serves as a resource for current and future alumni to network and develop new work. In one year we have grown to over 400 members. This past fall, we presented our second InstaConcert, a night of first drafts. Participants rehearsed four to six hours and then performed their work. A few of us put up a scene from The Understudy. It was only five minutes long, but we could not get enough of it. Ultimately we decided to put up a production of our own and create our own opportunities. We couldn’t be more excited to share it with you in May.

THE FOLKS INVOLVED

CAST
Brian Byus........................Jake
Craig Hanson*...................Harry
Becca Schneider...............Roxanne

*Appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association.

CREATIVE TEAM
Jenn Haltman....................Director
Sandy Yaklin.....................Set Designer
Alling Langin......................Lighting Designer
Ien DeNio..........................Sound Designer
Michelle Leibrock..............Costume Designer
Jerzy Jung........................Original Music
Rael Linder.......................Stage Manager
Elana McKelahan..............Assistant Director
Meghan Ryan...................Assistant Stage Manager
Becca Schneider..............Lead Producer
Christina Pezzello.............Associate Producer

And now we need YOU! Take a look at some of the great perks available, and please consider making a donation, however small, to help this show come to life. Oh, and be sure to check back throughout the campaign as we add more perks!

THE BUDGET

Our goal is to raise $7500. Want to know where your donation is going? Here’s a breakdown:

  • One-week rental at the fantastic Secret Theatre in Long Island City, NY
  • Royalties for this hilarious, poignant play by Theresa Rebeck
  • Creative budget for set, lighting, sound, and costumes
  • Accident insurance to protect everyone involved
  • Rehearsal space rental costs
  • Marketing and promotion

If you are unable to donate, we would love for you to send our campaign around to others you think might be interested! Share it on Facebook, Twitter, or whichever social media tool is your favorite.

We want to thank you in advance for your consideration and support of this endeavor, and we will see you at The Secret Theatre in May!

VIDEO CREDITS

Written by Becca Schneider and Brian Byus
Directed by Becca Schneider
Filmed and Edited by Larry Schneider
Music by Jeff Schneider
Poster Design by Annie Govekar
Special Thanks to New York Theatre Workshop, 4th Street Theatre, Fault Line Theatre, 
Sally Schneider, and Amanda D’Aquila

story:
Summary

We are Springboard Theatre Productions, a new theatre company created by 3 young women in their 20s, dedicated to producing new, provocative work, and enlisting the talented emerging artists that the Lower Mainland has to offer.

Producing a musical is an enormous up-taking, and there are hundreds of costs and factors that go into the success of a musical. Venue, set, costumes, performers, directors, insurance, honorariums, the list goes on! With your support, we will be creating a musical that touches on some serious issues, while balanced with plenty of light-hearted humor, fun, bawdy scenes, and hopeful, beautiful music.


Synopsis

The show we are producing is called Darling, a musical that is loosely based on Peter Pan. It was written in New York by B.T. Ryback and Ryan Scott Oliver, and has never been performed in Canada before. The musical is set in 1929 Boston, just weeks before the stock market crash, with jazz, speakeasies, booze, and a mysterious white powder called "Dust". Ursula encounters a boy named Peter, who is being pursued by Captain Rose of the police. Along the way, they meet the "lost boys" of the Warehouse speakeasy, Stella the jealous barkeep, and the girls of Lily's burlesque.

The Impact

Every dollar helps make Darling the best production it can be. Everything that is donated to this campaign will be used to make this show come to life, and everything/anything you can donate is absolutely appreciated from all the artists involved in this project.

This musical is different than the musicals that usually get produced. It is provocative and racy, and deals with the harsh realities that life can bring, things like prostitution, drug use, discrimination against sexual orientation, police brutality, teenage pregnancy, and the repercussions that can arise from these situations. Shows like these are not produced often, because they are not family friendly, and can make people feel uncomfortable. But theatre is not always about feeling happy and carefree; sometimes theatre is meant to make you feel something, and maybe change the way you think about the world. 

We have 20 cast members, and a production team almost as big, all working hard together to bring this thought-provoking musical to life. 


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you aren't able to donate monetarily,  there are still ways you can help.

    Please share this link/project on Facebook, Twitter, email, word of mouth, anything. Or if you have something you would like to donate that could be used as a prize of some sort (think gift cards/certificates, products, services) please let us know. We are happy to accept whatever help you can give.

story:
Road Veins is the story about a brother and sister traveling in an RV across the country after their father's death.  Along the way they rediscover their love for each other and finally find a family of their own.


With the generous help from The Anne Freedman Student Theatre Production Fund, a program of the Department of Theatre at Hunter College aWe Creative Group has received money that will cover space for a Workshop Production this Fall.
Amy E. Witting, artistic director of aWe Creative Group, recently graduated with her MFA from Hunter College where she had the great privilege of working with Alex Correia on her thesis production.  After receiving a grant the pair has teamed up again to bring her newest play, Road Veins, to the stage. 
Having an opportunity to do a workshop production is a wonderful chance to really get into the bulk of a script and see what works and what doesn't.  We are hoping to raise the rest of the money towards the production in order to keep tickets costs low, and pay the talented artists that have graciously decided to come on board.
The cast of ROAD VEINS includes:
KARA DUDLEY
PAUL EDDY
GLEN FEINSTEIN
JAMIE HEINLEIN
ALICE KREMELBERG

What We Need & What You Get

  • The play is set in an RV and we need to pay some talented designers to come up with a concept and materials to create this space.
  • The lovely actors and director are so gracious and passionate about this play but it would be wonderful to be able to pay them for their time.
  • Props, costumes, programs, and publicity all cost money.

story:
WHO WE ARE

  • BÉZNĂ Theatre, our theatre company, is devoted to social change. We aim to create confrontational and exciting theatre accessible to everyone. We have recognised the dangers of deregulated capitalism and we hope to share our awareness of these dangers with the world. 
  • Our company is helmed by two Artistic Directors, Sînziana Koenig and Nico Vaccari. We formed BÉZNĂ in May 2013 when our production of Deathwatch by Jean Genet, directed by Sînziana Koenig, sold out at the Accidental Festival at the Roundhouse. We also run English-language theatre summer camps for children in Romania where we share our love and knowledge of theatre with the new generations.
  • Through our work in Romania and the UK we hope to close the cultural gap between East and West and fight prejudice born out of media manipulation and ignorance.
  • Your support is essential in our fight against social inequality. Alongside the cuts to the welfare state the arts were also sacrificed, making it more difficult for young artists to expose their work. Your support can change this for us.

OFFERING AND RECEIVING

  • We need to raise £2500 in order to pay for our show to transfer to Romania. This amount will cover the shipping of set, props and costume, the travel of the 6 company members (4 actors, 1 director, 1 designer), their accommodation in Bucharest and the hire of the venue. Any extra gains will cover the cost of our new website.
  • Our perks include an exciting day in our rehearsal room, a free ticket to the show, mentions in the programme, an album of production photographs and a signed poster from all of us! 
  • If the amount you'd like to donate is not on our list, please let us know and we'll make sure to create one for you. Any support will make a difference.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we won't give up! We'll keep trying to find funds in order to take CRIME to Bucharest!

WHY IT MATTERS

  • In today's individualistic, hyper-capitalist world, the community is sacrificed. We are not encouraged to help each other, and in so doing, we do not help ourselves. We at BÉZNĂ Theatre believe that theatre is the ultimate act of giving: our passion, our work, our awareness. Please help our campaign if you also believe in the hope for change.
  • Our previous production of Deathwatch by Jean Genet got us a 5 star review with little to no budget. We are always happy to work for free as long as we can share our messages with the world. 
  • If you want more information from us we would love you to get in touch! Email Nico or Sînziana at beznatheatre@live.com.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can't contribute today, it doesn't mean that you can't help!

  • Please help us spread the word by sharing this with your friends and family! It is a cause that affects us all.
  • You can use Indiegogo's nifty share tools!
story_txt:
WHO WE ARE
BÉZNĂ Theatre, our theatre company, is devoted to social change. We aim to create confrontational and exciting theatre accessible to everyone. We have recognised the dangers of deregulated capitalism and we hope to share our awareness of these dangers with the world. 
Our company is helmed by two Artistic Directors, Sînziana Koenig and Nico Vaccari. We formed BÉZNĂ in May 2013 when our production of Deathwatch by Jean Genet, directed by Sînziana Koenig, sold out at the Accidental Festival at the Roundhouse. We also run English-language theatre summer camps for children in Romania where we share our love and knowledge of theatre with the new generations.
Through our work in Romania and the UK we hope to close the cultural gap between East and West and fight prejudice born out of media manipulation and ignorance.
Your support is essential in our fight against social inequality. Alongside the cuts to the welfare state the arts were also sacrificed, making it more difficult for young artists to expose their work. Your support can change this for us.
OFFERING AND RECEIVING
We need to raise £2500 in order to pay for our show to transfer to Romania. This amount will cover the shipping of set, props and costume, the travel of the 6 company members (4 actors, 1 director, 1 designer), their accommodation in Bucharest and the hire of the venue. Any extra gains will cover the cost of our new website.
Our perks include an exciting day in our rehearsal room, a free ticket to the show, mentions in the programme, an album of production photographs and a signed poster from all of us! 
If the amount you'd like to donate is not on our list, please let us know and we'll make sure to create one for you. Any support will make a difference.
If we don't reach our entire goal, we won't give up! We'll keep trying to find funds in order to take CRIME to Bucharest!
WHY IT MATTERS
In today's individualistic, hyper-capitalist world, the community is sacrificed. We are not encouraged to help each other, and in so doing, we do not help ourselves. We at BÉZNĂ Theatre believe that theatre is the ultimate act of giving: our passion, our work, our awareness. Please help our campaign if you also believe in the hope for change.
Our previous production of Deathwatch by Jean Genet got us a 5 star review with little to no budget. We are always happy to work for free as long as we can share our messages with the world. 
If you want more information from us we would love you to get in touch! Email Nico or Sînziana at beznatheatre@live.com.
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPIf you can't contribute today, it doesn't mean that you can't help!
Please help us spread the word by sharing this with your friends and family! It is a cause that affects us all.

story:
Asylos is a theater company that creates devised, multi-media immersive performance by a wonderfully wacky and compelling ensemble that likes to take their audience members on scenic detours to share a quirky anecdote or ask a few questions, with offerings of fruit, pies and perhaps even a boozy beverage.

Asylos is committed to creating non-traditional theater experiences that challenge the rules and confines of viewing theater, thus engaging an audience in an altogether unique and wondrous journey. 

Company members include: Teresa Braun, Elisa Marti, Amanda Rothman, Virginia Rupert and Yael Shavitt. 

The seeds of Asylos were planted back in June of 2012 when artistic director G.J. Dowding embarked on his first directorial journey with his original work, Quizzically Quimsical. The magical chemistry that was born of that show has kept a core group of artists working together on highly movement based material steeped in poetry and prose. From original work, to the words of Bob Dylan, to now Sylvia Plath, Asylos is bursting out beyond the wings of a theater.

Immersive theater is a very exciting venture right now. We are looking to continue to stretch the limits of immersive theater and to further expand upon what is possible. It is such an exciting and challenging experience!

Which brings us to our campaign! 

The minimum funding we need is $4,000. Here is where it goes:

-We will be able to pursue becoming a registered non-profit organization. This requires hiring a lawyer and paying some cold hard cash. As a registered non-profit we will be able to confidently pursue grants and fellowship opportunities that could continue to expand our company and its involvement with local NYC artists and the surrounding community.                                                                                                                    -We will be able to set up a business bank account that will help to further us as a serious and committed company.                                                                                                  -We will be able to set up methods of  compensation for our wonderfully invested and talented company members.                                                                                                   -As a company, we will be able to have funding for rehearsal space for our work.                                                                                                                                                               -MARKETING: It will allow us to fully fund the means to maintain our website, our company email account, purchase business cards, create a company logo.                                                                                                                -We will also have the opportunity to enter our current production, Out Of The Ash, with some seed money.

Out Of The Ash is an immersive, multi-media show that will perform at Glasshouse ArtLifeLab (glasshouseproject.org) in Brooklyn this coming fall (September 24-26 and October 1-3). The show is set to text by Sylvia Plath with a script by artistic director, G.J. Dowding.


This show has been in rehearsal since for over 6 months now. The level of commitment and passion the company has brought to the process has been astounding. Out Of The Ash recently performed a work-in-progress at the HOT! Festival at Dixon Place. It was during that process that Asylos was invited to build an immersive experience at Glasshouse ArtLifeLab. 

The seed money we hope to fundraise for this coming production will pay for the following:

-Lighting Designer                                                                                                                                -Sound Designer                                                                                                                                    -Video Designer                                                                                                                                     -Performers (Our 5 company members and 2 additional 'house guests')                        -Costume and set pieces                                                                                                                    -Food and drink that will be consumed by the performed and offered up to the audience throughout the show.                                                                                                                  -MARKETING: Creating postcards, flyers and posters to help spread the word about the show.

We are also looking to additional fundraising opportunities. On Friday, August 28th we will be holding a fundraising party for the launch of Asylos. It will be held at a killer Williamsburg neighborhood bar, Humboldt & Jackson (humboldtandjackson.com) The evening will feature live performances, drink specials, a 50/50 raffle, a kissing booth, ouija, some soul portraits by company member Teresa Braun and a whole lot of joy and celebration. Check out or Facebook page (Facebook.com/AsylosTheater) and website (asylostheater.com) for updates and more information. 

WHAT YOU GET IN RETURN:

As an enormous thank you for helping to fund our work, we are offering up some super exciting perks, which you can view on the right of your screen. We want to make this personal: We will be singing your praises on social media and in print, giving away tickets, showing you a good time at our post-show parties with champagne and glowing banter. We will write you poems, bake you pies, give you lessons in Hebrew, take you on a breathtaking guided hike, throw you a dinner party, paint you original artwork, knit you a handmade shawl for the upcoming fall months AND if you're feeling exceptionally generous, you will become obtain a lifetime membership and get FREE tickets to ANY AND ALL future Asylos productions!

We are extremely committed to engaging with our community and giving back. We have been so blessed to find wonderful support along our journey and  have often been invited to show our work at venues because of their belief in our work. We are so dedicated to nurturing this company and watching it grow so that someday we can have a home of our own to welcome fellow artists in our community into with  the chance to show their work. We have HUGE hopes and dreams and it all starts with this campaign!

Thank you SO much for your interest in our project and for your much appreciated support! Any amount AT ALL means the world to us. If you are unable to contribute monetarily, please spread the word to friends, family, loved ones and your community. Social media is a powerful beast and we are ready to be spread all over it!

For more information and to stay up to date on our progress check us out on Facebook:

Facebook.com/AsylosTheater

View our newly published website:

asylostheater.com

Try to come up with 1,000 words to put to our Instagram photos:

@asylostheater

BIG LOVE!

story:
CADT Student Choreography Showcase

Class Act Dance Troupe (CADT) is a nonprofit organization that provides students with additional opportunities to utilize their dance training and develop their abilities through the creative outlets of performance events and community involvement, while fostering self-esteem, confidence, and a sense of achievement. The troupe performs year-round throughout the Warsaw area, spreading an appreciation for the art of dance throughout our community. Because we feel it is vital to give back, we decided, for the first time, to put on an entirely student choreographed showcase in which all net proceeds will be donated to a local charity, The Community Closet. The Community Closet, based out of the First United Methodist Church of downtown Warsaw, is a small organization with a big impact. Helping those in need receive the items they need most, The Closet provides items that are not covered by food stamps (S.N.A.P.) and other government assistance, including  items like shampoo, soap, toothpaste, razors, and other toiletries, along with cleaning supplies, baby supplies, laundry detergent, and toilet paper. Among many other things, the Community Closet offers what we all too often take for granted to about 120 families each and every week. It is our wish and goal to make this showcase a reality for the dancers of Class Act Dance Troupe. Through this experience, they will gain artistry, choreography experience, a sense of what it takes to create for their peers, and a greater knowledge of how dance can be used to help their community. Even more than this, we wish to make it a reality for the members of our community that depend on the funds donated to The Community Closet.

What We Need & The Impact

Unfortunately, we cannot make this a reality without raising funds first and foremost to cover the costs of putting this charitable showcase on. 

  • We must raise at least $900 to cover the costs of facility rental, lighting, and promotional materials . All net proceeds made from the showcase and additional money raised here will be donated directly to The Community Closet. The Community Closet has no overhead and 100% of what is donated goes straight to those in our community who are in need. 
  • Of course any amount donated will be more than appreciated, but if you donate $100 or more, you will receive two complimentary tickets to the showcase to see the student's choreography first hand! 
Our Student Choreography Showcase is scheduled to be held on Wednesday, August 5, 2015 at 7pm in the WCHS Performing Arts Center. 

We are immensely grateful for any amount you are willing and able to contribute. Meeting our goal will give our students an opportunity to grow as artists, challenge themselves, learn how to use dance to help their community, and raise money for an incredible cause. We can't imagine going without many of the items that The Community Closet provides to families on a weekly basis. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, please help us spread the word! CADT wants to give back, but we truly cannot until we raise enough to cover the costs of the showcase itself!

story:
We're producing Urinetown like you've never seen it before. Through the lens of modern civil rights issues and social justice movements, we will tell the story of an oppressed people fighting for liberation. Also, it's super funny. Also, it's a musical.

Hello! We are Fracture Theatre Co. We are a new theatre company founded by three Syracuse University Alumni: Seth Landau (Director and Executive Producer), Tim Simon (Executive Producer), and Ethan Butler (Executive Producer). We are producing Urinetown, the Musical in the same space it originally premiered in Off-Broadway (the American Theater of Actors) under the mentorship of The Araca Group (the original producers of Urinetown) through the 2015 Araca Projects. 
The show originally premiered Off-Broadway at the American Theatre of Actors in 2001, it transferred to Broadway later that year. In the last 14 years, many of the issues Urinetown takes on (police brutality, corporate interests, income inequality) have become a much larger part of the national conversation. With that in mind, we see this as the perfect time to revive Urinetown. Keeping the show's wit and humor intact, we want to not just explore these issues but make a statement for meaningful change. Using a talented, diverse group of actors, and an endlessly creative design team, we want to create a show that is dramatic, hilarious, and grounded. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are looking to raise $25,000 to put on this production. While that may seem like a lot of money to some, this is a very small amount of money to produce a show this big at this scale. 
  • This money will cover: Set, Costumes, Lights, Props, Sound, Marketing Materials, Theatrical Production Rights, Stipends for amazing people we couldn't do this show without like our Music Director and Stage Manager, and Contingency Money. 
  • If you donate to our project, you can get some awesome stuff! Want some free wine or beer? Of course you do! Want a pair of house seats to the show? To opening night? No problem! We'll even list you as a Producer on the project! You can tell all of your friends you're producing Urinetown in the same space it premiered in Off-Broadway. 
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we will have to significantly scale down our production. While we are prepared to do this, we want Urinetown to get the production it deserves and needs in this time. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Like us on Facebook, Follow us on Twitter, and come see the show!
  • SHARE THIS PAGE ON YOUR SOCIAL MEDIA ACCOUNTS!


Thank you so much for your support! 

Tim Simon, Seth Landau, and Ethan Butler 

Executive Producers 

Fracture Theatre Co.

story:
Caleb Collins and Alison Holman, friends since the age of 5, have been working as a writing team since they were in high school. Since coming to NYC, their original musical, 'Freedom's Song' has played to sold out audiences in new works festivals in the city to rave reviews. Now, to get to the next step and even have a chance at seeing the lights of Broadway, they need some help from everyone who has ever loved this show or has believed in them as artists and serious writers! 

This money will be used to produce a professional, invite only industry staged reading for Broadway producers to watch and hopefully get behind them after seeing the newly revised product. It will be staged with Broadway stars and also will hopefully include giving prospective investors a concept album of the show. Funding will also go towards the production of this album which will take hours in studios with live musicians and their Broadway singers bringing it to life so the show can be reviewed even after investors leave the performance. 

Alison and Caleb have worked tirelessly to get the show to where it is today and have funneled every bit of their own funds they have been able to into it's current successes. But now they need your help to continue down the path which will hopefully end on the Great White Way! Any amount is greatly appreciated! Thank you for believing in us! Click on the 'Gallery' to see more video clips from the show!

Since coming to NYC, their original musical, 'Freedom's Song' has played to sold out audiences in new works festivals in the city to rave reviews. Now, to get to the next step and even have a chance at seeing the lights of Broadway, they need some help from everyone who has ever loved this show or has believed in them as artists and serious writers! This money will be used to produce a professional, invite only industry staged reading for Broadway producers to watch and hopefully get behind them after seeing the newly revised product. It will be staged with Broadway stars and also will hopefully include giving prospective investors a concept album of the show. Funding will also go towards the production of this album which will take hours in studios with live musicians and their Broadway singers bringing it to life so the show can be reviewed even after investors leave the performance. Alison and Caleb have worked tirelessly to get the show to where it is today and have funneled every bit of their own funds they have been able to into it's current successes. But now they need your help to continue down the path which will hopefully end on the Great White Way! Any amount is greatly appreciated! Thank you for believing in us! Click on the 'Gallery' to see more video clips from the show!

story:
Collaborate with us - help us bring a new play to the stage!

 

Theatre of NOTE has been supporting playwrights and their new works for more than 25 years in the heart of Hollywood. Without the efforts of 99-seat theaters like NOTE, new voices and new works would never have an opportunity to reach an audience. Disassembly is a wonderfully, written piece highlighting love's devotion from a dark, comedic perspective. To get it up and running, we need your collaboration, to be a part of our team.

 

While good Karma goes a long way, we also have perks just for you!

Disassembly will have a six-week run from February 14th to March 22nd, Thursday through Sunday nights. Our fundraising goal is $4,500 which would cover all production costs from costumes and props to director and designer fees. Every dollar donated would be spent on the production and every dollar is so appreciated!  Every dollar donated is also TAX DEDUCTIBLE as Theatre of NOTE is a 501(c)(3).

Please check out the perks that are listed for you!

Also, please feel free to share this with folks you know who love good theater or love giving away moolah. Seriously, please feel free :)

story:
Aloha everyone! We are a group of theatre tech graduate and undergraduate students who want to go to the United States Institute for Theatre Technology conference in Fort Worth, Texas next spring. We represent costuming, lights, sound, set, stage management and youth theatre. By contributing, you will be helping us to network, find job/internship possibilities, and represent not just UH, but Hawaii at an international theatre conference.

In total, we need approximately $30,000 in funding to get us to Texas. Though we will be getting funding from other sources, we will need more help to get us there. Perks:

  • $10- Thanked in our post trip presentation
  • $25- digital copy of photo album
  • $60- two comp tickets to a show that we work on with our new-found skills
  • $100- physical copy of photo album
Even if we do not reach our full goal, we will be thankful for every single dollar we raise. All of it will go toward funding this trip.

Even if you cannot contribute, spreading the word about our campaign will help! Tweet, share on Facebook, ask your tumblr followers, any kind of signal boost will be a huge help!

story:
The Common Ground: A History

  • As a doctoral student at the University of Toronto, Dr. Ken McNeilly interviewed teenagers who had been raised in queer-led families. Upon completion of his PhD, he knew his 400-page dissertation was filled with rich stories that needed life beyond the dusty shelves of an academic library. What better way to reach the masses than through musical theatre? “The Common Ground: A Musical Dissertation” explores the powerful voices, the unique perspectives, and the beautiful stories of several Ontario youth. "The Common Ground" is lucky enough to be part of the Toronto Fringe Festival 2014, and in order for us to make it all happen we need financial support!

The Common Ground: Our Campaign

We will be using the money we raise to:

  • Pay our actors, Director, Production Manager, Stage Manager, Designers and everyone else who is volunteering their time to this project
  • Rent equipment such as headsets, instruments, amplifiers etc.
  • Make our set and costumes
  • Advertise to make sure as many people as possible hear these incredible stories!

The Common Ground: Other ways to help

While it is a HUGE help if you can donate, we understand that not all folks have the ability to do so. Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Come see the show and bring friends and family
  • Tell friends about our campaign
  • Share our campaign on whatever social media outlets you use (Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram, etc.)

story:
Our Girls Need Your Help!

Girl Be Heard is a non profit theatre company (EIN: 27-1848709) that brings global issues affecting girls center stage.  We perform at the United Nations throughout the year to advocate for women and girls locally and globally.  

10k is needed to bring this full length production of 9mm American, about gun violence, to the main stage. Tickets at girlbeard.org

30k is needed to bring our stop the violence show and educational curriculum into community centers and public schools where gun violence is a daily threat.

Here is an excerpt -- one girl's story whose brother was shot and killed -- Melanie's Story and reviews from previous shows here.

“fearless, political theatre” --Huffington Post

“can’t miss” production" --Ebony Magazine

What We Need & What You Get  

If we are unable to raise $10K, the production, staff, and all-girl cast will suffer. To simply open 9mm America, we need to cover the below costs.  

  • Cast and Crew Stipends  $7000 
  • Rent (writing workshops & rehearsals)  $3000

Our perks are fantastic.  USB drives, singing thank yous, headshots, tickets to shows.  Every donor is invited to our July 4 party (the very last day of this campaign) where we will celebrate in true Americana style.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Go to girlbeheard.org to audition or book a show.
  • Like us on Facebook and let a girl be heard.
  • Follow us on Twitter to join our movement to stop gun violence.
  • Come to the show! Tickets at: http://planetconnections.org/9mm-america
  • If you cannot donate, please share this with others. Together, we can stage the revolution to end to gun violence.

The show would have cost over $100k without the love and support of our cast, crew and village of volunteers.    

The Cast and Crew

9mm America features work by:  Aya Abdelaziz, Naeemah Cooks-Faulk, Dominique Fishback, Monica Furman, Melanie Martins, Breani Michele, Betsy Perez, Jai Raphael, Tiff Roma, Karen Vigo, Nykemah Warren 

Starring:  Naeemah Cooks-Faulk, Dominique Fishback, Monica Furman, Melanie Martins, Breani Michele, Betsy Perez, Jai Raphael, Tiff Roma, Karen Vigo, Nykemah Warren 

Directed by Ashley Marinaccio ~ Produced by Jessica Greer Morris ~ Stage Managed by Tiffany DeBruyn ~ Assistant Stage Managed by Desiree Monae ~ Dramaturgy by Sydney Arndt ~ Assistant Directed by Dominique Fishback ~ Projection, Media and Sound Design by Gil Sperling ~ Choreography by Karen Vigo ~  Postcard Design by Ileany Fields ~ Lighting Design by Mitch Ost ~  Prop Design by Tiff Roma  ~ Set Design by Sparks Grassoy ~  Costume Design by Lienne Dobraja

GREY
Mark Fina- Executive Creative Director
Nicole Handler- Copywriter
Lindsey Katon – Art Director
Alex DeSantis – Producer
Michelle Moscone – Project Manager

SOUND LOUNGE
Glen Landrum – Audio Engineer

LPZ Media crew:
John Lopez - Director
Kevin Lopez - Executive Producer
Derek Aspenberg - Director of Photography
Nicholas Bedo - Sound Operator
Javier Aguirre - Assistant Director
Anthony Sylvestor - Editor
Anthony Velez - Production Assistant

story:
Our Story

The purpose of the Hendrickson Silver Dancers organization is to encourage quality performance, high academic standards, loyal school spirit, and high personal values among its members.  The Silver Dancers team consists of 10th, 11th, and 12th grade girls.  They perform various types of dance routines, including pom, jazz, hip hop, lyrical and high kick. Silver Dancers perform at each of the varsity football games, pep rallies, various competitions and their Spring Show.

The Impact

Through the development of dance technique, leadership, cooperation, self-discipline, and sportsmanship in each individual member, the Silver Dancers will fulfill their purpose for the benefit of Hendrickson High School and the community of the Pflugerville Independent School District.

 

What this has meant to me so far

Being a part of this team has totally made me feel happy!!! Not only am I part of an awesome group of girls, it has help me form new friendships, keeps me busy, and birthed a love of dance that I didn't even know was there before I joined this team.

 

Doing my part

So, I have decided to do my part and try to raise as much money as possible on my own. For any of you guys that are local and have small children you may donate any amount for a free evening with out kids as I will offer my services to baby sit. I take care of the 3-5 yr old children in my church and now that I have a baby brother and sister I have experience even with the little ones, but best would be if they were three years and up.
