story:
Who are we?
Produced Moon Theatre Company focused on creating new experiences for audiences that are playful and collaborative. Our work challenges the conventional expectations of the theatrical relationship between spectator and spectacle. We ask our audience to engage actively with the world and narrative at hand, transforming audience members from distanced viewers to intimate participant. Our intimate participants become immediately integral to the piece, unlocking the narrative they wish to explore rather than passively following what is prescribed. This exciting risk, that lies at the heart of the our work, not only furthers the exhilarating ephemeral nature of all theatre but also establishes the true uniqueness of every show and each individual audience member who steps through our doors and into a world which can become theirs.

What is the project?
Our project is our next piece of theatre, Eden Gate. An interactive and immersive performance, Eden Gate will be premiering at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival later this August. 

What is 'Eden Gate?
A deadly virus is wiping out humanity.What do you do? Who do you go to? Where do you run?Edinburgh. 2017. Scotland's capital is being ravaged by a deadly virus.Citizens and tourists alike are dropping like flies. GTNV,a health organisation set up in the current terror and turmoil, are offering mankind a beacon of hope: Eden Gate. Once you step through the doors of Eden Gate, you step into the world of the show, leave all other realities behind and take on the new one you find yourself within. In order to experience this exciting new kind of theatre Produced Moon Theatre Company invites you to play alongside performers, pick up loose ends, piece together what does not seem to fit and help distinguish fact from fiction. Your opinions, morals, beliefs and decisions mould the show and its narrative, meaning every performance is responsive and therefore tailored to YOU. 

With your financial support we will be able to bring the show to Edinburgh and an audience as well as capable to offer tickets at price that allows everyone the opportunity to experience this kind of work. 


How will your support help?
Our performances are incredibly dependant on our performance space. We need to be able to pay for a venue that offers the kind of space we need. This is where your support comes in. We need to be able to raise £2000 to help us pay for the multiple costs that come from putting on a production.

Venue: Your generous support will help us pay towards the high cost of Eden Gate's venue during its run at the Fringe festival. 

Set: In order to create the world of Eden Gate we need to create both the narrative world and the physical, meaning our sets are detailed. Your support will help us to fund the creative design and construction of the the show's set. 

Props & Costume: Similar to our set, props and costume need to be just as detailed. With your help we will be able to pay for these crucial additions to the show that add so much life and colour to the world of Eden Gate.

Apps, Films & Screens: For the first time we are hoping to introduce live technology into the performance itself. Working with live feed video and app technology within the performance is an incredibly exciting venture as a company, but one that incurs a cost. You money will help towards these costs, ultimately enhancing and enriching the show and its theatrical capabilities. 


Why support Produced Moon?
Theatre is constantly changing and evolving. We are offering you the chance to be involved in the beginning of something with the potential to have a huge affect on how we look at, engage with and think of theatre. When you remove the concept of 'a stage' from a performance and immerse yourself within that performance, theatre surrounds you. From that moment you no longer look to the stage to obtain it, instead, it can be found everywhere around you. Where you chose to look decides what you see. You have the power within the performance. How you interact with what you see decides your experience. 

Our last production, The Hawke Papers,  was a sell out at last year's festival and received glowing reviews. With a bigger, more adventurous and entirely new production, this year looks to be no different. 

"A solid and engaging immersive murder mystery from a young company with clear potential."
All Edinburgh Theatre

"A tentative audience morphed into vocal, argumentative interrogators and a set of fantastic actors managed to stay utterly in character, even when the detective limelight was not shone on them."
FOUR STARS
Three Weeks

"What’s particularly impressive is the considerable dexterity required from the actors to make this kind of immersive theatre work. The cast have to negotiate the environs of a small pub and verbally cajole audience members in the right direction. In this case it really comes off. Interjections and interventions arrive just in time, moving the plot forwards and providing the audience with prompts that lead them to discover certain objects and bring them closer to the truth."
FOUR STARS
A Younger Theatre


Who is on board?
With a huge amount of other shows at this years festival, we are confident that Eden Gate will stand out and above the rest as we are able to already boast a brilliant list of innovative creatives that are involved with the show's creation. With many years of experience in theatre the team are ready to take on the show!

Director: Leonie Rae Gasson (Buzzcut Festival, New Works Festival, Supporting Wall, Misshapen Theatre)
Dramaturg: Melanie Phillips (Greenwich and Docklands Festival, LIFT, Summerhall, Lyric Hammersmith, Barbican Centre, National Theatre)
Designer: David Doyle (NSFD Emerging Artist, NSDF Commendation for Lighting Design, Dublin Fringe Festival, C Nova)
Producer: Harriet Bolwell (Gate Theatre, Cottiers Theatre, The Tramway, SWG3, Theatre Basel)


If you want to help us in our campaign to help fund Eden Gate we can't thank you enough. It's because of people like you that we are able to keep pushing the boundaries of theatre and questioning it as an art form in order to create new and exciting work for audiences everywhere. 

But we can't do this on our own. If you've become a supporter then please, do whatever you can to help publicise this campaign and share this Indiegogo page via the Indiegogo sharing tools.
 Tell your friends, your family, your neighbours, the cashier in the supermarket, the train attendant, your hairdresser, the person next to you at the hairdressers. Who ever you can tell!

Interesting in helping evening more?
That's fantastic! Others you can help are by spreading the word about Eden Gate in the run up to the show. Follow us on twitter! Like us on facebook! Come and see the show and let us know what you thought.

story:
About Me:

Hey this is John some call me JMike also John Michael...I AM A DANCER... I'm also a drummer in my free-time-all-the-time-whenever-time!! I have been dancing all my young life..since I was 3 to be exact. I am currently 16 so yea that's a long time that I have been performing. My training consists of Ballet, Tap, Jazz, Acrobatics, Lyrical, Contemporary and Modern. I became a dance soloist & competed regionally & nationally by age 7. I traveled with my local dance company to multiple dance competitions and attended dance workshops taught by teachers from all over! So its been a busy & exciting journey. Even when worn out at times it has taught me a great deal and trust me I have alot more to learn. Thank GOD for all my dance teachers along the way and my Morgantown Dance family...but honestly being a boy-in-ballet isn't something you shout out on the rooftops Until now........

HEY I AM A DANCER!!!!! I can tell you my dancing has taken notice by many by the awards and dance titles I have achieved over the last 9 years. I must be doing something right..yea? Don't forget who you are, put passion into everything, and don't be afraid to be YOU!!! Please read why I brought you here

My Campaign: 

I auditioned this winter for 6 different dance schools that offered a Summer Intensive Program and all of them accepted me, but I can only choose one. Of my top 3 I chose San Francisco Conservatory of Dance...yep the furthest away from home. Honestly I chose it because of its diversity in Classical & Modern dance. Please copy or click the link below and see why this is so important to me. 

I want to be there but only if you help me...

            http://www.sfconservatoryofdance.org/about-us                     


What I Need & What You Get

Here is the breakdown in more detail:

  • I need to raise $2,500 which will take care of my room/board, meals, required dance apparel and a round-trip flight there. My Tuition of $2,300 has already been paid in full through resources from loves ones who believe in me and want me to succeed. I am so grateful for them all. Unfortunately I need to acquire more funds to make this happen. Let me show you:
  1. $965 for 4 weeks (plus refundable $200 security deposit) Housing provided by University of California 
  2. $150 Resident Advisor (RA) fee (required of all students residing in McAllister Tower)
  3. $390 for 24 dinners (Note: The dinner plan will not begin until Sunday, June 8. From then on, dinners will be served every day except for the days of our BBQs and the last two days in the theater)
  4. $461 for Non-Stop round-trip
  5. $200 for groceries (Breakfast & Lunch)
  6. $134 for dance apparel & shoes
  • Please look for my "special perks" which is my way of saying thank you for your generosity.

The Impact

I want to explain how the difference your contribution will make:

  • My project is very valuable to me as it is providing me with an opportunity for advanced training in ballet and modern technique by a stellar faculty
  • Unlike my previous success record this is a project bigger than I have done before and truly want your support and trust in me. Make this REAL with me!!!
Note:You have an option for your donation to remain anonymous. Also any $ dollar amount is exceptable. Thank you so very much.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't be apart of this with me. Here is how you can help:

  • Ask your friends & family and help get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools with everyone you know!
  • Also anyone out there that may have "Fly Miles" that they can donate that would be great!!!

And that’s all there is to it. Thank you for your support and LETS DO THIS!!!
story_txt:
About Me:Hey this is John some call me JMike also John Michael...I AM A DANCER... I'm also a drummer in my free-time-all-the-time-whenever-time!! I have been dancing all my young life..since I was 3 to be exact. I am currently 16 so yea that's a long time that I have been performing. My training consists of Ballet, Tap, Jazz, Acrobatics, Lyrical, Contemporary and Modern. I became a dance soloist & competed regionally & nationally by age 7. I traveled with my local dance company to multiple dance competitions and attended dance workshops taught by teachers from all over! So its been a busy & exciting journey. Even when worn out at times it has taught me a great deal and trust me I have alot more to learn. Thank GOD for all my dance teachers along the way and my Morgantown Dance family...but honestly being a boy-in-ballet isn't something you shout out on the rooftops Until now........HEY I AM A DANCER!!!!! I can tell you my dancing has taken notice by many by the awards and dance titles I have achieved over the last 9 years. I must be doing something right..yea? Don't forget who you are, put passion into everything, and don't be afraid to be YOU!!! Please read why I brought you hereMy Campaign: I auditioned this winter for 6 different dance schools that offered a Summer Intensive Program and all of them accepted me, but I can only choose one. Of my top 3 I chose San Francisco Conservatory of Dance...yep the furthest away from home. Honestly I chose it because of its diversity in Classical & Modern dance. Please copy or click the link below and see why this is so important to me. I want to be there but only if you help me...            http://www.sfconservatoryofdance.org/about-us                     What I Need & What You GetHere is the breakdown in more detail:

story:
THE TUCKING OF MY SHREW

HOMOHOTDISH, a Minnesota-based performance group dedicated to creating new and eccentric queer work, is pulling together their third production for Minnesota Fringe 2014. "The Tucking of My Shrew" is HOMOHOTDISH's largest show to date, following up the group's premiere of "I DO! I DO!" at 20% Theater last October. Our last show had rollerskating bridesmaids and an all-knowing pregnant deity... who knows what this one will have in store.

In "The Tucking of My Shrew", Chastity Burns and Mona S'More are on the run. These two small-town drag queens have been kicked out of their local scene of Lake City, Minnesota, and have come up to the queer twin cities to bring you a glitzy-glam vision of beyond. Their show has songs for the lonely, legs for days, and a life-sized penis that talks. It isn't quite Shakespeare, and it isn't quite drag-- it's Elizabethan Realness (or whatever that means).

The show features Jared Zeigler (performer), Ryan Patrick (performer), Megan Burns (performer), JuCoby Johnson (performer),  Chase Burns (writer/director), Ed Euclid (assist. director), Jack Tillman (stage manager), and Cole Bylander (costume designer). 

"The Tucking of My Shrew" performs at the  Minneapolis Theater Garage on 8/1 @ 5:30, 8/3 @ 4pm, 8/7 @ 7pm, 8/8 @ 5:30pm, and 8/9 @ 10pm.

What We Need & What You Get

We're pretty crafty, but those lace-fronts and heels don't pay for themselves. (Let's not even discuss that giant penis costume we're making.) HOMOHOTDISH is fortunate enough to have fairly low costs, but we still need help raising the $1600 that is venue costs, costumes, photo shoots, marketing, printing, make-up, and rehearsal space costs. The $2000 goal will cover all of our production costs, and begin to pay for actors and crew, as well. Help us make these drag queens' dreams come true!

Here's what you can get!

  • $25 - A shout-out in our program. Updates on the show.
  • $50 - A glittery thank-you card made my drag queens. All other items above.
  • $100 - Drinks with the cast / any cast member you want. You can't take them home, but we'll see how it goes... All other items above.
  • $250 - A shout-out during the show. (We don't play by the rules.) All other items above.
  • $500 - Play "Bianca" on the night you come to the show. (No rehearsal necessary. Again, we don't play by the rules.) All other items above.

What Your Help Means...

We created HOMOHOTDISH because we felt there was a lack of visible, exciting queer work in the Twin Cities. In a little over a year, we've been able to produce two shows, further develop our group's mission, as well as connect with other professionals in the cities. Your help allows us to continue to grow, serve, and create fun ways to connect the queer communities of these cities.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Find us on Facebook and like our page!
  • Share our Indiegogo campaign!
  • Most importantly: Come see our shows!  Ticketing information can be found on the Minnesota Fringe Festival website.


THANK YOU ALL!

story:
Short Summary

Shakespeare BASH'd is back after 3 sold out runs with their most ambitious season yet! The company that brought you the 2012 Best of the Fringe winning production of The Taming of the Shrew, sold out runs of Much Ado About Nothing at the 2013 Fringe as well as a sold out production of Romeo and Juliet at the 3030 Dundas West is back at the 2014 Toronto Fringe, producing the zany comedy Love's Labour's Lost!

We're not stopping there, folks. Shakespeare BASH'd is also preparing to present two shows in rep in the winter. That's 3 full length shows to be produced in 2014! We're excited to bring you the best Shakespeare work in Toronto, but in order to do so, we need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

$3000 will help us pay for costumes, rehearsal space, and the rental of performance space for our winter show.  It will help us build sets and buy props. It will, to put it simply, allow us to put on a show. And we really, really want to put on a show for you. 

The Impact

Since our Best of the Fringe winning production of The Taming of the Shrew in 2012, Shakespeare BASH'd has produced some of the best Shakespeare work in Toronto, consistently selling out each production we've mounted. We believe in presenting clear, honest work in a relaxed setting. We want you to be able to enjoy a delightful beverage while enjoying some incredible Shakespeare. 

We want to give you the best entertainment possible. We want to make you laugh, cry and high five. We will high five you, both physically, and meta-physically. When you donate to us, we automatically high-five you with our minds and hearts. 

Please share our campaign with your friends, family, coworkers, or even your rivals. Start a bidding war. Let's get serious with it.  We'll be updating you on our progress, so you can check back here and at www.shakespearebashd.com for details on upcoming events as we lead up to the Toronto Fringe.

story:
About Dorothy and Why We Are Raising Money on This Site:

My daughter, Dorothy Sapyta is 15 years old and working to become a professional dancer and performer.  She has been dancing since age 2, and is currently training, full-time, in New York City with AS Ballet NYC (American Swiss Ballet).  Every penny donated will go directly towards Dorothy going to two European competitions and attending the 2014 Radio City Rockettes Summer Intensive.

Last summer, Dorothy auditioned for and participated in the 2013 Radio City Rockettes Summer Intensive. She has now been accepted to participate in the 2014 Radio City Rocekttes Summer Intensive.  Additionally, she has been working to compete two European International Dance Competitions:  the 17e Concours International de Danse d'Aix-en-Provence in Aix-en-Provence, France and the Odyssee de la Dans in Lyon, France. 

These three dance opportunities represent a significant expense.  The tuition for the Rockettes Intensive is $1100 and is due April 25, 2014.  The two European competitions will entail airfare, housing, transportation, meals and entry fees.  Additionally there is the added expense of competition costumes and private training to prepare.  The competitions are the last week of April and the first week of May.

Our household income is tied in with the US Military procurement.  The sequester last year, followed by the government shutdown represented a significant decrease in our overall income, thus the need for fundraising.  Additionally, we live on Rockaway Beach in New York City and were personally impacted significantly by Hurricane Sandy.  Dorothy has some businesses of her own, making keychains, jewelery and decorated sea shells, but she doesn't make enough to really help with these larger expenses.

Dorothy has dreamed of becoming a professional dancer since she was a small child and these opportunities would further her goal for a career as a professional dancer immensely.

Please donate to help her attend these competitions and intensives.

Thank you for your consideration.

story:
ABOUT US

The Pulp Stage is a non-profit theatre company based out of Portland, Oregon. For over six years, we have been providing intimate, live storytelling for fans of science fiction, fantasy and suspense.

Running on countless hours of volunteer time, we are building a dream: to provide communities with scripts that are

1) accessible to performers.

2) irresistible to audiences.

 

ABOUT YOUR DONATION

Your help makes a real difference: this campaign will fund more than 60% of our budget for 2017. The year's bold new step is to release our first e-book of scripts. Everyone else in the world will finally have the chance to use our easy-to-produce material to rivet their communities. 

Now, let's stay transparent. Anyone can throw an e-book onto Amazon for $0...

...why are we tying the e-book into our $3000 fundraiser?

The e-book is the culmination of our work as a company. In order to keep moving forward, the company needs helpers like you. Donations like yours will fund

-the general operations that keep the ground under our feet. You'll be helping us pay for postage, printing, board insurance, event insurance, office supplies, etc.

-community expansion projects. You'll be helping us pay for special events that we host, appearances in festivals and conventions, plus sample readings in homes and schools.

-performances that test the effectiveness of our scripts and inspire future work. You'll be helping us pay for venue rental, actor reimbursement, playwright royalties and playbill printing.

General Operations + Community Expansion + Shows = Scripts and e-book for everyone!

 

ABOUT YOUR PERKS

Remember, your donation is tax-deductible, minus the value of any perks.

If you want some fun, we've got

-the Pulp Stage shirts.

-the Pulp Stage Infinity Scarf (?!!... oh yes, we've got it).

-the Pulp Stage coaster (and who doesn't want a coaster with a splat built into the logo?).

-classic company posters.

-a new original Pulp Stage coloring book.

-gift combo packages.

*plus* the chance to sponsor company stunts:

-get your full name as a character in one of our online monologues.

-get Pulp Stage company members and collaborators to sing pop songs while bucking like chickens...

Every perk is something you'll treasure and want to share.


ABOUT THE COMPANY'S TRACK RECORD

The Pulp Stage makes things happen. You're adding to an organization that has

-successfully funded 2 previous Indiegogo campaigns.

-developed 40 plays in our format.

-produced over 30 showcases and special events.

-collaborated with over 60 actors in the state of Oregon.

-created over 290 (yes, 290) free monologues for actors of any gender...

...and we're truly just getting started.

 
ABOUT YOUR OTHER WAYS IN
 
No donation cash on hand? No problem. Some more ways you can join the movement.
 
1) Did you know that we can be supported *at no cost to you* every time you shop at Amazon or Fred Meyer? Type in "The Pulp Stage" as your charitable organization.
 
FOR AMAZON, GO TO
smile.amazon.com/ch/38-3880484
 
FOR FRED MEYER, GO TO
tinyurl.com/fredpulp
 
2) Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter and other social media!

story:
What is The Long Tides?

The Long Tides is a new devised physical theater piece that explores themes around time, with inspiration from Ted Talks, corporate seminars, and advances in physics. The piece is told through the lens of intrepid call center worker Joann Merriweather. Tasked with leading her co-workers in a time management seminar, Joann must look at how she spends her own time, and how her minutes add up. Weaving together clown, movement, audience participation and narrative, The Long Tides is at turns both comic character sketch and poignant audit of how we spend our minutes--and what happens in the moments that stand out.

Who You're Supporting

Nicole Quenelle (that's me!) is an interdisciplinary, independent theater artist focused on physical approaches to writing, devising, character, and ensemble building for original theater and film projects. Currently based in Philadelphia, she spent 10 years performing with regional theater companies in her hometown of Durham, North Carolina before training in Lecoq-based physical theater in Florence, Italy. She was a company member of  Durham, NC’s Little Green Pig for seven years, with which she performed and collaborated on many original works and adaptations--originating with the Bard, Beckett, Dostoyevsky, Goethe, and others--and transforming them into reimagined works by the company in traditional theater spaces and site-specific locations. The Long Tides is her first full-length self-produced work since completing a graduate level physical theater program in Italy. More info: nicolequenelle.com

I'm also lucky to be working with some talented designers on The Long Tides:
Michael Lambui - Lighting Designer
Brad Pouliot - Sound Designer
Brad and Michael are both recent graduates of University of the Arts here in Philly. We are working in a studio space that has no light or sound infrastructure, so their work on The Long Tides will be a highly creative pursuit to help me rig creative, beautiful, and affordable lighting and sound design to augment this piece. I am thrilled to have them on this project, and hope that their work with this piece will help them continue to build their already impressive design portfolios.

I'm also very excited to be working with a writing consultant and a few outside eyes -- artists whose work I respect enormously. I'm confident they will help me realize a strong vision for this piece and I'm humbled and grateful to be working with them. Those discussions are still in the works, but I hope to shout out their names very soon!

What I Need & The Impact Of Your Contribution

Development of The Long Tides to date has been supported by a gratis residency at Drop Forge & Tool in Hudson, NY and generous contribution of rehearsal space from FringeArts in Philadelphia. But aside from this support, I have been working on a shoestring, first-time-self-producing artist's budget.

I'm now in the final, most rigorous, and most important stage of the development--the final two months before the show premiers in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival--and monetary support is more important than ever. Your contribution will help me pay for:
  • Fringe Festival registration fees
  • Liability insurance
  • Artist fees (this is perhaps the most important thing on this list -- it's very important to me that I'm able to pay the artists I'm working with for their time and talent, and secondarily reimburse myself for my own expenses)
  • Printing of publicity materials
  • Set, costume and prop materials
  • Lighting and sound equipment
  • Photography and videography
  • Processing fees for this crowdfunding campaign


Risks & Challenges

There's an enormous amount of work that goes into self-producing beyond the creative part of what you end up seeing. If you're a regular arts patron, chances are, this is not news to you. But the point is, the more I can raise toward my financial goal, the more I can focus on the creative part of making this piece, which is so critical to realizing a strong creative vision of what I offer. I am enormously grateful for any contribution you can make that will help me meet this goal. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We're also looking for volunteers to get involved with the production. I could use a hand with:
  • Distribution of show postcards and other publicity materials
  • Box office volunteers (taking tickets before shows)
  • Finding/making props and set pieces

Please get in touch if you'd like to get involved!

So much love,
Nicole


(Video cover photo by Hannah Van Sciver. Image editing by Nicole Quenelle.)

We are working in a studio space that has no light or sound infrastructure, so their work on The Long Tides will be a highly creative pursuit to help me rig creative, beautiful, and affordable lighting and sound design to augment this piece. I am thrilled to have them on this project, and hope that their work with this piece will help them continue to build their already impressive design portfolios. I'm also very excited to be working with a writing consultant and a few outside eyes -- artists whose work I respect enormously. I'm confident they will help me realize a strong vision for this piece and I'm humbled and grateful to be working with them. Those discussions are still in the works, but I hope to shout out their names very soon! 
  What I Need & The Impact Of Your Contribution
 Development of The Long Tides to date has been supported by a gratis residency 
at Drop Forge & Tool in Hudson, NY and generous contribution of 
rehearsal space from FringeArts in Philadelphia. But aside from this support, I have been working on a shoestring, first-time-self-producing artist's budget. I'm now in the final, most rigorous, and most important stage of the development--the final two months before the show premiers in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival--and monetary support is more important than ever. Your contribution will help me pay for:
Fringe Festival registration fees
Liability insurance
Artist fees (this is perhaps the most important thing on this list -- it's very important to me that I'm able to pay the artists I'm working with for their time and talent, and secondarily reimburse myself for my own expenses)

Printing of publicity materials
Set, costume and prop materials
Lighting and sound equipment
Photography and videography
Processing fees for this crowdfunding campaign



Risks & Challenges
There's an enormous amount of work that goes into self-producing beyond the creative part of what you end up seeing. If you're a regular arts patron, chances are, this is not news to you. But the point is, the more I can raise toward my financial goal, the more I can focus on the creative part of making this piece, which is so critical to realizing a strong creative vision of what I offer. I am enormously grateful for any contribution you can make that will help me meet this goal.      
Other Ways You Can HelpWe're also looking for volunteers to get involved with the production. I could use a hand with:
Distribution of show postcards and other publicity materials

Box office volunteers (taking tickets before shows)
Finding/making props and set pieces

Please get in touch if you'd like to get involved!So much love,Nicole

(Video cover photo by Hannah Van Sciver. Image editing by Nicole Quenelle.)

story:
Bringing the show to life:

My name is Aimee Woods. I am the artistic director of MOVE.  With our producer, Magnolia Music Studio, we are going to bring this new and engaging cabaret musical to Northern Colorado!  

THE PLAN

 The Preview Performances will be Aug 5-7 at Magnolia Music Studio. Then, pending acceptance, we will be performing the Fort Collins Fringe Festival in September, and plan to pursue producing a fully staged production in late 2016. 

What We Need & What You Get

What will your contribution be used for?  That is an excellent question!  

We are hoping to raise $2000 toward our production costs.  Whether we meet our goal, or not, here is what we plan to use the funds raised for: 

1) To hire an amazing collaborative pianist and other live musicians (bass, guitar, drums, cello, clarinet, just to name a few)

2) To pay production costs (such as venue rentals, lighting, sound, etc)

3) To purchase additional performance rights for the show

4) To pay the professional performers 

5) And all remaining funds will be used to pay for programs, advertising and to fund additional performances!

  • What are the Perks?  Well, other than our undying gratitude?  See the section on the right side of the page for the fun perks associated with donating to our show!

The Impact

MOVE has successfully performed concerts and one-act operas. Now we plan to bring [Sorta] Love Songs to the Northern Colorado community.

One of the reasons we love this show is that it addresses several relevant social issues in an accessible way. Yes, there are some light-hearted love songs too.  There are also songs that deal with loss, fear,  harassment, and adultery.  

Risks & Challenges

Putting on a musical that no one has performed in the area is a challenge.  MOVE has successfully performed concerts and one-act operas. Now we plan to bring [Sorta] Love Songs to the Northern Colorado community.  We are a small arts group in a large arts community, which is a benefit to us as we will be using many local and social media formats (as we have for past productions) to reach out to our audience. To take this production to the next level, we plan to use a small portion of the funds raised to also advertise in the surrounding communities. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that some of you are not in a place to contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out!  Share this with your friends! Tell the local arts organizations about us! 
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

About the Creators of [Sorta] Love Songs: Scott Burkell and Paul Loesel's songs have been performed at Carnegie Hall (Michael Feinstein: Now and Then series), Lincoln Center (American Songbook Series), Joe's Pub, Birdland, Symphony Space, The Kennedy Center and the Chicago Humanities Festival. Their songs have been premiered by Kristin Chenoweth, Rebecca Luker, Marin Mazzie, Jason Danieley, Stephanie J. Block, Susan Egan, and Liz Callaway. Recordings of their work are heard on Marin Mazzie and Jason Danieley's "Opposite You" recording, Stephanie J. Block's "This Place I Know" and Rebecca Luker's "Greenwich Time." Their musical Six of One received a Jonathan Larson Performing Arts Foundation Grant, an ASCAP workshop, a CAP21 workshop, and a production in the 2007 Philly Fringe Festival. Their new musical, Ella Minnow Pea received a production at the University of Michigan. Loesel is the most recent recipient of the Burton Lane Award. For more information visit www.scottandpaul.com.

story:
Short Summary

In 2013, Kelly Wilson, Anna St. Hilaire & Sara Neville came together to found Avenue Theater Company. Their goal was to create fun, fresh and professional-quality community musical theater in Philadelphia.

What We Need & What You Get

Now entering it's 3rd season, we are seeking to expand what it means to do community theater in Center City. We've enjoyed two summers of successful shows but are ready to take our company to the next level. Our team has grown significantly, both in size and talent, and we hope to match the quality of our team with a higher overall production value.

This year we are thrilled to be performing at the brand new Louis Bluver Theater at the Drake on the Avenue of the Arts and want to continue being in Philly's newest and most accessible venues.

Here's the Challenge: Help us raise $2,500 in 25 days in honor of our summer 2016 production of "The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee!"

Here's what your contribution will go towards:
- Innovative set design & construction
- High quality costumes & props
- Professional pit orchestra musicians
- Wide-spread publicity & marketing

And a breakdown dollar-for-dollar, what your contribution will fund:
$12= One hour of rehearsal space rental
$25= One hour with an accompanist
$35= One hour of tech rehearsal space rental
$50=  Custom costume piece
$75= Small run of show publicity posters
$100= A special effects set piece
$150= Spotlight rental
$250= Set construction supplies
$350= One musician for the run of a show

The Impact

We have had two years of well-attended and well-received productions and are thankful to our patrons for helping us achieve that, but we are eager to stand out as a quality theater company in Center City Philadelphia. Being able to provide the items above will help us become a standout company AND give us more flexibility to focus on expanding what we do both in terms of theatrical programming and how often we can produce shows.

We would like to be fully funded by August 1, 2016- only 25 days from now!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't help out with a monetary donation, you can still help spread the word about our company and our upcoming production of "The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee!"  Like us on Facebook and follow us on Instagram and make sure to share our campaign with #ATC25in25.

We look forward to continuing to provide summer musical theater for Philadelphia in the coming years and can't wait for what's next to come for Avenue Theater.

Thanks!
Kelly, Anna, Wesley, Chloe & Danielle

 

Avenue Theater Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Avenue Theater Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Season 13 Will Be Better Than Ever

The Other Place by Sharr White is a sharp-tongued, fast-paced, witty, powerhouse of a drama — one perfectly suited for Chimera Productions’ 13th season. Juliana is an accomplished scientist on the precipice of a revolutionary discovery that could help thousands of people and make her very wealthy. She is also contemplating divorce, trying to connect with her estranged daughter Laurel (who ran off with Juliana’s doctoral assistant), and desperate to make it through this last big pitch to her restless investors. It might all work out if she can just manage to focus on the next slide.

Directed by Drew Griffiths & Jeffrey Alan Davis

Starring: 
Michelle Wood
Nishika Bagchi
David Sullivan
Alex Leonhardt

July 19,20,21
Curtain 8pm (Doors 7:30pm)
The Arts Council of Princeton 
102 Witherspoon Street
Princeton, NJ 08542

About Chimera Productions

Chimera Productions was founded by a group of artists who produce plays solely for their artistic merit. Why Chimera Productions? A Chimera is an imaginary monster comprised of incongruous parts; an illusion or fabrication of the mind; something that is fantastically visionary, improbable or the product of an unchecked imagination.

The company’s goal is to only produce work that is interesting, enlightening, and not often seen; to explore the power of theater, and the bond between artist and live audience. The Other Place is our 13th consecutive production at the Arts Council of Princeton.

 

What's In It For You

YOU GET THE BEST SEATS IN THE HOUSE!
Almost every perk comes with PREFERRED SEATING for one of the three performances.

This guarantees you get one of the best seats for your selected performance. We also have goodie bags, date night perks, drinks and dinner packages, plus if you or your friends are big spenders, your own private performance! No matter what everyone who donates gets a Thank You in our program. 

PLEASE NOTE MOST PERKS ARE FOR 1 OR 2 TICKETS WITH PREFERRED SEATING. IF YOU WANT MORE THAN 2 PREFERRED SEATS, PLEASE LEAVE US A MESSAGE BY CLICKING "ASK A QUESTION" AT THE TOP RIGHT AND WE WILL GET BACK TO YOU WITH OPTIONS.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We know not everyone can afford to help financially but there are other ways you can help spread the word.
  • You can share this campaign with your friends, family and theater lovers.
  • Like and share us on Facebook and tell your friends.
  • Regram, like, and comment on Instagram @Chimera_Productions.
  • Hand out postcards or posters in your area. We will send them to you!
  • You can come to the show and bring someone who's never seen our productions!

 

What Your Money Will Be Used For

It's simple: 100% of your money winds up directly on the stage. Your donations help to cover the expense of renting theater space, building sets, transportation and lights. What is even more amazing, is our entire cast and crew donates their time to help craft our production. Plus our theater space is also a non-profit community arts home so your funds will continue to give back to the community after the show.

Every donation helps us keep ticket prices affordable to everyone. That way everyone has the opportunity to experience the power of theater for less than a night out at the movies!

 

Thank you so much and see you at the show!!

story:
Winter Dimes for Summertime

During this time of giving, we hope you can spare some change for Theatre-Hikes during our winter slumber. There are many reasons to help us out:

  • We combine Exercise, Environment and Entertainment in 1 afternoon.
  • We work hard to instill an appreciation and care for our natural environments.
  • We hold strong to our values of paying every artist who works with us.
  • We try to support Chicago based actors, designers, playwrights, etc feeding your money back into this economy.

Please consider making a tax deductible donation to our cause.

How can I help?

We have 3 ways you can contribute this fall:

  • There are several perks to donating through our IndieGoGo Campaign.
  • You can always donate on our website or by sending a check to our address from our website, www.Theatre-Hikes.org
  • If you don't have financial means we can always use volunteers, or perhaps one of the gifts you got wasn't quite for you and maybe would work well for us, we also have a wish list.

The Impact is HUGE

Your money goes primarily to paying people; enriching the arts and economy in the Chicago-land area.  We pay a competitive rate to theaters our size in the Chicago area and if we make more in donations we can raise the wages of our employees, have money for more positions to help our shows improve or increase budgets to make things a little easier for our designers and directors.

story:
Two (2) one-act comedies in one show. June, 2015.

JUNE THEME: Eat the Poor, Strip the Rich explores the fears and frustrations faced by the shrinking middle class:

  • OUT AT SEA, three shipwrecked survivors decide which of them will be eaten by the others.  It's SURVIVOR meets BASTARD CHEF.
  • STRIPTEASE, two middle managers struggle for control against a mysterious online force. It’s as if Mark Zuckerberg wrote OFFICE SPACE.

Yes they’re short, pointed satire that are weird and fun and dark. 

While one act plays are nothing new, Under the Gun has reframed and updated two great pieces by Slawomir Mrozek, the Polish satirist.

Mrozek’s exposures of the hidden links between culture and power are EXACTLY the kind of inventive, bizarre, reflective shows that Chicago needs after a mayoral run-off and our thinly veiled class and civil-rights struggles...not to mention dealing with the dubious nick-name, "Chi-raq."

Simply put, we're asking for $5,450 to cover four key costs:

  1. Licensing for two of his one-act plays for performance.
  2. Stipends for the cast and crew of seven. 
  3. Sets/Costumes/Props.
  4. Marketing.
Be a Chicago theater Producer.  (When is the last time you heard that at a party?)
Check out the great perks at different gift amounts: two tickets to opening night...tickets AND a tray of Polish treats...gift certificates to the world famous Red Apple Polish buffet.  We will thank you in the program for even a modest gift. In other words, documented proof that you are a Producer.

Why else?

  • I get it from page to stage.  I recently adapted three Kurt Vonnegut short stories into a critically and financially successful Chicago show, "Drupelets."
  • I know show business is two words.  As a working actor with a business degree, this will be the third Chicago store-front theater show I produce. Over ten years as an actor, clown and improviser at well-known places: ComedySportz, iO, Annoyance.
  • It will be wonderful.  I'm part of the Under the Gun ensemble that regularly performs the hit show, "Comedy Against Humanity" and I hand-picked an absolutely STELLAR cast.  Most of the money is to pay the cast and crew.

Please give what you can.  And if you can only give the gift of word-of-mouth, that's okay too!  But if you can give some cash, do it.

story:
Hi!

Who are we?

Trina is a girl who serves at a pub and studies psychology and mentors women in prison and writes rap songs for her best friends and is genuinely funny and likes driving in her car.

Sam is a girl who serves at a pub and sees her psychologist regularly and teaches her friends to swim and reads a lot and blushes often, sometimes just because someone is looking at her.

We’re running this campaign because we really want to Fringe together, and not just as servers at the bar all the Fringers frequent. We have a story we're really excited to tell and we want to tell it this summer as a Fringe show.

Where you come in:

We need some funds to help us put a great show together and to help cover the cost of taking our show on the road to Winnipeg. It would be much more financially manageable if we were just doing the show in Edmonton, where we live, but we really want to do the show in Manitoba too, as that's where Sam hails from. Taking the necessary time off work, travel expenses, and venue and equipment rentals are all going to add up.

Perks:

If you do fund us, we’ve got a multitude of fun, creative, substantial perks to offer you in return. Any little bit helps (really!) and we’ll show our appreciation by sending you things like t-shirts, poems and stories, portraits, tickets to the show, and cookies! 

Why we think our show is important:

We like to talk about mental health whenever possible in an effort to destigmatize the ways in which we all suffer, and to make it easier for people to leap over that barrier and seek help if/when they need it. Using the Fringe as a platform to talk about mental health isn’t new but we do think our show is a valuable contribution to the overall conversation. We believe mental health care should be much more accessible than it is, and our show is our own small way of offering up some legitimate help while still being a good time.

The current challenge:

We applied for both the Edmonton and Winnipeg Fringes, and sadly we didn’t win either of the lotteries, which means we now have more work to do! In both cities we have to find and book venues, hire technicians to help us out, and rent equipment to pull it all off.

This is exactly what we were crossing our fingers against, but it’s cool, we can do it! 

What else?

Come see our show in either Edmonton or Winnipeg! We’d love to have you!

Follow us on Facebook and Instagram if you want to see us and our insecurities going nuts!

Share this campaign with some people you think will give a shit!

Trina is a girl who serves at a pub and studies psychology and mentors women in prison and writes rap songs for her best friends and is genuinely funny and likes driving in her car.
Sam is a girl who serves at a pub and sees her psychologist regularly and teaches her friends to swim and reads a lot and blushes often, sometimes just because someone is looking at her.
We’re running this campaign because we really want to Fringe together, and not just as servers at the bar all the Fringers frequent. We have a story we're really excited to tell and we want to tell it this summer as a Fringe show.

Where you come in:
We need some funds to help us put a great show together and to help cover the cost of taking our show on the road to Winnipeg. It would be much more financially manageable if we were just doing the show in Edmonton, where we live, but we really want to do the show in Manitoba too, as that's where Sam hails from. Taking the necessary time off work, travel expenses, and venue and equipment rentals are all going to add up.
Perks:
If you do fund us, we’ve got a multitude of fun, creative, substantial perks to offer you in return. Any little bit helps (really!) and we’ll show our appreciation by sending you things like t-shirts, poems and stories, portraits, tickets to the show, and cookies! 

Why we think our show is important:
We like to talk about mental health whenever possible in an effort to destigmatize the ways in which we all suffer, and to make it easier for people to leap over that barrier and seek help if/when they need it. Using the Fringe as a platform to talk about mental health isn’t new but we do think our show is a valuable contribution to the overall conversation. We believe mental health care should be much more accessible than it is, and our show is our own small way of offering up some legitimate help while still being a good time.

The current challenge:
We applied for both the Edmonton and Winnipeg Fringes, and sadly we didn’t win either of the lotteries, which means we now have more work to do! In both cities we have to find and book venues, hire technicians to help us out, and rent equipment to pull it all off.
This is exactly what we were crossing our fingers against, but it’s cool, we can do it! 

What else?
Come see our show in either Edmonton or Winnipeg! We’d love to have you!
Follow us on Facebook and Instagram if you want to see us and our insecurities going nuts!
Share this campaign with some people you think will give a shit!

story:
The Impact

Vampires don't play by the rules. Pan-sexual & alternative, vampires push boundaries and literally take a bite out of life. As such, our three concerts for Mythos will challenge expectations of attraction and desire. At each performance the lead roles of Mythos will be cast to explore different manifestations of love, lust and power: Traditional, Alternative and LGBTQ+.

Thu, Aug 2nd @ 6:00 p.m. - Traditional casting

Fri, Aug 3rd @ 7:00 p.m. - Alternative casting (talk-back following concert)

Sat, Aug  4th @ 3:00 p.m. - LGBTQ+ casting (talk-back following concert)

Who we are

Heather Jopling (Librettist) and David Velarde (Composer) collaborated to create Mythos: The Crimson Chorus - an original vampire rock opera.

Heather got the theatre bug when she was 11 years old. She debuted in The Sound of Music at Kingston Elementary School, having worked her way from Ensemble Nun to Major Nun, Understudy to Brigitta, Brigitta and then finally Louisa (while still retaining Brigitta's big scene with Maria). Through her subsequent decades, Heather has written and directed plays, founded a Shakespeare company, created diversity-friendly children's books, written deliciously trashy romance novels and been a surrogate mother for gay fathers.

When David was 5 years old, he already knew all the songs of Sound Of Music, West Side Story and Seven Brides For Seven Brothers by heart. By the 8th grade, David had become an orphan in Oliver. Having graduated from Carnegie Mellon University's Classical Voice program, David has gone on to perform lead roles for Broadway and European tours and also on TV. David’s musical, Autumn Moon, ran Off-Broadway in 2006. Mythos: The Crimson Chorus is David’s third musical theatre composition. 

Our Outstanding Cast for NYMF:

 

Where your money goes

The funds we raise through IndieGoGo will be directed towards practical production costs for our participation in the 2018 New York Musical Festival.  

We plan to raise $12,000 on Indiegogo to cover 50% of our production budget.  Included in our budget is:

  • Renting rehearsal space in New York
    (2 week rehearsal period)
  • Paying 18 Collaborative Artists a living wage 
    (13 Actors/Singers, 3 Musicians, 1 Music Director, 1 General Manager)
  • PR/Advertising to get bums in the seats
    (press releases, posters, postcards, ads, programs)
  • Insurance to protect all those working on these concerts

We have created a piece of theatre with engaging characters, global themes and great musical scope.   With your financial help we can get this show ready take New York by storm.  Please help make our vampire dreams come true!

Please spread the word by liking our Facebook, Twitter and web pages.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone has cash to spare. You can still help Mythos get up and singing!

  • You can get the word out on social media and make some noise about our campaign.
  • You can share Mythos on IndieGoGo

story:
The Navigators Theater Company

The Navigators produce produce Science Fiction Theater with a clear feminist perspective. We are dedicated to elevating female driven stories in a genre dominated by men by empowering women playwrights, producers, directors, designers, and actors in our productions. We seek to engage new audiences, realize new and daring realities, and expand the boundaries of what theater can achieve by fully exploring sci-fi on stage.

Founding Members:

Bella Poynton (Artistic Director and Resident Playwright), Ariel Francoeur (Producing Artistic Director and Resident Director) and Melina Neves (Literary Manager and Resident Actor) met at the University of Iowa, and decided that their mutual passion for science fiction, feminist thought, and amazing theatre was too great to ignore! The company was formed in 2014. Since then we have produced over 50 short science fiction plays with feminist themes.

Since their inception, The Navigators have produced:

  • Three weekend-long Science Fiction Theatre Festivals called The Lift-Off New Play Series during which we have produced over 50 new plays!
  • A full scale production of Bella Poynton's The Aurora Project in 2017
  • The Dark Matter Reading Series of new Science Fiction plays in development
  • Three Commissioned One Acts Readings in collaboration with the Plaxall Gallery in Long Island City.

Why We Need A Mid-Season Boost

This season has been fantastic--our best yet! We've produced our first full scale production, and the Third Annual Lift-Off Series of New Science Fiction Plays. This spring, we are partnering with the Long Island City Artists (LIC-A) at the Plaxall Gallery in LIC to bring you three brand new commissioned one-act sci-fi plays, which will be presented in the same space as brand new commissioned Sci-fi visual art. But towards the end of the season, things can get tough. This small boost will help pay for:

  • Costumes for the Three Commissioned One Acts
  • Prop accessories for the Three Commissioned One Acts
  • Projection Design
  • Audition and rehearsal space.

We want to assure all of our collaborators, partners, and fans that our Commissioned One Acts as well as the 4th Annual Lift-Off Festival will go on as planned with or without this boost--we do not plan on stopping!  However, this small amount of aid will help us a great deal, and allow us to give the upcoming One-Acts the resources and attention they deserve. 

Please consider donating today. Every dollar counts!

story:
What's it all about?

Our Mission

Over March and April we will spend three weeks between Berlin and Bristol developing a first draft of the show. We will then present two work-in-progress performances at The Wardrobe Theatre, Bristol on the 16th and 17th April.

These performances will allow us to share the work and get valuable feedback from the public, invited groups from the BAME community, the One25 Charity for women at risk of, or trapped in, street sex work, the LGBTQ+ community and YOU. We will also be showcasing the work to programmers who will book it for their venues in future.

We want you to be part of our making process, and we need your support to make this production soar.

About the Show

John Gay's original play 'Polly' is a brilliantly sharp, raucous romp through the Caribbean under the British Empire. A cutting satire on our colonial expansions, the wealth of the criminals, the criminality of wealth and the gender and sexual politics of its time.

Brecht, Weill and Haupmann's  'Threepenny Opera' fused the original world of 18th century London with their own: early 20th Century Berlin. It was ground-breaking, and has resonated through the art world for decades. It is easy to see its influence in the work of a diverse set of artists, writers and musicians, Nina Simone, Nick Cave and Amanda Palmer for example, directors like Joan Littlewood and Peter Brook and theatre companies like Kneehigh and Complicité. 

We will do the same to 'Polly'. Our adaptation will fuse the past with our present, #MeToo, black lives matter, contemporary slavery and sex traficking, as well 21st Century questions of gender and sexuality. We will also explore our complicated relationship with our colonial legacy.

From that vantage point we will retell the story of Macheath's three wives; Polly Peachum, Jenny Diver and Lucy Lockit, making a dirty, sexy, grotesque, heartbreaking modern day opera.

Its score will be genre-bending, with Ben's original music fusing multi-textured folk harmonies and 18th Century ballads, power-pop with soul and jazz and, of course, Berlin techno. 

There will be pregnant murderers, jilted brides and washed up cabaret singers.

We will uncompromisingly dissect politics, economics, sexuality, gender, love and hate, and make  a show that can connect to the Harvey Weinstein scandal as well as it can to Brexit. Looking at Britain's past, and to its future.

But to create something this complex, rich and nuanced we need your support!

Photography by Paul Blakemore

Why should you support us?

In this time of funding cuts and austerity it's crucially important to let the arts be a place where risks can be taken, where we can question the world, and where we can have conversations that are relevant nationally and internationally.

It's also critical that cross-cultural collaboration continues to receive support as the UK separates from Europe. Our time in Berlin will let us engage with other perspectives, infuse our work with new influences, promote long-lasting artistic connections and allow us to reflect on the UK from abroad.

The #MeToo movement has galvanised conversation in online public spaces and in real life, and we need to make sure that these conversations and stories are happening in our art too. 

Art is a space where we can reflect, walk in other people's shoes, and communicate in languages richer and more nuanced than our verbal language can be. 

To develop a piece of theatre that can properly talk to all of us takes time and investment. 

We have wrestled as much in-kind support as we can, explored arts council funding options, approached private investors (we have already secured £2,000 from one brilliant private donor) and now we need to match that with your support to make this project the best it can be.

Who Are We?

Stephanie Kempson, Director

Steph is a Bristol-based director, dramaturg and writer, and is the artistic director of Sharp Teeth Theatre.  

She was assistant director on Sally Cookson’s Jane Eyre at Bristol Old Vic, which later transferred to the National and toured all over the UK. She is a graduate of National Theatre's Directors Scheme 2017, Bristol Old Vic’s Made in Bristol Scheme, and winner of the 2014 JMK Regional Young Director's Bursary. She has an MA in film, theatre and literary adaptation from the University of York. 

Her work has been performed at The Royal Festival Hall, Battersea Arts Centre, The Tobacco Factory, Bristol Old Vic and Theatre Royal Bath. 

Ben Osborn, Musical Director

Ben lives in Berlin and is a composer, sound designer and songwriter. He is the musical director of the multi-award winning Fellswoop Theatre Company, and he has collaborated with many other companies internationally.

Recently he has worked with the Young Vic, the Bristol Old Vic, and the Finbrough.

His soundtracks and songs have won the Cameron Mackintosh Award for Musical Theatre, the Methuen Drama Emerging Artists Award, Ignite Critics’ Choice Award, the Peter Brooke Empty Space Award and a Manchester Theatre Award.

Marie Hamilton, Performer

Marie trained at the Ecole Philippe Gaulier and is based between Bristol and London, working in theatre, film, radio and TV.

She has worked at the Almeida, the Soho Theatre, the Arcola, the Tobacco Factory and the Bristol Old Vic, and performed with companies including Talawa, ATC and Travelling Light.

Over Christmas she was at the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Sally Cookson's smash-hit version of The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe.

Madeline Shann, Performer

Madeline is a dancer, choreographer and musician (Be Still My Heart).

She has worked with Eclipse theatre company, Sheffield Theatres and the Bush, and performed in RashDash's large-scale outdoor work The Darkest Corners.

Her own works includes one-woman show Little Terrors and dance theatre ensemble piece Sex In Real Life. She is currently assistant director on Black Men Walking, directed by Dawn Walton at The Royal Court, West Yorkshire Playhouse, Bristol Old Vic and The Royal Exchange, Manchester.

Photography by Paul Blakemore

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise £3000 to pay for our travel, rehearsal space, promotional photos, poster and leaflet design and printing, plus the fee for our dramaturg, Nicole Kehrberger. 

Any extra above and beyond this will help us with producing support, stage management, set design, lighting design and our subsistence.

COSTS

- Flights, trains and bus transfers for 5 People: £910

- Subsidised Rehearsal Space: £220

- Dramaturgy: £450

- Promotional Photography: £200

- Poster and Leaflet Design: £110

- Poster and Leaflet Printing: £80

-Instrument Hire and Tuning: £150

-Costumes, £40 each: £120

Grand Total: £2,890

That is a huge amount. None of us are getting paid, and we have already spent a lot of our own time and money getting the show to this point. If you are able to help us cover some of our costs, we would be enormously grateful. In return we have some great perks for you!

Make a pledge and get yourself: Badges, Social Media Shout Outs, Tickets to the Show, or perhaps even a Love Letter...

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that making philanthropic donations to fringe theatre companies is not always a possibility for people. Your support would be hugely appreciated in other ways too: 

- Share this campaign on social media! 

- Email friends who might be interested!

- Come to our work in progress showing at The Wardrobe, Bristol on the 16th and 17th April!
